column2: HE in the ancient way by strength engendered, lo! straight hath taken to himself all wisdom. The waters and the bowl have made him friendly. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

column1: saḥ pūrvayā ni vidā kavyatā āyoḥ imāḥ pra jāḥ ajanayat manūnām vivasvatā cakṣasā dyām apaḥ ca devāḥ agnim dhārayan draviṇaḥ dām
column2: At Âyu's ancient call he by his wisdom gave all this progeny of men their being, And, by refulgent light, heaven and the waters. The Gods possessed the wealth. bestowing Agni.

column1: tam il̥ata prathamam yajña sādham viśaḥ ārīḥ āhutam r̥ñjasānam ūrjaḥ putram bharatam sr̥pra dānum devāḥ agnim dhārayan draviṇaḥ dām
column2: Praise him, ye Aryan folk, as chief performer of sacrifice adored and ever toiling, Well-tended, Son of Strength, the Constant Giver. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

column1: saḥ mātariśvā puruvāra puṣṭiḥ vidat gātum tanayāya svaḥ vit viśām gopāḥ janitā rodasyoḥ devāḥ agnim dhārayan draviṇaḥ dām
column2: That Mâtariṣvan rich in wealth and treasure, light-winner, finds a pathway for his offispring. Guard of our folk, Father of earth and heaven. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

column1: naktoṣasā varṇam āmemyāneity āmemyāne dhāpayeteiti śiśum ekam samīcī itisam īcī dyāvākṣāmā rukmaḥ antaḥ vi bhāti devāḥ agnim dhārayan draviṇaḥ dām
column2: Night and Dawn, changing each the other's colour, meeting together suckle one same Infant: Golden between the heaven and earth he shineth. The Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

column1: rāyaḥ budhnaḥ sam gamanaḥ vasūnām yajñasya ketuḥ manma sādhanaḥ veḥ amr̥ta tvam rakṣamāṇāsaḥ enam devāḥ agnim dhārayan draviṇaḥ dām
column2: Root of wealth, gathering-place of treasures, banner of sacrifice, who grants the suppliant's wishes: Preserving him as their own life immortal, the Gods possessed the wealth-bestowing Agni.

column1: nu ca purā ca sadanam rayīṇām jātasya ca jāyamānasya ca kṣām sataḥ ca gopām bhavataḥ ca bhūreḥ devāḥ agnim dhārayan draviṇaḥ dām
column2: Now and of old the home of wealth, the mansion of what is born and what was born aforetime, Guard of what is and what will be hereafter,– the Gods possessed the wealth bestowing Agni.

column1: draviṇaḥ dāḥ draviṇasaḥ turasya draviṇaḥ dāḥ sanarasya pra yaṁsat draviṇaḥ dāḥ vīra vatīm iṣam naḥ draviṇaḥ dāḥ rāsate dīrgham āyuḥ
column2: May the Wealth-Giver grant us conquering riches; may the Wealth-Giver grant us wealth with heroes. May the Wealth-Giver grant us food with offspring, and length of days may the Wealth-Giver send us.

column1: eva naḥ agne sam idhā vr̥dhānaḥ revat pāvaka śravase vi bhāhi tat naḥ mi traḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: Fed with our fuel, purifying Agni, so blaze to us auspiciously for glory. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: apa naḥ śośucat agham agne śuśugdhi ā rayim apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: CHASING with light our sin away, O Agni, shine thou wealth on us. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: su kṣetriyā sugātu yā vasu yā ca yajāmahe apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: For goodly fields, for pleasant homes, for wealth we sacrifice to thee. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: pra yat bhandiṣṭhaḥ eṣām pra asmākāsaḥ ca sūrayaḥ apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: Best praiser of all these be he; foremost, our chiefs who sacrifice. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: pra yat te agne sūrayaḥ jāyemahi pra te vayam apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: So that thy worshippers and we, thine, Agni, in our sons may live. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: pra yat agneḥ sahasvataḥ viśvataḥ yanti bhānavaḥ apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: As ever- conquering Agni's beams of splendour go to every side, May his light chase our sin away.

column1: tvam hi viśvataḥ mukha viśvataḥ pari bhūḥ asi apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: To every side thy face is turned, thou art triumphant everywhere. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: dviṣaḥ naḥ viśvataḥ mukha ati nāvāiva pāraya apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: O thou whose face looks every way, bear us past foes as in a ship. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: saḥ naḥ sindhum iva nāvayā ati parṣa svastaye apa naḥ śośucat agham
column2: As in a ship, convey thou us for our advantage o'er the flood. May his light chase our sin away.

column1: vaiśvānarasya su matau syāma rājā hi kam bhuvanānām abhi śrīḥ itaḥ jātaḥ viśvam idam vi caṣṭe vaiśvānaraḥ yatate sūryeṇa
column2: STILL in Vaiṣvânara's grace may we continue: yea, he is King supreme o'er all things living. Sprung hence to life upon this All he looketh. Vaiṣvânara hath rivalry with Sûrya.

column1: pr̥ṣṭaḥ divi pr̥ṣṭaḥ agniḥ pr̥thivyām pr̥ṣṭaḥ viśvāḥ oṣadhīḥ ā viveśa vaiśvānaraḥ sahasā pr̥ṣṭaḥ agniḥ saḥ naḥ divā saḥ riṣaḥ pātu naktam
column2: Present in heaven, in earth, all-present Agni,– all plants that grow on ground hath he pervaded. May Agni, may Vaiṣvânara with vigour, present, preserve us day and night from foemen.

column1: vaiśvānara tava tat satyam astu asmān rāyaḥ maghavānaḥ sacantām tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: Be this thy truth, Vaiṣvânara, to us-ward: let wealth in rich abundance gather round us. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: jata vedase sunavāma somam arāti yataḥ ni dahāti vedaḥ saḥ naḥ parṣat ati duḥ gāni viśvā nāvāiva sindhum duḥ itā ati agniḥ
column2: FOR Jâtavedas let us press the Soma: may he consume the wealth of the malignant. May Agni carry us through all our troubles, through grief as in a boat across the river.

column1: saḥ yaḥ vr̥ṣā vr̥ṣṇyebhiḥ sam okāḥ mahaḥ divaḥ pr̥thivyāḥ ca sam rāṭ satīna satvā havyaḥ bhareṣu marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: MAY he who hath his home with strength, the Mighty, the King supreme of earth and spacious heaven, Lord of true power, to he invoked in battles,– may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: yasya anāptaḥ sūryasya iva yāmaḥ bhare bhare vr̥tra hā śuṣmaḥ asti vr̥ṣan tamaḥ sakhi bhiḥ svebhiḥ evaiḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Whose way is unattainable like Sûrya's: he in each fight is the strong Vr̥itra-slayer, Mightiest with his Friends in his own courses. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: divaḥ na yasya retasaḥ dughānāḥ panthāsaḥ yanti śavasā apari itāḥ tarat dveṣāḥ sasahiḥ paiṁsyebhiḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Whose paths go forth in their great might resistless, forthmilking, as it were, heaven's genial moisture. With manly strength triumphant, foe-subduer,– may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ aṅgiraḥ bhiḥ aṅgiraḥ tamaḥ bhūt vr̥ṣā vr̥ṣa bhiḥ sakhi bhiḥ sakhā san r̥gmi bhiḥ r̥gmī gātu bhiḥ jyeṣṭhaḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Among Angirases he was the chiefest, a Friend with friends, mighty amid the mighty. Praiser mid praisers, honoured most of singers. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ sūnu bhiḥ na rudrebhiḥ r̥bhvā nr̥ sahye sasahvān amitrān sa nīl̥ebhiḥ śravasyāni tūrvan marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Strong with the Rudras as with his own children, in manly battle conquering his foemen ' With his close comrades doing deeds of glory,– may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ manyu mīḥ sa madanasya kartā asmākebhiḥ nr̥ bhiḥ sūryam sanat asmi n ahan sat patiḥ puru hūtaḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Humbler of pride, exciter of the conflict, the Lord of heroes, God invoked of many, May he this day gain with our men the sunlight. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be oursuccour.

column1: tam ūtayaḥ raṇayat śūra sātau tam kṣemasya kṣitayaḥ kr̥ṇvata trām saḥ viśvasya karuṇasy a īśe ekaḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: His help hath made him cheerer in the battle, the folk have made him guardian of their comfort. Sole Lord is he of every holy service. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: tam apsanta śavasaḥ ut saveṣu naraḥ naram avase tam dhanāya saḥ andhe cit tamasi jyotiḥ vidat marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: To him the Hero, on high days of prowess, heroes for help and booty shall betake them. He hath found light even in the blinding darkness. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ savyena yamati vrādhataḥ cit saḥ dakṣiṇe sam gr̥bhītā kr̥tāni saḥ kīriṇā cit sanitā dhanāni marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: He with his left hand checketh even the mighty, and with his righthand gathereth up the booty. Even with the humble he acquireth riches. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ grāmebhiḥ sanitā saḥ rathebhiḥ vide viśvābhiḥ kr̥ṣti bhiḥ nu adya saḥ paiṁsyebhiḥ abhi bhūḥ aśastīḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: With hosts on foot and cars he winneth treasures: well is he known this day by all the people. With manly might he conquereth those who hate him. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ jāmi bhiḥ yat sam ajāti mīl̥he ajāmi bhiḥ vā puru hūtaḥ evaiḥ apām tokasya tanayasya jeṣe marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: When in his ways with kinsmen or with strangers he speedeth to the fight, invoked of many, For gain of waters, and of sons and grandsons, may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: saḥ vajra bhr̥t dasyu hā bhīmaḥ ugraḥ sahasra cetāḥ śata nīthaḥ r̥bhvā camrīṣaḥ na śavasā pāñca janyaḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Awful and fierce, fiend-slayer, thunder-wielder, with boundless knowledge, hymned by hundreds, mighty, In strength like Soma, guard of the Five Peoples, may Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: tasya vajraḥ krandati smat svaḥ sāḥ divaḥ na tveṣaḥ ravathaḥ śimī vān tam sacante sanayaḥ tam dhanāni marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Winning the light, hitherward roars his thunder like the terrific mighty voice of Heaven. Rich gifts and treasures evermore attend him. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: yasya ajasram śavasā mānam uktham pari bhujat rodasī iti viśvataḥ sīm saḥ pāriṣat kratu bhiḥ mandasānaḥ marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: Whose home eternal through his strength surrounds him on every side, his laud, the earth and heaven, May he, delighted with our service, save us. May Indra, girt by Maruts, be our succour.

column1: na yasya devāḥ devatā na martā āpaḥ cana śavasaḥ antam āpuḥ saḥ pra rikvā tvakṣasā kṣmaḥ divaḥ ca marutvān naḥ bhavatu indraḥ ūtī
column2: The limit of whose power not Gods by Godhead, nor mortal men have reached, nor yet the Waters. Both Earth and Heaven in vigour he surpasseth. May Indra, girt by Maruts, he our succour.

column1: rohit śyāvā sumat aṁśuḥ lalāmīḥ dyukṣā rāye r̥jra aśvasya vr̥ṣaṇ vantam bibhratī dhūḥ su ratham mandrā ciketa nāhuṣīṣu vikṣu
column2: The red and tawny mare, blaze-marked, high standing, celestial who, to bring R̥ijrâṣva riches, Drew at the pole the chariot yoked with stallions, joyous, among the hosts of men was noted.

column1: etat tyat te indra vr̥ṣṇe uktham vārṣāgirāḥ abhi gr̥ṇanti rādhaḥ r̥jra aśvaḥ praṣṭi bhiḥ ambarīṣaḥ saha devaḥ bhayamānaḥ su rādhāḥ
column2: The Vârshâgiras unto thee, O Indra, the Mighty One, sing forth this laud to please thee, R̥ijrâṣva with his fellows, Ambarîsha, Surâdhâs, Sahadeva, Bhayamâna.

column1: dasyūn śimyūn ca puru hūtaḥ evaiḥ hatvā pr̥thivyām śarvā ni barhīt sanat kṣetram sakhi bhiḥ śvitnyebhiḥ sanat sūryam sanat apaḥ su vajraḥ
column2: He, much invoked, hath slain Dasyus and Ṣimyus, after his wont, and laid them low with arrows. The mighty Thunderer with his fair-complexioned friends won the land, the sunlight, and the waters.

column1: viśvāhā indraḥ adhi vaktā naḥ astu apari hvr̥tāḥ sanuyāma vājam tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: May Indra evermore be our protector, and unimperilled may we win the booty. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: pra mandine pitu mat arcata vacaḥ yaḥ kr̥ṣṇa garbhāḥ niḥ ahan r̥jiśvanā avasyavaḥ vr̥ṣaṇam vajra dakṣiṇam marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: SING, with oblation, praise to him who maketh glad, who with R̥ijiṣvan drove the dusky brood away. Fain for help, him the strong whose right hand wields the bolt, him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: yaḥ vi aṁsam jahr̥ṣāṇena manyunā yaḥ śambaram yaḥ ahan piprum avratam indraḥ yaḥ śuṣṇam aśuṣam ni avr̥ṇak marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: Indra, who with triumphant wrath smote Vyansa down, and Ṣambara, and Pipru the unrighteous one; Who extirpated Ṣushṇa the insatiate, him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: yasya dyāvāpr̥thivī iti paiṁsyam mahat yasya vrate varuṇaḥ yasya sūryaḥ yasya indrasya sindhavaḥ saścati vratam marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: He whose great work of manly might is heaven and earth, and Varuṇa and Sûrya keep his holy law; Indra, whose law the rivers follow as they flow,– him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: yaḥ aśvānām yaḥ gavām go patiḥ vaśī yaḥ āritaḥ karmaṇi karmaṇi sthiraḥ vīl̥oḥ cit indraḥ yaḥ asunvataḥ vadhaḥ marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: He who is Lord and Master of the steeds and kine, honoured -the firm and sure- at every holy act; Stayer even of the strong who pours no offering out, -him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: yaḥ viśvasya jagataḥ prāṇataḥ patiḥ yaḥ brahmaṇe prathamaḥ gāḥ avi ndat indraḥ yaḥ dasyūn adharān ava atirat marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: He who is Lord of all the world that moves and breathes, who for the Brahman first before all found the Cows; Indra who cast the Dasyus down beneath his feet,– him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: yaḥ śūrebhiḥ havyaḥ yaḥ ca bhīru bhiḥ yaḥ dhāvat bhiḥ hūyate yaḥ ca jigyubhiḥ indram yam viśvā bhuvanā abhi sam dadhuḥ marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: Whom cowards must invoke and valiant men of war, invoked by those who conquer and by those who flee; Indra, to whom all beings turn their constant thought,– him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: rudrāṇām eti pra diśā vi cakṣaṇaḥ rudrebhiḥ yoṣā tanute pr̥thu jrayaḥ indram manīṣā abhi arcati śrutam marutvantam sakhyāya havāmahe
column2: Refulgent in the Rudras' region he proceeds, and with the Rudras through the wide space speeds the Dame. The hymn of praise extols Indra the far-renowned: him girt by Maruts we invoke to be our Friend.

column1: yat vā marutvaḥ parame sadha sthe yat vā avame vr̥jane mādayāse ataḥ ā yāhi adhvaram naḥ accha tvāyā haviḥ cakr̥ma satya rādhaḥ
column2: O girt by Maruts, whether thou delight thee in loftiest gathering-place or lowly dwelling, Come thence unto our rite, true boon-best-ower: through love of thee have we prepared oblations.

column1: tvāyā indra somam susuma su dakṣa tvāyā haviḥ cakr̥ma brahma vāhaḥ adha ni yutvaḥ sa gaṇaḥ marut bhiḥ asmin yajñe barhiṣi mādayasva
column2: We, fain for thee, strong Indra, have pressed Soma, and, O thou sought with prayer, have made oblations. Now at this sacrifice, with all thy Maruts, on sacred grass, O team-borne God, rejoice thee.

column1: mādyasva hari bhiḥ ye te indra vi syasva śipre vi sr̥jasva dheneiti ā tvā su śipra harayaḥ vahantu uśan havyāni prati naḥ juṣasva
column2: Rejoice thee with thine own Bay Steeds, O Indra, unclose thy jaws and let thy lips be open. Thou with the fair cheek, let thy Bay Steeds bring thee: gracious to us, he pleased with our oblation.

column1: marut stotrasya vr̥janasya gopāḥ vayam indreṇa sanuyāma vājam tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: Guards of the camp whose praisers are the Maruts, may we through Indra, get ourselves the booty. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: imām te dhiyam pra bhare mahaḥ mahīm asya stotre dhiṣaṇā yat te ānaje tam ut save ca pra save ca sasahim indram devāsaḥ śavasā amadan anu
column2: To thee the Mighty One I bring this mighty hymn, for thy desire hath been gratified by my laud. In Indra, yea in him victorious through his strength, the Gods have joyed at feast and when the Soma flowed.

column1: asya śravaḥ nadyaḥ sapta bibhrati dyāvākṣāmā pr̥thivī darśatam vapuḥ asme iti sūryācandramasā abhi cakṣe śraddhe kam indra carataḥ vi tarturam
column2: The Seven Rivers bear his glory far and wide, and heaven and sky and earth display his comely form. The Sun and Moon in change alternate run their course, that we, O Indra, may behold and may have faith.

column1: tam sma ratham magha van pra ava sātaye jaitram yam te anu madāma sam game ājā naḥ indra manasā puru stuta tvāyat bhyaḥ magha van śamar yaccha naḥ
column2: Maghavan, grant us that same car to bring us spoil, thy conquering car in which we joy in shock of fight. Thou, Indra, whom our hearts praise highly in the war, grant shelter, Maghavan, to us who love thee well.

column1: vayam jayema tvayā yujā vr̥tam asmākam aṁśam ut ava bhare bhare asmabhyam indra varivaḥ su gam kr̥dhi pra śatrūṇām magha van vr̥ṣṇyā ruja
column2: Encourage thou our side in every fight: may we, with thee for our ally, conquer the foeman's host. Indra, bestow on us joy and felicity break down, O Maghavan, the vigour of our foes.

column1: nānā hi tvā havamānāḥ janāḥ ime dhanānām dhartaḥ avasā vipanyavaḥ asmākam sma ratham ā tiṣṭha sātaye jaitram hi indra ni bhr̥tam manaḥ tava
column2: For here in divers ways these men invoking thee, holder of treasures, sing hymns to win thine aid. Ascend the car that thou mayest bring spoil to us, for, Indra, thy fixt winneth the victory.

column1: go jitā bāhū iti amita kratuḥ simaḥ karman karman śata mūrtiḥ khajam karaḥ akalpaḥ indraḥ prati mānam ojasā atha janāḥ vi hvayante sisāsavaḥ
column2: His arms win kine, his power is boundless in each act best, with a hundred helps waker of battle's din Is Indra: none may rival him in mighty strength. Hence, eager for the spoil the people call on him.

column1: ut te śatāt magha van ut cabhūyasaḥ ut sahasrāt ririce kr̥ṣṭiṣu śravaḥ amātram tvā dhiṣaṇā titviṣe mahī adha vr̥trāṇi jighnase puram dara
column2: Thy glory, Maghavan, exceeds a hundred yea, more than a hundred, than a thousand mid the folk, The great bowl hath inspirited thee boundlessly: so mayst thou slay the Vr̥itras breaker-down of forts!

column1: triviṣṭi dhātu prati mānam ojasaḥ tisraḥ bhūmīḥ nr̥ pate trīṇi rocanā at i idam viśvam bhuvanam vavakṣitha aśatruḥ indra januṣā sanāt asi
column2: Of thy great might there is a three counterpart, the three earths, Lord men and the three realms of light. Above this whole world, Indra, thou hast waxen great: without a foe art thou, nature, from of old.

column1: tvām deveṣu prathamam havāmahe tvam babhūtha pr̥tanāsu sasahiḥ saḥ imam naḥ kārum upa manyum ut bhidam indraḥ kr̥ṇotu pra save ratham puraḥ
column2: We invocate thee first among the Deities: thou hast become a mighty Conquer in fight. May Indra fill with spirit this our singer's heart, and make our car impetuous, foremost in attack.

column1: tvam jigetha na dhanā rurodhitha arbheṣu ājā magha van mahat su ca tvām ugram avase sam śiśīmasi atha naḥ indra havaneṣu codaya
column2: Thou hast prevailed, and hast not kept the booty back, in trifling battles in those of great account. We make thee keen, the Mighty One, succour us: inspire us, Maghavan, when we defy the foe.

column1: viśvāhā indraḥ adhi vaktā naḥ astu apari hvr̥tāḥ sanuyāma vājam tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: May Indra evermore be our Protector, and unimperilled may we win the booty. This prayer of ours may Vartuna grant and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column2: THAT highest Indra-power of thine is distant: that which is here sages possessed aforetime. This one is on the earth, in heaven the other, and both unite as flag with flag in battle.

column2: You, I have heard, were mightiest, Indra-Agni, when Vr̥itra fell and when the spoil was parted. Sit at this sacrifice, ye ever active, on the strewn grass, and with the juice delight you.

column1: pra carṣaṇi bhyaḥ pr̥tanāhaveṣu pra pr̥thivyāḥ riricātheiti divaḥ ca pra sindhu bhyaḥ pra giri bhyaḥ mahi tvā pra indrāgnī iti viśvā bhuvanā ati anyā
column2: Surpassing all men where they shout for battle, ye Twain exceed the earth and heaven in greatness. Greater are ye than rivers and than mountains, O Indra-Agni, and all things beside them.

column1: ā bharatam śikṣatam vajrabāhū itivajra bāhū asmān indrāgnī avatam śacībhiḥ ime nu te raśmayaḥ sūryasya yebhiḥ sa pitvam pitaraḥ naḥ āsan
column2: Bring wealth and give it, ye whose arms wield thunder: Indra and Agni, with your powers protect us. Now of a truth these be the very sunbeams wherewith our fathers were of old united.

column1: puram darā śikṣatam vajra hastā asmān indrāgnī iti avatam bhareṣu tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥th ivī uta dyauḥ
column2: Give, ye who shatter forts, whose hands wield thunder: Indra and Agni, save us in our battles. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: tatam me apaḥ tat oṁ iti tāyate punariti svādiṣṭhā dhītiḥ ucathāya śasyate ayam samudraḥ iha v iśva devyaḥ svāhākr̥tasya sam oṁ iti tr̥pṇuta r̥bhavaḥ
column2: THE holy work I wrought before is wrought again: my sweetest hymn is sung to celebrate your praise. Here, O ye R̥ibhus, is this sea for all the Gods: sate you with Soma offered with the hallowing word.

column1: ābhogayam pra yat icchantaḥ aitana apākāḥ prāñcaḥ mama ke cit āpayaḥ saudhanvanāsaḥ caritasya bhūmanā agacchata savituḥ dāśuṣaḥ gr̥ham
column2: When, seeking your enjoyment onward from afar, ye, certain of my kinsmen, wandered on your way, Sons of Sudhanvan, after your long journeying, ye came unto the home of liberal Savitar.

column1: tat savitā vaḥ amr̥ta tvam ā asuvat agohyam yat śravayantaḥ aitana tyam cit camasam asurasya bhakṣaṇam ekam santam akr̥ṇuta catuḥ vayam
column2: Savitar therefore gave you immortality, because ye came proclaiming him whom naught can hide; And this the drinking-chalice of the Asura, which till that time was one, ye made to be fourfold.

column1: viṣṭavī śamī taraṇi tvena vāghataḥ martāsaḥ santaḥ amr̥ta tvam ānaśuḥ saudhanvanāḥ r̥bhavaḥ sūra cakṣasaḥ saṁvatsare sam apr̥cyanta dhīti bhiḥ
column2: When they had served with zeal at sacrifice as priests, they, mortal as they were, gained immortality. The R̥ibhus, children of Sudhanvan, bright as suns, were in a year's course made associate with prayers.

column1: kṣetram iva vi mamuḥ tejanenam ekam pātram r̥bhavaḥ jehamānam upa stutāḥ upa mam nādhamānāḥ amartyeṣu śravaḥ icchamānāḥ
column2: The R̥ibhus, with a rod measured, as 'twere a field, the single sacrificial chalice. wide of mouth, Lauded of all who saw, praying for what is best, desiring glorious fame among Immortal Gods.

column1: ā mānīṣām antarikṣasya nr̥ bhyaḥ srucāiva ghr̥tam juhavāma vidmanā taraṇi tvā ye pituḥ asya saścire r̥bhavaḥ vājam aruhan divaḥ rajaḥ
column2: As oil in ladles, we through knowledge will present unto the Heroes of the firmament our hymn,– The R̥ibhus who came near with this great Father's speed, and rose to heaven's high sphere to cat the strengthening food.

column1: r̥bhuḥ naḥ indraḥ śavasā navīyān r̥bhuḥ vājebhiḥ vasu bhiḥ vasuḥ dadiḥ yuṣmākam devāḥ avasā ahani priye abhi tiṣṭhema pr̥tsutīḥ asunvatām
column2: R̥ibhu to us is Indra freshest in his might, R̥ibhu with powers and wealth is giver of rich gifts. Gods, through your favour may we on the happy day quell the attacks of those who pour no offerings forth.

column1: iti yuvānā pitarā akr̥ṇotana
column2: Out of a skin, O R̥ibhus, once ye formed a cow, and brought the mother close unto her calf again. Sons of Sudhanvan, Heroes, with surpassing skill ye made your aged Parents youthful as before.

column1: vājebhiḥ naḥ vāja sātau aviḍḍhi r̥bhumān indra citram ā darṣi rādhaḥ tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: Help us with strength where spoil is won, O Indra: joined with the gbhus give us varied bounty. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: takṣan ratham su vr̥tam vidmanāapasaḥ takṣan harī iti indra vāhā vr̥ṣaṇvasūitivr̥ṣaṇ vasū takṣan pitr̥ bhyām r̥bhavaḥ yuvat vayaḥ takṣan vatsāya mātaram sacābhuvam
column2: WORKING with skill they wrought the lightly rolling car: they wrought the Bays who bear Indra and bring great gifts. The R̥ibhus for their Parents made life young again; and fashioned for the calf a mother by its side.

column1: ā naḥ yajñāya takṣata r̥bhu mat vayaḥ r̥tve dakṣāya su prajāvatīm iṣam yathā kṣayāma sarva vīrayā viśā tat naḥ śardhāya dhāsatha su indriyam
column2: For sacrifice make for us active vital power for skill and wisdom food with noble progeny. Grant to our company this power most excellent, that with a family all-heroic we may dwell.

column1: ā takṣata sātim asmabhyam r̥bhavaḥ sātim rathāya sātim arvate naraḥ sāti m naḥ jaitrīm sam maheta viśva hā jāmim ajāmim pr̥tanāsu sakṣaṇim
column2: Do ye, O R̥ibhus, make prosperity for us, prosperity for car, ye Heroes, and for steed. Grant us prosperity victorious evermore, conquering foes in battle, strangers or akin.

column1: r̥bhukṣaṇam indram ā huve ūtaye r̥bhūn vājān marutaḥ soma pītaye ubhā mitrāvarūṇā nūnam aśvinā te naḥ hinvantu sātaye dhiye jiṣe
column2: Indra, the R̥ibhus' Lord, I invocate for aid, the R̥ibhus, Vâjas, Maruts to the Soma draught. Varuṇa, Mitra, both, yea, and the Aṣvins Twain: let them speed us to wealth, wisdom, and victory.

column1: r̥bhuḥ bharāya sam śiśātu sātim samarya jit vājaḥ asmān aviṣṭu tat naḥ mi traḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: May R̥ibhu send prosperity for battle, may Vâja conquering in the fight protect us. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: īl̥e dyāvāpr̥thivī iti pūrva cittaye agnim gharmam su rucam yāman iṣṭaye yābhiḥ bhare kāram aṁśāya jinvathaḥ tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: To give first thought to them, I worship Heaven and Earth, and Agni, fair bright glow, to hasten their approach. Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids wherewith in fight ye speed the war-cry to the spoil.

column1: yuvoḥ dānāya su bharāḥ asaścataḥ ratham ā tasthuḥ vacasam na mantave yābhiḥ dhiyaḥ avathaḥ karman iṣṭaye tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Ample, unfailing, they have mounted as it were an eloquent car that ye may think of us and give. Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids wherewith ye help our thoughts to further holy acts.

column1: yuvam tāsām divyasya pra śāsane viśām kṣayathaḥ amr̥tasya majmanā yābh iḥ dhenum asvam pinvathaḥ narā tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Ye by the might which heavenly nectar giveth you are in supreme dominion Lords of all these folk. Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids wherewith ye, Heroes, made the barren cow give milk.

column1: yābhiḥ pari jmā tanayasya majmanā dviimātā tūrṣu taraṇiḥ vi bhūṣati yābhiḥ tri mantuḥ abhavat vi cakṣaṇaḥ tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: The aids wherewith the Wanderer through his offspring's might, or the Two-Mothered Son shows swiftest mid the swift; Wherewith the sapient one acquired his triple lore,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ rebham ni vr̥tam sitam at bhyaḥ ut vandanam airayatam svaḥ dr̥śe yābhiḥ kaṇvam pra sisāsantam āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye raised from waters, prisoned and fast bound, Rebha, and Vandana to look upon the light; Wherewith ye succoured Kaṇva as he strove to win,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ antakam jasamānam āaraṇe bhujyum yābhiḥ avyathi bhiḥ jijinvathuḥ yābh iḥ karkandhum vayyam ca jinvathaḥ tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye rescued Antaka when languishing deep in the pit, and Bhujyu with unfailing help. And comforted Karkandhu, Vayya, in their woe,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ śucanti dhanasām su saṁsadam taptam gharmam omyāvantam atraye yābhiḥ pr̥ṣni gum puru kutsam āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye gave Ṣuchanti wealth and happy home, and made the fiery pit friendly for Atri's sake; Wherewith ye guarded Purukutsa, Pr̥iṣnigu, -Come hither unto us, O Agvin;, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ śacībhiḥ vr̥ṣaṇā parāvr̥jam pra andham śroṇam cakṣase etave kr̥thaḥ yābhiḥ vartikām grasitām amuñcatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Mighty Ones, with what powers ye gave Paravrj aid what time ye made the blind and lame to see and walk; Wherewith ye set at liberty the swallowed quail,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ sindhum madhu mantam asaścatam vasiṣṭham yābhiḥ ajarau ajinvatam yābhiḥ kutsam śrutaryam naryam āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye quickened the most sweet exhaustless flood, and comforted Vasishṭha, ye who ne'er decay; And to Ṣrutarya, Kutsa, Narya gave your help,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ viśpalām dhana sām atharvyam sahasra mīl̥he ājau ajinvatam yābhiḥ vaśam aśvyam preṇim āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye helped, in battle of a thousand spoils, Vispala seeking booty, powerless to move. Wherewith ye guarded friendly Vaga, Aṣva's son,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ sudānūitisu dānū auśijāya vaṇije dīrgha śravase madhu kośaḥ akṣarat kakṣī vantam stotāram yābhiḥ āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Whereby the cloud, ye Bounteous Givers, shed sweet rain for Dîrghaṣravas, for the merchant Auṣija, Wherewith ye helped Kakshîvân, singer of your praise,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ rasām kṣodasā udgaḥ pipinvathuḥ anaśvam yābhiḥ ratham āvatam jiṣe yābhiḥ tri śokaḥ usriyāḥ ut ājata tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye made Rasâ swell full with water-floods, and urged to victory the car without a horse; Wherewith Triṣoka drove forth his recovered cows,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ sūryam pari yāthaḥ parāvati mandhātāram kṣaitra patyeṣu āvatam yābhiḥ vipram pra bharat vājam āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye, compass round the Sun when far away, strengthened Mandhâtar in his tasks as lord of lands, And to sage Bharadvâja gave protecting help,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ mahām atithi gvam kaśaḥ juvam divaḥ dāsam śambara hatye āvatam yābhiḥ pūḥ bhidye trasadasyum āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith, when Ṣambara was slain, ye guarded well great Âtithigva, Divodisa, Kaṣoju, And Trasadasyu when the forts were shattered down,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ vamram vi pipānam upa stutam kalim yābhiḥ vitta jānim duvasyathaḥ yābhiḥ vi aśvam uta pr̥thim āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye honoured the great drinker Vamra, and Upastuta and Kali when he gained his wife, And lent to Vyaṣva and to Pr̥ithi favouring help,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ narā śayave yābhiḥ atraye yābhiḥ purā manave gātum īṣathuḥ yābhiḥ śārīḥ ājatam syūma raśmaye tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith, O Heroes, ye vouchsafed deliverance to Ṣayu, Atri, and to Manu long ago; Wherewith ye shot your shafts in Syûmaraṣmi's cause.-Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ paṭharvā jaṭharasya majmanā agniḥ na adīdet citaḥ iddhaḥ ajman ā yābhiḥ śaryātam avathaḥ mahādhane tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith Paṭharvâ, in his majesty of form, shone in his course like to a gathered kindled fire; Wherewith ye helped Ṣaryâta in the mighty fray,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith, Angirases! ye triumphed in your heart, and onward went to liberate the flood of milk; Wherewith ye helped the hero Manu with new strength,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ patnīḥ vi madāya ni ūhathuḥ ā gha vā yābhiḥ aruṇīḥ aśikṣatam yābhiḥ su dāse ūhathuḥ su devyam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye brought awife for Vimada to wed, wherewith ye freely gave the ruddy cows away; Wherewith ye brought the host of kind Gods to Sudâs-Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ śantātī itiśam tātī bhavathaḥ dadāśuṣe bhujyum yābhiḥ avathaḥ yābhiḥ adhri gum omyāvatīm su bharām r̥ta stubham tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye bring great bliss to him who offers gifts, wherewith ye have protected Bhujyu, Adhrigu, And good and gracious Subhara and R̥itastup,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ kr̥śānum asane duvasyathaḥ jave yābhiḥ yūnaḥ arvantam āvatam madhu priyam bharathaḥ yat saraṭ bhyaḥ tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye served Kr̥iṣânu where the shafts were shot, and helped the young man's horse to swiftness in the race; Wherewith ye bring delicious honey to the bees,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ naram goṣu yudham nr̥ sahye kṣetrasya sātā tanayasya jinvathaḥ yābhiḥ rathān avathaḥ yābhiḥ arvataḥ tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye speed the hero as he fights for kine in hero battle, in the strife for land and sons, Wherewith ye safely guard his horses and his car,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins with those aids.

column1: yābhiḥ kutsam ārjuneyam śatakratūitiśata kratū pra turvītim pra ca dabhītim āvatam yābhiḥ dhvasantim puru santim āvatam tābhiḥ oṁ iti su ūti bhiḥ aśvinā ā gatam
column2: Wherewith ye, Lords of Hundred Powers, helped Kutsa, son of Aduni, gave Turvîti and Dabhîti strength, Favoured Dhvasanti and lent Purushanti help,– Come hither unto us, O Aṣvins, with those aids.

column1: apnasvatīm aśvinā vācam asme iti kr̥tam naḥ dasrā vr̥ṣaṇā manīṣām adyūtye avase ni hvaye vām vr̥dhe ca naḥ bhavatam vāja sātau
column2: Make ye our speech effectual, O ye Aṣvins, and this our hymn, ye mighty Wonder-Workers. In luckless game I call on you for succour . strengthen us also on the field of battle.

column2: With, undiminished blessings, O ye Aṣvins, for evermore both night and day protect us. This prayer of ours may Varuṇa grant, and Mitra, and Aditi and Sindhu, Earth and Heaven.

column1: idam śreṣṭham jyotiṣām jyotiḥ ā agāt citraḥ pra ketaḥ ajaniṣṭa vi bhvā yathā pra sūtā savituḥ savāya eva rātrī uṣase yonim araik
column2: This light is come, amid all lights the fairest; born is the brilliant, far-extending brightness. Night, sent away for Savitar's uprising, hath yielded up a birth-place for the Morning.

column1: ruśat vatsā ruśatī śvetyā ā agāt araik oṁ iti kr̥ṣṇā sadanāni asyāḥ samānabandhūitisamāna bandhū amr̥teiti anūcī iti dyāvā varṇam carataḥ āmināne ity āmināne
column2: The Fair, the Bright is come with her white offspring; to her the Dark One hath resigned her dwelling. Akin, immortal, following each other, changing their colours both the heavens move onward.

column1: samānaḥ adhvā svasroḥ anantaḥ tam anyāanyā carataḥ devaśiṣṭeitideva śiṣṭe na metheteiti na tasthatuḥ sumeke itisu meke naktoṣāsā sa manasā virūpeitivi rūpe
column2: Common, unending is the Sisters' pathway; taught by the Gods, alternately they travel. Fair-formed, of different hues and yet one-minded, Night and Dawn clash not, neither do they travel.

column1: bhāsvatī netrī sūnr̥tānām aceti citrā vi duraḥ naḥ āvar ity āvaḥ prar pya jagat vi oṁ iti naḥ rāyaḥ akhyat uṣāḥ ajīgaḥ bhuvanāni viśvā
column2: Bright leader of glad sounds, our eyes behold her; splendid in hue she hath unclosed the portals. She, stirring up the world, hath shown us riches: Dawn hath awakened every living creature.

column1: jihma śye caritave maghonī ābhogaye iṣṭaye rāye oṁ iti tvam dabhram paśyat bhyaḥ urviyā vi cakṣe uṣāḥ ajīgaḥ bhuvanān i viśvā
column2: Rich Dawn, she sets afoot the coiled-up sleeper, one for enjoyment, one for wealth or worship, Those who saw little for extended vision. All living creatures hath the Dawn awakened.

column1: kṣatrāya tvam śravase tvam mahīyai iṣṭaye tvam artham iva tvam ityai vi sadr̥śā jīvitā abhi pracakṣe uṣāḥ ajīgaḥ bhuvanāni viśvā
column2: One to high sway, one to exalted glory, one to pursue his gain, and one his labour: All to regard their different vocations, all moving creatures hath the Dawn awakened.

column1: eṣā divaḥ duhitā prati adarśi vi ucchantī yuvatiḥ śukra vāsāḥ viśvasya īśānā pārthivasya vasvaḥ uṣaḥ adya iha su bhage vi uccha
column2: We see her there, the Child of Heaven apparent, the young Maid, flushing in her shining raiment. Thou soyran Lady of all earthly treasure, flush on us here, auspicious Dawn, this morning.

column1: parāyatīnām anu eti pāthaḥ āyatīnām prathamā śaśvatīnām vi ucchantī jīvam ut īrayantī uṣāḥ mr̥tam kam cana bodhayantī
column2: She first of endless morns to come hereafter, follows the path of morns that have departed. Dawn, at her rising, urges forth the living him who is dead she wakes not from his slumber.

column1: uṣaḥ yat agnim sam idhe cakartha vi yat āvaḥ cakṣasā sūryasya yat mānuṣān yakṣyamāṇān ajīgariti tat deveṣu cakr̥ṣe bhadram apnaḥ
column2: As thou, Dawn, hast caused Agni to be kindled, and with the Sun's eye hast revealed creation. And hast awakened men to offer worship, thou hast performed, for Gods, a noble service.

column1: kiyati ā yat samayā bhavāti yāḥ vi ūṣuḥ yāḥ ca nūnam vi ucchān anu pūrvāḥ kr̥pate vāvaśānā pra dīdhyānā joṣam anyābhiḥ eti
column2: How long a time, and they shall be together,– Dawns that have shone and Dawns to shine hereafter? She yearns for former Dawns with eager longing, and goes forth gladly shining with the others.

column2: Gone are the men who in the days before us looked on the rising of the earlier Morning. We, we the living, now behold her brightness and they come nigh who shall hereafter see her.

column1: yāvayat dveṣāḥ r̥ta pāḥ r̥te jāḥ sumna varī sūnr̥tāḥ īrayantī su maṅgalīḥ bibhratī deva vītim iha adya uṣaḥ śreṣṭha tamā vi uccha
column2: Foe-chaser, born of Law, the Law's protectress, joy-giver waker of all pleasant voices, Auspicious, bringing food for Gods' enjoyment, shine on us here, most bright, O Dawn, this morning.

column2: So through thy favour may we force through all our enemies a way, As 'twere through streaming water-floods.

column2: Thou, Purifier Agni, high shinest forth, bright, adorable, When worshipped with the sacred oil.

column2: Ours art thou, Agni, Bharata, honoured by us with barren cows, With bullocks and with kine in calf

column2: Wood-fed, bedewed with sacred oil, ancient, Invoker, excellent, The Son of Strength, the Wonderful.

column2: Now praise, as one who strives for strength, the harnessing of Agni's car, The liberal, the most splendid One;

column2: Who, guiding worshippers aright, withers, untouched by age, the foe: When worshipped fair to look upon;

column2: Who for his glory is extolled at eve and morning in our homes, Whose statute is inviolate;

column1: ā yaḥ svaḥ na bhānunā citraḥ vi bhāti arciṣā añjānaḥ ajaraiḥ abhi
column2: Who shines refulgent like the Sun, with brilliance and with fiery flame, Decked with imperishable sheen.

column1: atrim anu sva rājyam agnim ukthāni vavr̥dhuḥ viśvāḥ adhi śriyaḥ dadhe
column2: Him Atri, Agni, have our songs Strengthened according to his sway: All glories hath he made his own.

column1: agneḥ indrasya somasya devānām ūti bhiḥ vayam ariṣyantaḥ sacemahi abhi syāma pr̥tanyataḥ
column2: May we with Agni's, Indra's help, with Soma's, yea, of all the Gods, Uninjured dwell together still, and conquer those who fight with us.

column1: ni hotā hotr̥ sadane vidānaḥ tveṣaḥ dīdi vān asadat su dakṣaḥ adabdha vratapramatiḥ vasiṣṭhaḥ sahasram bharaḥ śuci jihvaḥ agniḥ
column2: ACCUSTOMED to the Herald's place, the Herald hath seated him, bright, splendid, passing mighty, Whose foresight keeps the Law from violation, excellent, pure-tongued, bringing thousands, Agni.

column1: tvam dūtaḥ tvam oṁ iti naḥ paraḥ pāḥ tvam vasyaḥ ā vr̥ṣabha pra netā agne tokasya naḥ tane tanūnām apra yucchan dīdyat bodhi gopāḥ
column2: Envoy art thou, protector from the foeman, strong God, thou leadest us to higher blessings. Refulgent, be an ever-heedful keeper, Agni, for us and for our seed offspring.

column1: vidhema te parame janman agne vidhema stomaiḥ avare sadha sthe yasmāt yoneḥ ut āritha yaje tam pra tve iti havīṁṣi juhure sam iddhe
column2: May we adore thee in thy loftiest birthplace, and, with our praises, in thy lower station. The place whence thou issued forth I worship: to thee well kindled have they paid oblations.

column1: agne yajasva haviṣā yajīyān śruṣṭī deṣṇam abhi gr̥ṇīhi rādhaḥ tvam h i asi rayi patiḥ rayīṇām tvam śukrasya vacasaḥ manotā
column2: Agni, best Priest, pay worship with oblation; quickly commend the gift to be presented; For thou art Lord of gathered wealth and treasure. of the bright song of praise thou art inventor.

column1: ubhayam te na kṣīyate vasavyam dive dive jāyamānasya dasma kr̥dhi kṣu mantam jaritāram agne kr̥dhi patim su apatyasya rāyaḥ
column2: The twofold opulence, O Wonder-Worker, of thee new-born each day never decreases. Enrich with food the man who lauds thee, Agni: make him the lord of wealth with noble offspring.

column1: saḥ enā anīkena su vidatraḥ asme iti yaṣṭā devān āyajiṣṭhaḥ svasti adabdhaḥ gopāḥ uta naḥ paraḥ pāḥ agne dyu mat uta revat didīhi
column2: May he, benevolent with this fair aspect, best sacrificer, bring the Gods to bless us. Sure guardian, our protector from the foemen, shine, Agni, with thine affluence and splendour.

column1: johūtraḥ agniḥ prathamaḥ pitāiva il̥aḥ pade manuṣā yat sam iddhaḥ śriyam vasānaḥ amr̥taḥ vi cetāḥ marmr̥jenyaḥ śravasyaḥ saḥ vājī
column2: AGNI, first, loudly calling, like a Father, kindled by man upon the seat of worship. Clothed in his glory, deathless, keen of insight, must be adorned by all, the Strong, the Famous.

column1: śruyāḥ agniḥ citra bhānuḥ havam me viśvābhiḥ gīḥ bhiḥ amr̥taḥ vi cetāḥ śyāvā ratham vahataḥ rohitā vā uta aruṣā aha cakre vi bhr̥traḥ
column2: May Agni the resplendent hear my calling through all my songs, Immortal, keen of insight. Dark steeds or ruddy draw his car, or carried in sundry ways he makes them red of colour.

column1: uttānāyām ajanayan su sūtam bhuvat agniḥ puru peśāsu garbhaḥ śiriṇāyām cit aktunā mahaḥ bhiḥ apari vr̥taḥ vasati pra cetāḥ
column2: On wood supine they got the well-formed Infant: a germ in various-fashioned plants was Agni; And in the night, not compassed round by darkness, he dwells exceeding wise, with rays of splendour.

column1: jigharmi agnim haviṣā ghr̥tena prati kṣiyantam bhuvanāni viśvā pr̥thum t iraścā vayasā br̥hantam vyaciṣṭham annaiḥ rabhasam dr̥śānam
column2: With oil and sacred gifts I sprinkle Agni who makes his home in front of all things living, Broad, vast, through vital power o'er all expanded, conspicuous, strong with all the food that feeds him.

column1: ā viśvataḥ pratyañcam jigharmi arakṣasā manasā tat juṣeta marya śrīḥ spr̥hayat varṇaḥ agniḥ na abhi mr̥śe tanvā jarbhurāṇaḥ
column2: I pour to him who looks in all directions: may he accept it with a friendly spirit. Agni with bridegroom's grace and lovely colour may not be touched when all his form is fury.

column1: jñeyāḥ bhāgam sahasānaḥ vareṇa tvādūtāsaḥ manu vat vadema anūnam agnim juhvā vacasyā madhu pr̥cam dhana sāḥ johavīmi
column2: By choice victorious, recognize thy portion: with thee for envoy may we speak like Manu. Obtaining wealth, I call on perfect Agni who with an eloquent tongue dispenses sweetness.

column1: śrudhi havam indra mā riṣaṇyaḥ syāma te dāvane vasūnām imāḥ hi tvām ūrjaḥ vardhayanti vasu yavaḥ sindhavaḥ na kṣarantaḥ
column2: HEAR thou my call, O Indra; be not heedless: thine may we be for thee to give us treasures; For these presented viands, seeking riches, increase thy strength like streams of water flowing.

column1: sr̥jaḥ mahīḥ indra yāḥ apinvaḥ pari sthitāḥ ahinā śūra pūrvīḥ amartyam cit dāsam manyamānam ava abhinat ukthaiḥ vavr̥dhānaḥ
column2: Floods great and many, compassed by the Dragon, thou badest swell and settest free, O Hero. Strengthened by songs of praise thou rentest piecemeal the Dâsa, him who deemed himself immortal.

column1: uktheṣu it nu śūra yeṣu cākan stomeṣu indra rudriyeṣu ca tubhya it etāḥ yāsu mandasānaḥ pra vāyave sisrate na śubhrāḥ
column2: For, Hero, in the lauds wherein thou joyedst, in hymns of praise, O Indra, songs of Rudras, These streams in which is thy delight approach thee, even as the brilliant ones draw near to Vâyu.

column1: śubhram nu te śuṣmam vardhayantaḥ śubhram vajram bāhvoḥ dadhānāḥ śubhraḥ tvam indra vavr̥dhānaḥ asme iti dāsīḥ viśaḥ sūryeṇa sahyāḥ
column2: We who add strength to thine own splendid vigour, laying within thine arms the splendid thunder- With us mayst thou, O Indra, waxen splendid, with Sûrya overcome the Dâsa races.

column1: guhā hitam guhyam gūl̥ham apsu api vr̥tam māyinam kṣiyantam uto iti apaḥ dyām tastabhvāṁsam ahan ahim śūra vīryeṇa
column2: Hero, thou slewest in thy valour Ahi concealed in depths, mysterious, great enchanter, Dwelling enveloped deep within the waters, him who checked heaven and stayed the floods from flowing.

column1: stava nu te indra pūrvyā mahāni uta stavāma nūtanā kr̥tāni stava vajram bāhvoḥ uśantam stava harī iti sūryasya ketū iti
column2: Indra, we laud thy great deeds wrought aforetime, we laud thine exploits later of achievement; We laud the bolt that in thine arms lies eager; we laud thy two Bay Steeds, heralds of Sûrya.

column1: harī iti nu te indra vājayantā ghr̥ta ścutam svāram asvārṣṭām vi samanā bhūmiḥ aprathiṣṭa araṁsta parvataḥ cit sariṣyan
column2: Indra, thy Bay Steeds showing forth their vigour have sent a loud cry out that droppeth fatness. The earth hath spread herself in all her fulness: the cloud that was about to move hath rested.

column1: ni parvataḥ sādi apra yucchan sam mātr̥ bhiḥ vāvaśānaḥ akrān dūre pāre vāṇīm vardhayantaḥ indra iṣitām dhamanim paprathan ni
column2: Down, never ceasing, hath the rain-cloud settled: bellowing, it hath wandered with the Mothers. Swelling the roar in the far distant limits, they have spread wide the blast sent forth by Indra.

column1: indraḥ mahām sindhum āśayānam māyāvinam vr̥tram asphurat niḥ arejetām rodasī iti bhiyāne iti kanikradataḥ vr̥ṣṇaḥ asya vajrāt
column2: Indra hath hurled down the magician Vr̥itra who lay beleaguering the mighty river. Then both the heaven and earth trembled in terror at the strong Hero's thunder when he bellowed.

column1: aroravīt vr̥ṣṇaḥ asya vajraḥ amānuṣam yat mānuṣaḥ ni jūrvāt ni māyinaḥ dānavasya māyāḥ apādayat papi vān sutasya
column2: Loud roared the mighty Hero's bolt of thunder, when he, the Friend of man, burnt up the monster, And, having drunk his fill of flowing Soma, baffled the guileful Dânava's devices.

column1: piba piba it indra śūra somam mandantu tvā mandinaḥ sutāsaḥ pr̥ṇantaḥ te kukṣī iti vardhayantu itthā sutaḥ pauraḥ indram āva
column2: Drink thou, O Hero Indra, drink the Soma; let the joy-giving juices make thee joyful. They, filling both thy flanks, shall swell thy vigour. The juice that satisfies hath helped Indra.

column1: tve iti indra api abhūma viprāḥ dhiyam vanema r̥ta yā sapantaḥ avasyavaḥ dhīmahi pra śastim sadyaḥ te rāyaḥ dāvane syāma
column2: Singers have we become with thee, O Indra: may we serve duly and prepare devotion. Seeking thy help we meditate thy praises: may we at once enjoy thy gift of riches.

column2: May we be thine, such by thy help, O Indra, as swell thy vigour while they seek thy favour. Give us, thou God, the riches that we long for, most powerful, with stare of noble children.

column1: rāsi kṣayam rāsi mitram asme iti rāsi śardhaḥ indra mārutam naḥ sa joṣasaḥ ye ca mandasānāḥ pra vāyavaḥ pānti agra nītim
column2: Give us a friend, give us an habitation; Indra, give us the company of Maruts, And those whose minds accord with theirs, the Vâyus, who drink the first libation of the Soma.

column1: vyantu it nu yeṣu mandasānaḥ tr̥pat somam pāhi drahyat indra asmān su pr̥t su ā tarutra avardhayaḥ dyām br̥hat bhiḥ arkaiḥ
column2: Let those enjoy in whom thou art delighted. Indra, drink Soma for thy strength and gladness. Thou hast exalted us to heaven, Preserver, in battles, through the lofty hymns that praise thee.

column1: br̥hantaḥ it nu ye te tarutra ukthebhiḥ vā sumnam āvivāsān str̥ṇānāsaḥ barhiḥ pastya vat tvāūtāḥ it indra vājam agman
column2: Great, verily, are they, O thou Protector, who by their songs of praise have won the blessing. They who strew sacred grass to be thy dwelling, helped by thee have got them strength, O Indra.

column1: ugreṣu it nu śūra mandasānaḥ tri kadrukeṣu pāhi somam indra pra dodhuvat śmaśruṣu prīṇānaḥ yāhi hari bhyām sutasya pītim
column2: Upon the great Trikadruka days, Hero, rejoicing thee, O Indra, drink the Soma. Come with Bay Steeds to drink of libation, shaking the drops from out thy beard, contented.

column1: dhiṣva śavaḥ śūra yena vr̥tram ava abhinat dānum aurṇa vābham apa avr̥ṇoḥ jyotiḥ āryāya ni savyataḥ sādi dasyuḥ indra
column2: Hero, assume the might wherewith thou clavest Vr̥itra piecemeal, the Dânava Aurṇavâbha. Thou hast disclosed the light to light the Arya: on thy left hand, O Indra, sank the Dasyu.

column2: May we gain wealth, subduing with thy succour and with the Ârya, all our foes, the Dasyus. Our gain was that to Trita of our party thou gavest up Tvashṭar's son Viṣvarûpâ.

column1: asya suvānasya mandinaḥ tritasya ni arbudam vavr̥dhānaḥ astari tyastaḥ avartayat sūryaḥ na cakram bhinat valam indraḥ aṅgirasvān
column2: He cast down Arbuda what time his vigour was strengthened by libations poured by Trita. Indra sent forth his whirling wheel like Sûrya, and aided by the Angirases rent Vala.

column1: nūnam sā te prati varam jaritre duhīyat indra dakṣiṇā maghonī śikṣa stotr̥ bhyaḥ mā ati dhak bhagaḥ naḥ br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Now let that wealthy Cow of thine, O Indra, yield in return a boon to him who lauds thee. Give to thy praisers: let not fortune fail us. Loud may we speak, with brave men, in the assembly.

column1: yaḥ jātaḥ eva prathamaḥ manasvān devaḥ devān kratunā pari abhūṣat yasya śuṣmāt rodasī iti abhyasetām nr̥mṇasya mahnā saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: HE who, just born, chief God of lofty spirit by power and might became the Gods' protector, Before whose breath through greatness of his valour the two worlds trembled, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ pr̥thivīm vyathamānām adr̥ṁhat yaḥ parvatān pra kupitān aramṇāt yaḥ antarikṣam vi mame varīyaḥ yaḥ dyām astabhnāt saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: He who fixed fast and firm the earth that staggered, and set at rest the agitated mountains, Who measured out the air's wide middle region and gave the heaven support, He, men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ hatvā ahim ariṇāt sapta sindhūn yaḥ gāḥ ut ājat apa dhā valasya yaḥ aśmanoḥ antaḥ agnim jajāna sam vr̥k samat su saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Who slew the Dragon, freed the Seven Rivers, and drove the kine forth from the cave of Vala, Begat the fire between two stones, the spoiler in warriors' battle, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yena imā viśvā cyavanā kr̥tāni yaḥ dāsam varṇam adharam guhā akar ityakaḥ śvaghnī iva yaḥ jigīvān lakṣam ādat aryaḥ puṣṭāni saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: By whom this universe was made to tremble, who chased away the humbled brood of demons, Who, like a gambler gathering his winnings seized the foe's riches, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yam sma pr̥cchanti kuha saḥ iti ghoram uta īm āhuḥ na eṣaḥ asti iti enam saḥ aryaḥ puṣṭīḥ vijaḥ iva ā mināti śrat asmai dhatta saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Of whom, the Terrible, they ask, Where is He? or verily they say of him, He is not. He sweeps away, like birds, the foe's possessions. Have faith in him, for He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ radhrasya coditā yaḥ kr̥śasya yaḥ brahmaṇaḥ nādhamānasya kīreḥ yukta grāvṇaḥ yaḥ avitā su śipraḥ suta somasya saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Stirrer to action of the poor and lowly, of priest, of suppliant who sings his praises; Who, fair-faced, favours him who presses Soma with stones made ready, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yasya aśvāsaḥ pra diśi yasya gāvaḥ yasya grāmāḥ yasya viśve rathāsaḥ yaḥ sūryam yaḥ uṣasam jajāna yaḥ apām netā saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: He under whose supreme control are horses, all chariots, and the villages, and cattle; He who gave being to the Sun and Morning, who leads the waters, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yam krandasī iti saṁyatī itisam yatī vihvayeteitivi hvayete pare avare ubhayāḥ amitrāḥ samānam cit ratham ātasthi vāṁsā nānā haveteiti saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: To whom two armies cry in close encounter, both enemies, the stronger and the weaker; Whom two invoke upon one chariot mounted, each for himself, He, O ye men, is Indra.

column1: yasmāt na r̥te vi jayante janāsaḥ yam yudhyamānāḥ avase havante yaḥ viśvasya prati mānam babhūva yaḥ acyuta cyut saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Without whose help our people never conquer; whom, battling, they invoke to give them succour; He of whom all this world is but the copy, who shakes things moveless, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ śaśvataḥ mahi enaḥ dadhānān amanyamānān śarvā jaghāna yaḥ śardhate na anu dadāti śr̥dhyām yaḥ dasyoḥ hantā saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: He who hath smitten, ere they knew their danger, with his hurled weapon many grievous sinners; Who pardons not his boldness who provokes him, who slays the Dasyti, He, O men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ śambaram parvateṣu kṣiyantam catvāriṁśyām śaradi anu avindat ojāyamānam yaḥ ahim jaghāna dānum śayānam saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: He who discovered in the fortieth autumn Ṣambara as he dwelt among the mountains; Who slew the Dragon putting forth his vigour, the demon lying there, He, men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ sapta raśmiḥ vr̥ṣabhaḥ tuviṣmān ava asr̥jat sartave sapta s indhūn yaḥ rauhiṇam asphurat vajra bāhuḥ dyām ārohantam saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Who with seven guiding reins, the Bull, the Mighty, set free the Seven great Floods to flow at pleasure; Who, thunder-armed, rent Rauhiṇa in pieces when scaling heaven, He, O ye men, is Indra.

column1: dyāvā cit asmai pr̥thivī iti nameteiti śuṣmāt cit asya parvatāḥ bhayante yaḥ soma pāḥ ni citaḥ vajra bāhuḥ yaḥ vajra hastaḥ saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Even the Heaven and Earth bow down before him, before his very breath the mountains tremble. Known as the Soma-drinker, armed with thunder, who wields the bolt, He, O ye men, is Indra.

column1: yaḥ sunvantam avati yaḥ pacantam yaḥ śaṁsantam yaḥ śaśamānam ūtī yasya brahma vardhanam yasya somaḥ yasya idam rādhaḥ saḥ janāsaḥ indraḥ
column2: Who aids with favour him who pours the Soma and him who brews it, sacrificer, singer. Whom prayer exalts, and pouring forth of Soma, and this our gift, He, O ye men, Is Indra.

column1: yaḥ sunvate pacate dudhraḥ ā cit vājam dardarṣi saḥ kila asi satyaḥ vayam te indra viśvaha priyāsaḥ su vīrāsaḥ vidatham ā vadema
column2: Thou verily art fierce and true who sendest strength to the man who brews and pours libation. So may we evermore, thy friends, O Indra, speak loudly to the synod with our heroes.

column1: r̥tuḥ janitrī tasyāḥ apaḥ pari makṣu jātaḥ ā aviśat yāsu vardhate tat āhanāḥ abhavat pipyuṣī payaḥ aṁśoḥ pīyūṣam prathamam tat ukthyam
column2: THE Season was the parent, and when born therefrom it entered rapidly the floods wherein it grows. Thence was it full of sap, streaming with milky juice: the milk of the plant's stalk is chief and meet for lauds.

column1: sadhrī īm ā yanti pari bibhratīḥ payaḥ viśva psnyāya pra bharanta bhojanam samānaḥ adhvā pra vatām anu syade yaḥ tā akr̥ṇoḥ prathamam saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: They come trooping together bearing milk to him, and bring him sustenance who gives support to all. The way is common for the downward streams to flow. Thou who didst these things first art worthy of our lauds.

column1: anu ekaḥ vadati yat dadāti tat rūpā minan tat apāḥ ekaḥ īyate viśvāḥ ekasya vi nudaḥ titikṣate yaḥ tā akr̥ṇoḥ prathamam saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: One priest announces what the institutor gives: one, altering the forms, zealously plies his task, The third corrects the imperfections left by each. Thou who didst these things first art worthy of our lauds.

column1: pra jābhyaḥ puṣṭim vi bhajantaḥ āsate rayim iva pr̥ṣṭham pra bhavantam āyate asinvan daṁṣṭraiḥ pituḥ atti bhojanam yaḥ tā akr̥ṇoḥ prathamam saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Dealing out food unto their people there they sit, like wealth to him who comes, more than the back can bear. Greedily with his teeth he eats the master's food. Thou who didst these things first art worthy of our lauds.

column1: adha akr̥ṇoḥ pr̥thivīm sam dr̥śe dive yaḥ dhautīnām ahi han ariṇak pathaḥ tam tvā stomebhiḥ uda bhiḥ na vājinam devam devāḥ ajanan saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Thou hast created earth to look upon the sky: thou, slaying Ahi, settest free the river's paths. Thee, such, a God, the Gods have quickened with their lauds, even as a steed with waters: meet for praise art thou.

column1: yaḥ bhojanam ca dayase ca vardhanam ārdrāt ā śuṣkam madhu mat dudohitha saḥ śevadhim ni dadhiṣe vivasvati viśvasya ekaḥ īśiṣe saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Thou givest increase, thou dealest to us our food: thou milkest from the moist the dry, the rich in sweets. Thou by the worshipper layest thy precious store: thou art sole Lord of all. Meet for our praise art thou.

column1: yaḥ puṣpiṇīḥ ca pra svaḥ ca dharmaṇā adhi dāne vi avanīḥ adhārayaḥ yaḥ ca asamāḥ ajanaḥ didyutaḥ divaḥ uruḥ ūrvān abhitaḥ saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Thou who hast spread abroad the streams by stablished law, and in the field the plants that blossom and bear seed; Thou who hast made the matchless lightnings of the sky,– vast, compassing vast realms, meet for our praise art thou.

column1: yaḥ nārmaram saha vasum ni hantave pr̥kṣāya ca dāsa veśāya ca avahaḥ ūrjayantyāḥ apari viṣṭam āsyam uta eva adya puru kr̥t saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Who broughtest Nârmara with all his wealth, for sake of food, to slay him that the fiends might be destroyed, Broughtest the face unclouded of the strengthening one, performing much even now, worthy art thou of praise.

column1: śatam vā yasya daśa sākam ā adyaḥ ekasya śruṣṭau yat ha codam āv itha arajjau dasyūn sam unap dabhītaye supra avyaḥ abhavaḥ saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Thou boundest up the Dâsa's hundred friends and ten, when, at one's hearing, thou belpest thy worshipper. Thou for Dabhîti boundest Dasyus not with cords; Thou wast a mighty help. Worthy of lauds art thou.

column1: viśvā it anu rodhanāḥ asya paiṁsyam daduḥ asmai dadhire kr̥tnave dhanam ṣaṭ astabhnāḥ vi stiraḥ pañca sam dr̥śaḥ pari paraḥ abhavaḥ saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: All banks of rivers yielded to his manly might; to him they gave, to him, the Strong, gave up their wealth. The six directions hast thou fixed, a five-fold view: thy victories reached afar. Worthy of lauds art thou.

column1: su pravācanam tava vīra vīryam yat ekena kratunā vindase vasu jātū sthirasya pra vayaḥ sahasvataḥ yā cakartha saḥ indra viśvā asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Meet for high praise, O Hero, is thy power, that with thy single wisdom thou obtainest wealth, The life-support of conquering Jatusthira. Indra, for all thy deeds, worthy of lauds art thou.

column1: aramayaḥ sara apasaḥ tarāya kam turvītaye ca vayyāya ca srutim nīcā santam ut anayaḥ parāvr̥jam pra andham śroṇam śravayan saḥ asi ukthyaḥ
column2: Thou for Turvîti heldest still the flowing floods, the river-stream for Vayya easily to pass Didst raise the outcast from the depths, and gavest fame unto the halt and blind. Worthy of lauds art thou.

column1: asmabhyam tat vaso iti dānāya rādhaḥ sam arthayasva bahu te vasavyam indra yat citram śravasyāḥ anu dyūn br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Prepare thyself to grant us that great bounty, O Vasu, for abundant is thy treasure. Snatch up the wonderful, O Indra, daily. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ bharata indrāya somam ā amatrebhiḥ siñcata madyam andhaḥ kāmī hi vīraḥ sadam asya pītim juhota vr̥ṣṇe tat it eṣaḥ vaṣṭ i
column2: MINISTERS, bring the Soma juice for Indra, pour forth the gladdening liquor with the beakers.logeth ever To drink of this the Hero offer it to the Bull, for this he willeth.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ apaḥ vavrivāṁsam vr̥tram jaghāna aśanyāiva vr̥kṣam tasmai etam bharata tat vaśāya eṣaḥ indraḥ arhati pītim asya
column2: Ye ministers, to him who with the lightning smote, like a tree, the rain-withholding Vr̥itra- Bring it to him, him who is fain to taste it, a draught of this which Indra here deserveth.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ dr̥bhīkam jaghāna yaḥ gāḥ ut ājat apa hi valam varitivaḥ tasmai etam antarikṣe na vātam indram somaiḥ ā ūrṇuta jūḥ na vastraiḥ
column2: Ye ministers, to him who smote Dr̥ibhîkas who drove the kine forth, and discovered Vala, Offer this draught, like Vita in the region: clothe him with Soma even as steeds with trappings.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ uraṇam jaghāna nava cakhvāṁsam navatim ca bāhūn yaḥ arbudam ava nīcā babādhe tam indram somasya bhr̥the hinota
column2: Him who did Uraṇa to death, Adhvaryus! though showing arms ninety-and-nine in number; Who cast down headlong Arbuda and slew him,– speed ye that Indra to our offered Soma.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ su aśnam jaghāna yaḥ śuṣṇam aśuṣam yaḥ vi aṁsam yaḥ piprum namucim yaḥ rudhi krām tasmai indrāya andhasaḥ juhota
column2: Ye ministers, to him who struck down Svaṣna, and did to death Vyansa and greedy Ṣushṇa, And Rudhikrâs and Namuchi and Pipru,– to him, to Indra, pour ye forth libation.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ śatam śambarasya puraḥ bibheda aśmanāiva pūrvīḥ yaḥ varcinaḥ śatam indraḥ sahasram apa avapat bharata somam asmai
column2: Ye ministers, to him who as with thunder demolished Ṣambara's hundred ancient castles; Who cast down Varcin's sons, a hundred thousand,– to him, to Indra, offer ye the Soma.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ śatam ā sahasram bhūmyāḥ upa sthe avapat jaghanvān kutsasya āyoḥ atithi gvasya vīrān ni avr̥ṇak bharata somam asmai
column2: Ye ministers, to him who slew a hundred thousand, and cast them down upon earth's bosom; Who quelled the valiant men of Âtithigva, Kutsa, and Âyu,– bring to him the Soma.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yat naraḥ kāmayādhve śruṣṭī vahantaḥ naśatha tat indre gabhasti pūtam bharata śrutāya indrāya somam yajyavaḥ juhota
column2: Ministers, men, whatever thing ye long for obtain ye quickly bringing gifts to Indra. Bring to the Glorious One what bands have cleansed; to Indra bring, ye pious ones, the Soma.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ kartana śruṣṭim asmai vane ni pūtam vane ut nayadhvam juṣāṇaḥ hastyam abhi vāvaśe vaḥ indrāya somam madiram juhota
column2: Do ye, O ministers, obey his order: that purified in wood, in wood uplift ye. Well pleased he longs for what your hands have tended: offer the gladdening Soma juice to Indra.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ payasā ūdhaḥ yathā goḥ somebhiḥ īm pr̥ṇata bhojam indram veda aham asya ni bhr̥tam me etat ditsantam bhūyaḥ yajataḥ ciketa
column2: As the cow's udder teems with milk, Adhvaryus, so fill with Soma Indra, liberal giver. I know him: I am sure of this, the Holy knows that I fain would give to him more largely.

column1: adhvaryavaḥ yaḥ divyasya vasvaḥ yaḥ pārthivasya kṣamyasya rājā tam ūrdaram na pr̥ṇata yavena indram somebhiḥ tat apaḥ vaḥ astu
column2: Him, ministers, the Lord of heavenly treasure and all terrestrial wealth that earth possesses, Him, Indra, fill with Soma as a garner is filled with barley full: be this your labour.

column1: asmabhyam tat vaso iti dānāya rādhaḥ sam arthayasva bahu te vasavyam indra yat citram śravasyāḥ anu dyūn br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Prepare thyself to grant us that great booty, O Vasu, for abundant is thy treasure. Gather up wondrous wealth, O Indra, daily. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly.

column1: pra gha nu asya mahataḥ mahāni satyā satyasya karaṇāni vocam tr i kadrukeṣu apibat sutasya asya made ahim indraḥ jaghāna
column2: Now, verily, will I declare the exploits, mighty and true, of him the True and Mighty. In the Trikadrukas he drank the Soma then in its rapture Indra slew the Dragon.

column1: avaṁśe dyām astabhāyat br̥hantam ā rodasī iti apr̥ṇat antarikṣam saḥ dhārayat pr̥thivīm paprathat ca somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: High heaven unsupported in space he stablished: he filled the two worlds and the air's mid-region. Earth he upheld, and gave it wide expansion. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: sadma iva prācaḥ vi mimāya mānaiḥ vajreṇa khāni atr̥ṇat nadīnām vr̥thā asr̥jat pathi bhiḥ dīrgha yāthaiḥ somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: From front, as 'twere a house, he ruled and measured; pierced with his bolt the fountains of the rivers, And made them flow at ease by paths far-reaching, These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: saḥ pra vol̥hr̥n pari gatya dabhīteḥ viśvam adhāk āyudham iddhe agnau sam gobhiḥ aśvaiḥ asr̥jat rathebhiḥ somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: Compassing those who bore away Dabhîti, in kindled fire he burnt up all their weapons. And made him rich with kine and cars and horses. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: saḥ īm mahīm dhunim etoḥ aramṇāt saḥ asnātr̥r̥n apārayat svasti te ut snāya rayim abhi pra tasthuḥ somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: The mighty roaring flood he stayed from flowing, and carried those who swam not safely over. They having crossed the stream attained to riches. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: saḥ udañcam sindhum ariṇāt mahitvā vajreṇa anaḥ uṣasaḥ sam pipeṣa ajavasaḥ javinībhiḥ vi vr̥ścan somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: With mighty power he made the stream flow upward, crushed with his thunderbolt the car of Ushas, Rending her slow steeds with his rapid coursers. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: saḥ vidvān apa goham kanīnām āviḥ bhavan ut atiṣṭhat parāvr̥k prati śroṇaḥ sthāt vi anak acaṣṭa somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: Knowing the place wherein the maids were hiding, the outcast showed himself and stood before them. The cripple stood erect, the blind beheld them. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: bhinat valam aṅgiraḥ bhiḥ gr̥ṇānaḥ vi parvatasya dr̥ṁhitāni airat riṇak rodhāṁsi kr̥trimāṇi eṣām somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: Praised by the Angirases he slaughtered Vala, and burst apart the bulwarks of the mountain. He tore away their deftly-built defences. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: svapnena abhi upya cumurim dhunim ca jaghantha dasyum pra dabhītim āvaḥ rambhī cit atra vivide hiraṇyam somasya tā made indraḥ cakāra
column2: Thou, with sleep whelming Chumuri and Dhuni, slewest the Dasyu, keptest safe Dabhîti. There the staff-bearer found the golden treasure. These things did Indra in the Soma's rapture.

column1: nūnam sā te prati varam jaritre duhīyat indra dakṣiṇā maghonī śikṣa stotr̥ bhyaḥ mā ati dhak bhagaḥ naḥ br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Now let that wealthy Cow of thine, O Indra , yield in return a boon to him who lauds thee. Give to thy praisers: let not fortune fail us. Loud may we speak, with brave men, in assembly.

column1: pra vaḥ satām jyeṣṭhatamāya su stutim agnau iva sam idhāne haviḥ bhare indram ajuryam jarayantam ukṣitam sanāt yuvānam avase havāmahe
column2: To him, your own, the best among the good, I bring eulogy, like oblation in the kindled fire. We invocate for help Indra untouched by eld, who maketh all decay, strengthened, for ever young.

column1: yasmāt indrāt br̥hataḥ kim cana īm r̥te viśvāni asmin sam bhr̥tā adhi vīryā jaṭhare somam tanvi sahaḥ mahaḥ haste vajram bharati śīrṣaṇi kratum
column2: Without whom naught exists, Indra the Lofty One; in whom alone all powers heroic are combined. The Soma is within him, in his frame vast strength, the thunder in his hand and wisdom in his head.

column1: na kṣoṇībhyām pari bhve te indriyam na samudraiḥ parvataiḥ indra te rathaḥ na te vajram anu aśnoti kaḥ cana yat āśu bhiḥ patasi yojanā puru
column2: Not by both worlds is thine own power to be surpassed, nor may thy car be stayed by mountains or by seas. None cometh near, O Indra, to thy thunderbolt, when with swift steeds thou fliest over many a league.

column1: viśve hi asmai yajatāya dhr̥ṣṇave kratum bharanti vr̥ṣabhāya saścate vr̥ṣā yajasva haviṣā viduḥ taraḥ piba indra somam vr̥ṣabheṇa bhānunā
column2: For all men bring their will to him the Resolute, to him the Holy One, to him the Strong they cleave. Pay worship with oblation, strong and passing wise. Drink thou the Soma, Indra, through the mighty blaze.

column1: vr̥ṣṇaḥ kośaḥ pavate madhvaḥ ūrmiḥ vr̥ṣabha annāya vr̥ṣabhāya pātave vr̥ṣaṇā adhvaryū iti vr̥ṣabhāsaḥ adrayaḥ vr̥ṣaṇam somam vr̥ṣabhāya susvati
column2: The vessel of the strong flows forth, the flood of meath, unto the Strong who feeds upon the strong, for drink, Strong are the two Adhvaryus, strong are both the stones. They press the Soma that is strong for him the Strong.

column1: vr̥ṣā te vajraḥ uta te vr̥ṣā rathaḥ vr̥ṣaṇā harī iti vr̥ṣabhāṇi āyudhā vr̥ṣṇaḥ madasya vr̥ṣabha tvam īśiṣe indra somasya vr̥ṣabhasya tr̥pṇuhi
column2: Strong is thy thunderbolt, yea, and thy car is strong; strong are thy Bay Steeds and thy weapons powerful. Thou, Indra, Bull, art Lord of the strong gladdening drink. with the strong Soma, Indra, satisfy thyself.

column1: pra te nāvam na samane vacasyuvam brahmaṇā yāmi savaneṣu dadhr̥ṣiḥ kuvit naḥ asya vacasaḥ ni bodhiṣat indram utsam na vasunaḥ sicāmahe
column2: I, bold by prayer, come near thee in thy sacred rites, thee like a saving ship, thee shouting in the war. Verily he will hear and mark this word of ours: we will pour Indra forth as 'twere a spring of wealth.

column1: purā sam bādhāt abhi ā vavr̥tsva naḥ dhenuḥ na vatsam yavasasya pipyuṣī sakr̥t su te sumati bhiḥ śatakrato itiśata krato sam patnībhiḥ na vr̥ṣaṇaḥ nasīmahi
column2: Turn thee unto us ere calamity come nigh, as a cow full of pasture turns her to her calf. Lord of a Hundred Powers, may we once firmly cling to thy fair favours even as husbands to their wives.

column1: nūnam sā te prati varam jaritre duhīyat indra dakṣiṇā maghonī śikṣa stotr̥ bhyaḥ mā ati dhak bhagaḥ naḥ br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Now let that wealthy Cow of thine, O Indra, yield in return a boon to him who lauds thee. Give to thy praisers: let not fortune fail us. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly.

column1: tat asmai navyam aṅgirasvat arcata śuṣmāḥ yat asya pratna thā ut īrate viśvā yat gotrā sahasā pari vr̥tā made somasya dr̥ṁhitāni airayat
column2: LIKE the Angirases, sing this new song forth to him, for, as in ancient days, his mighty powers are shown, When in the rapture of the Soma he unclosed with strength the solid firm-shut stables of the kine.

column1: saḥ bhūtu yaḥ ha prathamāya dhāyase ojaḥ mimānaḥ mahimānam ā at irat śūraḥ yaḥ yut su tanvam pari vyata śīrṣaṇi dyām mahinā prati amuñcata
column2: Let him be even that God who, for the earliest draught measuring out his power, increased his majesty; Hero who fortified his body in the wars, and through his greatness set the heaven upon his head.

column1: adha akr̥ṇoḥ prathamam vīryam mahat yat asya agre brahmaṇā śuṣmam airayaḥ rathe sthena hari aśvena vi cyutāḥ pra jīrayaḥ sisrate sadhryak pr̥thak
column2: Thou didst perform thy first great deed of hero might what time thou showedst power, through prayer, before this folk. Hurled down by thee the car-borne Lord of Tawny Steeds, the congregated swift ones fled in sundry ways.

column1: adha yaḥ viśvā bhuvanā abhi majmanā īśāna kr̥t pra vayāḥ abhi avardhata āt rodasī iti jyotiṣā vahniḥ ā atanot sīvyan tamāṁsi dudhitā sam avyayat
column2: He made himself by might Lord of all living things, and strong in vital power waxed great above them all. He, borne on high, o'erspread with light the heaven and earth, and, sewing up the turbid darkness, closed it in.

column1: saḥ prācīnān parvatān dr̥ṁhat ojasā adharācīnam akr̥ṇot apām apaḥ adhārayat pr̥thivīm viśva dhāyasam astabhnāt māyayā dyām ava srasaḥ
column2: He with his might made firm the forward-bending hills, the downward rushing of the waters he ordained. Fast he upheld the earth that nourisheth all life, and stayed the heaven from falling by his wondrous skill.

column1: saḥ asmai aram bāhu bhyām yam pitā akr̥ṇot viśvasmāt ā januṣaḥ vedasaḥ pari yena pr̥thivyām ni krivim śayadhyai vajreṇa hatvī avr̥ṇak tuvi svaniḥ
column2: Fit for the grasping of his arms is what the Sire hath fabricated from all kind of precious wealth. The thunderbolt, wherewith, loud-roaring, he smote down, and striking him to death laid Krivi on the earth.

column1: amājūḥ iva pitroḥ sacā satī samānāt ā sadasaḥ tvām iye bhagam kr̥dh i pra ketam upa māsi ā bhara daddhi bhāgam tanvaḥ yena mamahaḥ
column2: As she who in her parents' house is growing old, I pray to thee as Bhaga from the seat of all. Grant knowledge, mete it out and bring it to us here: give us the share wherewith thou makest people glad.

column1: bhojam tvām indra vayam huvema dadiḥ tvam indra apāṁsi vājān avi ḍḍhi indra citrayā naḥ ūtī kr̥dhi vr̥ṣan indra vasyasaḥ naḥ
column2: May we invoke thee as a liberal giver thou givest us, O Indra, strength and labours. Help us with manifold assistance, Indra: Migthy One, Indra, make us yet more wealthy.

column1: nūnam sā te prati varam jaritre duhīyat indra dakṣiṇā maghonī śikṣa stotr̥ bhyaḥ mā ati dhak bhagaḥ naḥ br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Now may that weaithy Cow of thine, O Indra, give in return a boon to him who lauds thee. Give to thy praisers: let not fortune fail us. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly.

column1: prātariti rathaḥ navaḥ yoji sasniḥ catuḥ yugaḥ tri kaśaḥ sapta raśmiḥ daśa aritraḥ manuṣyaḥ svaḥ sāḥ saḥ iṣṭi bhiḥ mati bhiḥ raṁhyaḥ bhūt
column2: THE rich new car hath been equipped at morning; four yokes it hath, three whips, seven reins to guide it: Ten-sided, friendly to mankind, light-winner, that must be urged to speed with prayers and wishes.

column1: saḥ asmai aram prathamam saḥ dvitīyam uto iti tr̥tīyam manuṣaḥ saḥ hotā anyasyāḥ garbham anye oṁ iti jananta saḥ anyebhiḥ sacate jenyaḥ vr̥ṣā
column2: This is prepared for him the first, the second, and the third time: he is man's Priest and Herald. Others get offspring of another parent he goeth, as a noble Bull, with others.

column2: To Indra's car the Bay Steeds have I harnessed, that new well-spoken words may bring him hither. Here let not other worshippers detain thee, for among us are many holy singers.

column2: Indra, come hitherward with two Bay Coursers, come thou with four, with six when invocated. Come thou with eight, with ten, to drink the Soma. Here is the juice, brave Warrior: do not scorn it.

column1: ā viṁśatyā triṁśatā yāhi arvāṅ ā catvāriṁśatā hari bhiḥ yujānaḥ ā pañcāśatā su rathebhiḥ indra ā ṣaṣṭyā saptatyā soma peyam
column2: O Indra, come thou hither having harnessed thy car with twenty, thirty, forty horses. Come thou with fifty well trained coursers, Indra, sixty or seventy, to drink the Soma.

column1: ā aśītyā navatyā yāhi arvāṅ ā śatena hari bhiḥ uhyamānaḥ ayam h i te śuna hotreṣu somaḥ indra tvāyā pari siktaḥ madāya
column2: Come to us hitherward, O Indra, carried by eighty, ninety, or an hundred horses. This Soma juice among the Ṣunahotrâs hath been poured out, in love, to glad thee, Indra.

column2: To this my prayer, O Indra, come thou hither: bind to thy car's pole all thy two Bay Coursers. Thou art to be invoked in many places Hero, rejoice thyself in this libation.

column1: na me indreṇa sakhyam vi yoṣat asmabhyam asya dakṣiṇā duhīta upa jyeṣṭhe varūthe gabhastau prāye prāye jigīvāṁsaḥ syāma
column2: Ne'er be my love from Indra disunited still may his liberal Milch-cow yield us treasure. So may we under his supreme protection, safe in his arms, succeed in each forth-going.

column2: Now may that wealthy Cow Of thine, O Indra, give in return a boon to him who lauds thee. Give to thy praisers: let not fortune fail us. Loud may we speak, with heroes, in assembly.

column2: DRAUGHTS of this sweet juice have been drunk for rapture, of the wise Soma-presser's offered dainty, Wherein, grown mighty in the days aforetime, Indra hath found delight, and men who worship.

column2: Cheered by this meath Indra, whose hand wields thunder, rent piecemeal Ahi who barred up the waters, So that the quickening currents of the rivers flowed forth like birds unto their resting-places.

column2: Indra, this Mighty One, the Dragon's slayer, sent forth the flood of waters to the ocean. He gave the Sun his life, he found the cattle, and with the night the works of days completed.

column2: To him who worshippeth hath Indra given many and matchless gifts. He slayeth Vr̥itra. Straight was he to be sought with supplications by men who struggled to obtain the sunlight.

column2: Once to the driver of his chariot, Kutsa, he gave up greedy Sûrya, plague of harvest; And Indra, for the sake of Divodâsa demolished Ṣambara's nine-and-ninety castles.

column2: Thus the Gr̥itsamadas for thee, O Hero, have wrought their hymn and task as seeking favour. May they who worship thee afresh, O Indra, gain food and strength, bliss, and a happy dwelling.

column2: May Indra, called with solemn invocations. the young, the Friend, be men's auspicious keeper, One who will further with his aid the singer, the toiler, praiser, dresser of oblations.
