column2: Then by the laud the Gods engendered Agni in heaven, who fills both worlds through strength and vigour. They made him to appear in threefold essence: he ripens plants of every form and nature.

column1: yadā it enam adadhuḥ yajñiyāsaḥ divi devāḥ sūryam āditeyam yadā cariṣṇū iti mithunau abhūtām āt it pra apaśyan bhuvanāni viśvā
column2: What time the Gods, whose due is worship, set him as Sûrya, Son of Aditi, in heaven, When the Pair, ever wandering, sprang to being, all creatures that existed looked upon them.

column2: For all the world of life the Gods made Agni Vaiṣvânara to be the days' bright Banner,– Him who hath spread abroad the radiant Mornings, and, coming with his light, unveils the darkness.

column2: The wise and holy Deities engendered Agni Vaiṣvânara whom age ne'er touches. The Ancient Star that wanders on for ever, lofty and. strong, Lord of the Living Being.

column2: We call upon the Sage with holy verses, Agni Vaiṣvânara the ever-beaming, Who hath surpassed both heaven and earth in greatness: lie is a God below, a God above us.

column2: I have heard mention of two several pathways, ways of the Fathers and of Gods and mortals. On these two paths each moving creature travels, each thing between the Father and the Mother.

column2: These two united paths bear him who journeys born from the head and pondered with the spirit He stands directed to all things existing, hasting, unresting in his fiery splendour.

column2: Which of us twain knows where they speak together, upper and lower of the two rite-leaders? Our friends have helped to gather our assembly. They came to sacrifice; who will announce it?

column2: How many are the Fires and Suns in number? What is the number of the Dawns and Waters? Not jestingly I speak to you, O Fathers. Sages, I ask you this for information.

column2: As great as is the fair-winged Morning's presence to him who dwells beside us, Mâtariṣvan! Is what the Brahman does when he approaches to sacrifice and sits below the Hotar.

column2: I WILL extol the most heroic Indra who with his might forced earth and sky asunder; Who hath filled all with width as man's Upholder, surpassing floods and rivers in his greatness.

column2: Sûrya is he: throughout the wide expanses shall Indra turn him, swift as car-wheels, hither, Like a stream resting not but ever active he hath destroyed, with light, the blackhued darkness.

column2: To him I sing a holy prayer, incessant new, matchless, common to the earth and heaven, Who marks, as they were backs, all living creatures: ne'er doth he fail a friend, the noble Indra.

column2: I will send forth my songs in flow unceasing, like water from the ocean's depth, to Indra. Who to his car on both its sides securely hath fixed the earth and heaven as with an axle.

column2: Rousing with draughts, the Shaker, rushing onward, impetuous, very strong, armed as with arrows Is Soma; forest trees and all the bushes deceive not Indra with their offered likeness.

column2: Soma hath flowed to him whom naught can equal, the earth, the heavens, the firmament, the mountains,– When heightened in his ire his indignation shatters the firm and breaks the strong in pieces.

column2: As an axe fells the tree so be slew Vr̥itra, brake down the strongholds and dug out the rivers. He cleft the mountain like a new-made pitcher. Indra brought forth the kine with his Companions.

column2: Wise art thou, Punisher of guilt, O Indra. The sword lops limbs, thou smitest down the sinner, The men who injure, as it were a comrade, the lofty Law of Varuṇa and Mitra.

column2: Men who lead evil lives, who break agreements, and injure Varuṇa, Aryaman and Mitra,– Against these foes, O Mighty Indra, sharpen, as furious death, thy Bull of fiery colour.

column2: Indra is Sovran Lord of Earth and Heaven, Indra is Lord of waters and of mountains. Indra is Lord of prosperers and sages Indra must be invoked in rest and effort.

column2: Vaster than days and nights, Giver of increase, vaster than firmament and flood of ocean, Vaster than bounds of earth and wind's extension, vaster than rivers and our lands is Indra.

column2: Forward, as herald of refulgent Morning, let thine insatiate arrow fly, O Indra. And pierce, as 'twere a stone launched forth from heaven, with hottest blaze the men who love deception.

column2: Him, verily, the moons, the mountains followed, the tall trees followed and the plants and herbage. Yearning with love both Worlds approached, the Waters waited on Indra when he first had being.

column2: Where was the vengeful dart when thou, O Indra, clavest the demon ever beat on outrage? When fiends lay there upon the ground extended like cattle in the place of immolation?

column2: Those who are set in enmity against us, the Oganas, O Indra, waxen mighty,– Let blinding darkness follow those our fbemen, while these shall have bright shining nights to light them.

column2: May plentiful libations of the people, and singing R̥ishis' holy prayers rejoice thee. Hearing with love this common invocation, come unto us, pass by all those who praise thee.

column2: O Indra, thus may we be made partakers of thy new favours that shall bring us profit. Singing with love, may we the Viṣvâmitras win daylight even now through thee, O Indra.

column2: Call we on Maghavan, auspicious Indra, best hero in the fight where spoil is gathered, The Strong who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vr̥itras, wins and gathers riches.

column2: A THOUSAND heads hath Purusha, a thousand eyes, a thousand feet. On every side pervading earth he fills a space ten fingers wide.

column2: This Purusha is all that yet hath been and all that is to be; The Lord of Immortality which waxes greater still by food.

column2: So mighty is his greatness; yea, greater than this is Purusha. All creatures are one-fourth of him, three-fourths eternal life in heaven.

column1: bala vijñāyaḥ sthaviraḥ pra vīraḥ sahasvān vājī sahamānaḥ ugraḥ abhi vīraḥ abhi satvā sahaḥ jāḥ jaitram indra ratham ā tiṣṭha go vit
column2: Conspicuous by thy strength, firm, foremost fighter, mighty and fierce, victorious, all-subduing, The Son of Conquest, passing men and heroes, kine-winner, mount thy conquering car, O Indra.

column1: gotra bhidam go vidam vajra bāhum jayantam ajma pra mr̥ṇantam ojasā imam sa jātāḥ anu vīrayadhvam indram sakhāyaḥ anu sam rabhadhvam
column2: Cleaver of stalls, kine-winner, armed with thunder, who quells an army and with might destroys it.- Follow him, brothers! quit yourselves like heroes, and like this Indra show your zeal and courage.

column1: abhi gotrāṇi sahasā gāhamānaḥ adayaḥ vīraḥ śata manyuḥ indraḥ duḥ cyavanaḥ pr̥tanāṣāṭ ayudhyaḥ asmākam senāḥ avatu pra yut su
column2: Piercing the cow-stalls with surpassing vigour, Indra, the pitiless Hero, wild with anger, Victor in fight, unshaken and resistless,may he protect our armies in our battles.

column1: indraḥ āsām netā br̥haspatiḥ dakṣiṇā yajñaḥ puraḥ etu somaḥ deva senānām abhi bhañjatīnām jayantīnām marutaḥ yantu agram
column2: Indra guide these: Br̥ihaspati precede them, the guerdon, and the sacrifice, and Soma; And let the banded Maruts march in forefront of heavenly hosts that conquer and demolish.

column1: indrasya vr̥ṣṇaḥ varuṇasya rājñaḥ ādityānām marutām śardhaḥ ugram mahāmanasām bhuvana cyavānām ghoṣaḥ devānām jayatām ut asthāt
column2: Ours be the potent host of mighty Indra, King Varuṇa, and Maruts, and Âdityas. Uplifted is the shout of Gods who conquer high-minded Gods who cause the worlds to tremble.

column1: ut harṣaya magha van āyudhāni ut satvanām māmakānām manāṁsi ut vr̥tra han vājinām vājināni ut rathānām jayatām yantu ghoṣāḥ
column2: Bristle thou up, O Maghavan, our weapons: excite the spirits of my warring heroes. Urge on the strong steeds' might, O Vr̥itra-slayer, and let the din of conquering cars go upward.

column1: asmākam indraḥ sam r̥teṣu dhvajeṣu asmākam yāḥ iṣavaḥ tāḥ jayantu asmākam vīrāḥ ut tare bhavantu asmān oṁ iti devāḥ avata haveṣu
column2: May Indra aid us when our flags are gathered: victorious be the arrows of our army. May our brave men of war prevail in battle. Ye Gods, protect us in the shout of onset.

column1: amīṣām cittam prati lobhayantī gr̥hāṇa aṅgāni apve parā ihi abhi pra ihi niḥ daha hr̥t su śokaiḥ andhena amitrāḥ tamasā sacantām
column2: Bewildering the senses of our foemen, seize thou their bodies and depart, O Apva. Attack them, set their hearts on fire and burn them: so let our foes abide in utter darkness.

column1: pra ita jayata naraḥ indraḥ vaḥ śarma yacchatu ugrāḥ vaḥ santu bāhavaḥ anādhr̥ṣyāḥ yathā asatha
column2: Advance, O heroes, win the day. May Indra be your sure defence. Exceeding mighty be your arms, that none may wound or injure you.

column1: asāvi somaḥ puru hūta tubhyam hari bhyām yajñam upa yāhi tūyam tubhyam giraḥ vipra vīrāḥ iyānāḥ dadhanvire indra piba sutasya
column2: Soma hath flowed for thee, Invoked of mat Speed to our sacrifice with both thy Coursers. To thee have streameld the songs or mighty singers, imploring, Indra, drink of our libation.

column1: ap su dhūtasya hari vaḥ piba iha nr̥ bhiḥ sutasya jaṭharam pr̥ṇasva mimikṣuḥ yam adrayaḥ indra tubhyam tebhiḥ vardhasva madam uktha vāhaḥ
column2: Drink of the juice which men have washed in waters, and fill thee full, O Lord of Tawny Horses. O Indra, hearer of the laud, with Soma which stones have mixed for thee enhance thy rapture.

column1: pra ugrām pītim vr̥ṣṇe iyarmi satyām pra yai sutasya hari aśva tubhyam indra dhenābhiḥ iha mādayasva dhībhiḥ viśvābhiḥ śacyā gr̥ṇānaḥ
column2: To make thee start, a strong true draught I offer to thee, the Bull, O thou whom Bay Steeds carry. Here take delight, O Indra, in our voices while thou art hymned with power and all our spirit.

column1: ūtī śacī vaḥ tava vīryeṇa vayaḥ dadhānāḥ uśijaḥ r̥ta jñāḥ prajāvat indra manuṣaḥ duroṇe tasthuḥ gr̥ṇantaḥ sadha mādyāsaḥ
column2: O Mighty Indra, through thine aid, thy prowess, obtaining life, zealous, and skilled in Order, Men in the house who share the sacred banquet stand singing praise that brings them store of children.

column1: pranīti bhiḥ te hari aśva su stoḥ susumnasya puru rucaḥ janāsaḥ maṁhiṣṭhām ūtim vi tire dadhānāḥ stotāraḥ indra tava sūnr̥tābhiḥ
column2: Through thy directions, Lord of Tawny Coursers, thine who art firm, splendid, and blest, the people Obtain most liberal aid for their salvation, and praise thee, Indra, through thine excellencies.

column1: upa brahmāṇi hari vaḥ hari bhyām somasya yāhi pītaye sutasya indra tvā yajñaḥ kṣamamāṇam ānaṭ dāśvān asi adhvarasya pra ketaḥ
column2: Lord of the Bays, come with thy two Bay Horses, come to our prayers, to drink the juice of Soma. To thee comes sacrifice which thou acceptest: thou, skilled in holy rites, art he who giveth.

column1: sahasra vājam abhimāti saham sute raṇam magha vānam su vr̥ktim upa bhūṣanti giraḥ aprati itam indram namasyāḥ jarituḥ pananta
column2: Him of a thousand powers, subduing foemen, Maghavan praised with hymns and pleased with Soma,– Even him our songs approach, resistless Indra: the adorations of the singer laud him.

column1: sapta āpaḥ devīḥ su raṇāḥ amr̥ktāḥ yābhiḥ sindhum ataraḥ indra pūḥ bhit navatim srotyāḥ nava ca sravantīḥ devebhyaḥ gātum manuṣe ca vindaḥ
column2: The way to bliss for Gods and man thou foundest, Indra, seven lovely floods, divine, untroubled, Wherewith thou, rending forts, didst move the ocean, and nine-and-ninety flowing streams of water.

column1: apaḥ mahīḥ abhi śasteḥ amuñcaḥ ajāgaḥ āsu adhi devaḥ ekaḥ indra yāḥ tvam vr̥tra tūrye cakartha tābhiḥ viśva āyuḥ tanvam pupuṣyāḥ
column2: Thou from the curse didst free the mighty Waters, and as their only God didst watch and guard them. O Indra, cherish evermore thy body with those which thou hast won in quelling Vr̥itra.

column1: vīreṇyaḥ kratuḥ indraḥ su śastiḥ uta api dhenā puru hūtam īṭe ādaryat vr̥tram akr̥ṇot oṁ iti lokam sasahe śakraḥ pr̥tanāḥ abhiṣṭiḥ
column2: Heroic power and noble praise is Indra yea, the song worships him invoked of many. Vr̥itra he quelled, and gave men room and freedom: gakra, victorious, hath conquered armies.

column1: śunam huvema magha vānam indram asmin bhare nr̥ tamam vāja sātau śr̥ṇvantam ugram ūtaye samat su ghnantam vr̥trāṇi sam jitam dhanānām
column2: Call we on Maghayan, auspicious Indra. best Hero in this fight where spoil is gathered, The Strong, who listens, who gives aid in battles, who slays the Vr̥itras, wins and gathers riches.

column1: kadā vaso iti stotram haryate ā ava śmaśā rudhat vāritivāḥ dīrgham sutam vātāpyāya
column2: WHEN, Vasu, wilt thou love the laud? Now let the channel bring the stream. The juice is ready to ferment.

column1: harī iti yasya su yujā vi vratā veḥ arvantā anu śepā ubhā rajī iti na keśinā patiḥ dan
column2: He whose two Bay Steeds harnessed well, swerving, pursue the Bird's tail-plumes, With Rowing manes, like heaven and earth, he is the Lord with power to give.

column1: apa yoḥ indraḥ pāpaje ā martaḥ na śaśramāṇaḥ bibhīvān śubhe yat yuyuje taviṣī vān
column2: Bereft of skill is Indra, if, like some outwearied man he fears The sinner, when the Mighty hath prepared himself for victory.

column1: sacā āyoḥ indraḥ carkr̥ṣe ā upānasaḥ saparyan nadayoḥ vi vratayoḥ śūraḥ indraḥ
column2: Indra with these drives round, until he meets with one to worship him: Indra is Master of the pair who snort and swerve upon their way.

column1: adhi yaḥ tasthau keṣa vantā vyacasvantā na puṣṭyai vanoti śiprābhyām śipriṇī vān
column2: Borne onward by the long-maned Steeds who stretch themselves as 'twere for food, The God who wears the helm defends them with his jaws.

column1: pra astaut r̥ṣva ojāḥ r̥ṣvebhiḥ tatakṣa śūraḥ śavasā r̥bhuḥ na kratu bhiḥ mātariśvā
column2: The Mighty sang with Lofty Ones: the Hero fashioned with his strength, Like skilful Mâtariṣvan with his power and might,

column1: vajram yaḥ cakre su hanāya dasyave hirīmaśaḥ harīmān aruta hanuḥ adbhutam na rajaḥ
column2: The bolt, which pierced at once the vitals of the Dasyu easy to be slain, With jaw uninjured like the wondrous firmament.

column1: ava naḥ vr̥jinā śiśīhi r̥cā vanema anr̥caḥ na abrahmā yajñaḥ r̥dhak joṣati tve iti
column2: Grind off our sins: with song will we conquer the men who sing no hymns: Not easily art thou pleased with prayerless sacrifice.

column1: ūrdhvā yat te tretinī bhūt yajñasya dhūḥ su sadman sa jūḥ nāvam sva yaśasam sacā āyoḥ
column2: When threefold flame burns high for thee, to rest on poles of sacrifice, Thou with the living joyest in the self-bright Ship.

column1: śriye te pr̥śniḥ upa secanī bhūt śriye darviḥ arepāḥ yayā sve pātre siñcase ut
column2: Thy glory was the speckled cup, thy glory was the flawless scoop. Wherewith thou pourest into thy receptacle.

column1: śatam vā yat asurya prati tvā su mitraḥ itthā astaut duḥ mitraḥ itthā astaut āvaḥ yat dasyu hatye kutsa putram pra āvaḥ yat dasyu hatye kutsa vatsam
column2: As hundreds, O Immortal God, have sung to thee, so hath Sumitra, yea, Durmitra praised thee here, What time thou holpest Kutsa's son, when Dasyus fell, yea, holpest Kutsa's darling when the Dasyus died.

column1: ubhau oṁ iti nūnam tat it arthayetheiti vi tanvātheiti dhiyaḥ vastrā apasāiva sadhrīcīnā yātave pra īm ajīgaḥ sudināiva pr̥kṣaḥ ā taṁsayetheiti
column2: THIS very thing ye Twain hold as your object: ye weave your songs as skilful men weave garments. That ye may come united have I waked you: ye spread out food like days of lovely weather.

column1: uṣṭārāiva pharvareṣu śrayetheiti prāyogāiva śvātryā śāsuḥ ā ithaḥ dūtāiva hi sthaḥ yaśasā janeṣu mā apa sthātam mahiṣāiva ava pānāt
column2: Like two plough-bulls ye move along in traces, and seek like eager guests your bidder's banquet. Ye are like glorious envoys mid the people: like bulls, approach the place where ye are watered.

column1: sākam yujā śakunasya iva pakṣā paśvāiva citrā yajuḥ ā gamiṣṭam agniḥ iva deva yoḥ dīdi vāṁsā parijmānāiva yajathaḥ puru trā
column2: Like the two pinions of a bird, connected, like two choice animals, ye have sought our worship. Bright as the fire the votary hath kindled, ye sacrifice in many a spot as roamers.

column1: āpī iti vaḥ asme iti pitarāiva putrā ugrāiva rucā nr̥patīivetinr̥patī iva turyai iryāiva puṣṭyai kiraṇāiva bhujyai śruṣṭīvānāiva havam ā gamiṣṭam
column2: Ye are our kinsmen, like two sons, two fathers, strong in your splendour and like kings for conquest; Like rays for our enjoyment, Lords to feed us, ye, like quick bearers, have obeyed our calling.

column1: vaṁsagāiva pūṣaryā śimbātā mitrāiva r̥tā śatarā śātapantā vājāiva uccā vayasā gharmye sthā meṣāiva iṣā saparyā purīṣā
column2: You are like two pleasantly moving well-fed (hills) like Mitra and Varuṇa, the two bestowers of felicity, veracious, possessors of infinite wealth, happy, like two horses plump with fodder, abiding in the firmament, like two rams (are you) to be nourished with sacrificial food, to be cherished (with oblations).

column1: sr̥ṇyāiva jarbharī iti turpharītūiti naitośāiva turpharī iti parpharīkā udanyajāiva jemanā maderū iti tā me jarāyu ajaram marāyu
column2: You are like two mad elephants bending their forequarters and smiting the foe, like the two sons of Nitosa destroying (foes), and cherishing (friends); you are bright as two water-born (jewels), do you, who are victorious, (render) my decaying mortal body free from decay.

column1: pajrāiva carcaram jāram marāyu kṣadma iva artheṣu tartarīthaḥ ugrā r̥bhū iti na āpat kharamajrā khara jruḥ vāyuḥ na parpharat kṣayat rayīṇām
column2: Fierce (Aṣvins), like two powerful (heroes), you enable this moving, perishable mortal (frame) to cross over to the objects (of its destination) as over water; extremely strong, like the R̥ibhus, your chariot, attained its destination swift as the wind, it pervaded (everywhere), it dispensed riches.

column1: gharmāiva madhu jaṭhare sanerūiti bhage avitā turpharī iti phārivā aram patarāiva cacarā candra nirnik manaḥ r̥ṅgā mananyā na jagmī iti
column2: With your bellies full of the Soma, like two saucepans, preservers of wealth, destroyers of enemies. (you are) armed with hatchets, moving like two flying (birds) with forms like the moon, attaining success through the mind, like two laudable beings, (you are) approaching (the sacrifice).

column1: br̥hantāiva gambhareṣu prati sthām pādāiva gādham tarate vidāthaḥ karṇāiva śāsuḥ anu hi smarāthaḥ aṁśāiva naḥ bhajatam citram apnaḥ
column2: Like giants, ye will find firm ground to stand on in depths, like feet for one who fords a shallow. Like ears ye will attend to him who orders: ye Two enjoy our wondrous work as sharers.

column1: āraṅgarāiva madhu ā īrayetheiti sāraghāiva gavi nīcīna bāre kīnārāiva svedam āsisvidānā kṣāma iva ūrjā suyavasa at sacetheitis
column2: Like toiling bees ye bring to us your honey, as bees into the hide that opens downward.

column1: r̥dhyāma stomam sanuyāma vājam ā naḥ mantram sa rathā iha upa yātam yaśaḥ na pakvam madhu goṣu antaḥ ā bhūta aṁśaḥ aśvinoḥ kāmam aprāḥ
column2: May we increase the laud and gain us vigour: come to our song, ye whom one chariot carries. Filled be our kine with ripened meath like glory: Bhûtânṣa hath fulfilled the Aṣvins' longing.

column1: āviḥ abhūt mahi māghonam eṣām viśvam jīvam tamasaḥ niḥ amoci mahi jyotiḥ pitr̥ bhiḥ dattam ā agāt uruḥ panthāḥ dakṣiṇāyāḥ adarśi
column2: THESE men's great bounty hath been manifested, and the whole world of life set free from darkness. Great light hath come, vouchsafed us by the Fathers: apparent is the spacious path of Guerdon.

column1: uccā divi dakṣiṇāvantaḥ asthuḥ ye aśva dāḥ saha te sūryeṇa hiraṇya dāḥ amr̥ta tvam bhajante vāsaḥ dāḥ soma pra tirante āyuḥ
column2: High up in heaven abide the Guerdon-givers: they who give steeds dwell with the Sun for ever. They who give gold are blest with life eternal. they who give robes prolong their lives, O Soma.

column1: daivī pūrtiḥ dakṣiṇā deva yajyā na kava aribhyaḥ nahi te pr̥ṇanti atha naraḥ prayata dakṣiṇāsaḥ avadya bhiyā bahavaḥ pr̥ṇanti
column2: Not from the niggards-for they give not fireely-comes Meed at sacrifice, Gods' satisfaction: Yea, many men with hands stretched out with Guerdon present their gifts because they dread dishonour.

column1: śata dhāram vāyum arkam svaḥ vidam nr̥ cakṣasaḥ te abhi cakṣate haviḥ ye pr̥ṇanti pra ca yacchanti sam game te dakṣiṇām duhate sapta mātaram
column2: These who observe mankind regard oblation as streamy Vâyu and light-finding Arka. They satisfy and give their gifts in synod, and pour in streams the seven-mothered Guerdon.

column1: dakṣiṇāvān prathamaḥ hūtaḥ eti dakṣiṇāvān grāma nīḥ agram eti tam eva manye nr̥ patim janānām yaḥ prathamaḥ dakṣiṇām āvivāya
column2: He who brings Guerdon comes as first invited: chief of the hamlet comes the Guerdon-bearer. Him I account the ruler of the people who was the first to introduce the Guerdon.

column1: tam eva r̥ṣim tam oṁ iti brahmāṇam āhuḥ yajña nyam sāma gām uktha śāsam saḥ śukrasya tanvaḥ veda tisraḥ yaḥ prathamaḥ dakṣiṇayā rarādha
column2: They call him R̥ishi, Brahman, Sâma-chanter, reciter of the laud, leader of worship. The brightly-shining God's three forms he knoweth who first bestowed the sacrificial Guerdon.

column1: dakṣiṇā aśvam dakṣiṇā gām dadāti dakṣiṇā candram uta yat hiraṇyam dakṣi ṇā annam vanute yaḥ naḥ ātmā dakṣiṇām varma kr̥ṇute vi jānan
column2: Guerdon bestows the horse, bestows the bullock, Guerdon bestows, moreover, gold that R̥ishisters. Guerdon gives food which is our life and spirit. He who is wise takes Guerdon for his armour.

column1: na bhojāḥ mamruḥ na ni artham īyuḥ na riṣyanti na vyathante ha bhojāḥ idam yat viśvam bhuvanam svaḥ ca etat sarvam dakṣiṇā ebhyaḥ dadāti
column2: The liberal die not, never are they ruined: the liberal suffer neither harm nor trouble. The light of heaven, the universe about us,– all this doth sacrificial Guerdon give them.

column1: bhojāḥ jigyuḥ surabhim yonim agre bhojāḥ jigyuḥ vadhvam yā su vāsāḥ bhojāḥ jigyuḥ antaḥ peyam surāyāḥ bhojāḥ jigyuḥ ye ahūtāḥ pra yanti
column2: First have the liberal gained a fragrant dwelling, and got themselves a bride in fair apparel. The liberal have obtained their draught of liquor, and conquered those who, unprovoked, assailed them.

column1: bhojāya aśvam sam mr̥janti āśum bhojāya āste kanyā śumbhamānā bhojasya idam puṣkariṇī iva veśma pari kr̥tam devamānāiva citram
column2: They deck the fleet steed for the bounteous giver: the maid adorns herself and waits to meet him. His home is like a lake with lotus blossoms, like the Gods' palaces adorned and splendid.

column1: bhojam aśvāḥ suṣṭhu vāhaḥ vahanti su vr̥t rathaḥ vartate dakṣiṇāyāḥ bhojam devāsaḥ avata bhareṣu bhojaḥ śatrūn sam anīkeṣu jetā
column2: Steeds good at draught convey the liberal giver, and lightly rolling moves the car of Guerdon. Assist, ye Gods, the liberal man in battles: the liberal giver conquers foes in combat.

column1: kim icchantī saramā pra idam ānaṭ dūre hi adhvā jaguriḥ parācaiḥ kā asme hitiḥ kā pari takmyā āsīt katham rasāyāḥ ataraḥ payāṁsi
column2: WHAT wish of Saramâ hath brought her hither? The path leads far away to distant places. What charge hast thou for us? Where turns thy journey? How hast thou made thy way o'er Rasâ's waters.

column1: indrasya dūtīḥ iṣitā carāmi mahaḥ icchantī paṇayaḥ ni dhīn vaḥ ati skadaḥ bhiyasā tam naḥ āvat tathā rasāyāḥ ataram payāṁsi
column2: I come appointed messenger of Indra, seeking your ample stores of wealth, O Paṇis. This hath preserved me from the fear of crossing: thus have I made my way o'er Rasâ's waters.

column1: kīdr̥k indraḥ sarame kā dr̥śīkā yasya idam dūtīḥ asaraḥ parākāt ā ca gacchāt mitram ena dadhāma atha gavām go patiḥ naḥ bhavāti
column2: What is that Indra like, what is his aspect whose envoy, Saramâ, from afar thou comest? Let him approach, and we will show him friendship: he shall be made the herdsman of our cattle.

column1: na aham tam veda dabhyam dabhat saḥ yasya idam dūtīḥ asaram parākāt na tam gūhanti sravataḥ gabhīrāḥ hatāḥ indreṇa paṇayaḥ śayadhve
column2: I know him safe from harm: but he can punish who sent me hither from afar as envoy. Him rivers flowing with deep waters bide not. Low will ye be, O Paṇis, slain by Indra.

column1: imāḥ gāvaḥ sarame yāḥ aicchaḥ pari divaḥ antān su bhage patantī kaḥ te enāḥ ava sr̥jāt ayudhvī uta asmākam āyudhā santi tigmā
column2: These are the kine which, Saramâ, thou seekest, flying, O Blest One, to the ends of heaven. Who will loose these for thee without a battle? Yea, and sharp-pointed are our warlike weapons.

column1: asenyāḥ vaḥ paṇayaḥ vacāṁmsi aniṣavyāḥ tanvaḥ santu pāpīḥ adhr̥ṣṭaḥ vaḥ etavai astu panthāḥ br̥haspatiḥ vaḥ ubhayā na mr̥l̥āt
column2: Even if your wicked bodies, O ye Paṇis, were arrow-proof, your words are weak for wounding; And were the path to you as yet unmastered, Br̥ihaspati in neither case will spare you.

column1: ayam ni dhiḥ sarame adri budhnaḥ gobhiḥ aśvebhiḥ vasu bhiḥ ni r̥ṣṭaḥ rakṣanti tam paṇayaḥ ye su gopāḥ reku padam alakam ā jagantha
column2: Paved with the rock is this our treasure-chamber; filled full of precious things, of kine, and horses. These Paṇis who are watchful keepers guard it. In vain hast thou approached this lonely station.

column1: ā iha gāman r̥ṣayaḥ soma śitāḥ ayāsyaḥ aṅgirasaḥ nava gvāḥ te etam ūrvam vi bhajanta gonām atha etat vacaḥ paṇayaḥ vaman it
column2: R̥ishis will come inspirited with Soma, Angirases unwearied, and Navagvas. This stall of cattle will they part among them: then will the Paṇis wish these words unspoken.

column1: eva ca tvam sarame ājagantha pra bādhitā sahasā daivyena svasāram tvā kr̥ṇavai mā punaḥ gāḥ apa te gavām su bhage bhajāma
column2: Even thus, O Saramâ, hast thou come hither, forced by celestial might to make the journey. Turn thee not back, for thou shalt be our sister: O Blest One, we will give thee of the cattle.

column1: somaḥ ekebhyaḥ pavate ghr̥tam eke upa āsate yebhyaḥ madhu pra dhāvati tān cit eva api gacchatāt
column2: FOR some is Soma purified, some sit by sacrificial oil: To those for whom the meath flows forth, even to those let him depart.

column1: tapasā ye ānādhr̥ṣyāḥ tapasā ye svaḥ yayuḥ tapaḥ ye cakrire mahaḥ tān cit eva api gacchatāt
column2: Invincible through Fervour, those whom Fervour hath advanced to heaven, Who showed great Fervour in their lives, -even to those let him depart.

column1: ye yudhyante pra dhaneṣu śūrāsaḥ ye tanū tyajaḥ ye vā sahasra dakṣiṇāḥ tān cit eva api gacchatāt
column2: The heroes who contend in war and boldly cast their lives away, Or who give guerdon thousandfold, -even to those let him depart.

column1: ye cit pūrve r̥ta sāpaḥ r̥ta vānaḥ r̥tā vr̥dhaḥ pitr̥r̥n tapasvataḥ yama tān cit eva api gacchatāt
column2: Yea, the first followers of Law, Law's pure and holy strengtheners, The Fathers, Yama! Fervour-moved,even to those let him depart.

column1: sahasra nīthāḥ kavayaḥ ye gopāyanti sūryam r̥ṣīn tapasvataḥ yama tapaḥ jān api gacchatāt
column2: Skilled in a thousand ways and means, the sages who protect the Sun, The R̥ishis, Yama! Fervour-moved,– even to those let him depart.

column1: arāyi kāṇe vi kaṭe girim gaccha sadānve śirimbiṭhasya satva bhiḥ tebhiḥ tvā cātayāmasi
column2: ARAYI, one-eyed limping hag, fly, ever-screeching, to the hill. We frighten thee away with these, the heroes of Ṣirimbiṭha.

column1: catto iti itaḥ cattā amutaḥ sarvā bhrūṇānyi āruṣī arāyyam brahmaṇaḥ pate tīkṣṇa śr̥ṅga ut r̥ṣan ihi
column2: Scared from this place and that is she, destroyer of each germ unborn. Go, sharp-horned Brahmanaspti and drive Arayi far away.

column1: adaḥ yat dāru plavate sindhoḥ pāre apuruṣam tat ā rabhasva durhano itiduḥ hano tena gaccha paraḥ taram
column2: Yon log that floats without a man to guide it on the river's edge,– Seize it, thou thing with hideous jaws, and go thou far away thereon.

column1: yat ha prācīḥ ajaganta uraḥ maṇḍūra dhāṇikīḥ hatāḥ indrasya śatravaḥ sarve budbuda yāśavaḥ
column2: When, foul with secret stain and spot, ye hastened onward to the breast, All Indra's enemies were slain and passed away like froth and foam.

column1: pari ime gām aneṣata pari agnim ahr̥ṣata deveṣu akrata śravaḥ kaḥ imān ā dadharṣati
column2: These men have led about the cow, have duly carried Agni round, And raised their glory tg the Gods. Who will attack them with success?

column1: agnim hinvantu naḥ dhiyaḥ saptim āśum iva ājiṣu tena jeṣma dhanam dhanam
column2: LET songs of ours speed Agni forth like a fleet courser in the race, And we will win each prize through him.

column1: yayā gāḥ ākarāmahe senayā agne tava ūtyā tām naḥ hinva maghattaye
column2: Agni the dart whereby we gain kine for ourselves with help from thee,– That send us for the gain of wealth.

column1: ā agne sthūram rayim bhara pr̥thum go mantam aśvinam aṅdhi kham vartaya paṇim
column2: O Agni, bring us wealth secure, vast wealth in horses and in kine: Oil thou the socket, turn the wheel.

column1: agne nakṣatram ajaram ā sūryam rohayaḥ divi dadhat jyotiḥ janebhyaḥ
column2: O Agni, thou hast made the Sun, Eternal Star, to mount the sky, Bestowing light on living men.

column1: agne ketuḥ viśām asi preṣṭhaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ upastha sat bodha stotre vayaḥ dadhat
column2: Thou, Agni, art the people's light, best, dearest, seated in thy shrine: Watch for the singer, give him life.

column1: imā nu kam bhuvanā sīsadhāma indraḥ ca viśve ca devāḥ
column2: WE will, with Indra and all Gods to aid us, bring these existing worlds into subjection.

column1: yajñam ca naḥ tanvam ca pra jām ca ādityaiḥ indraḥ saha cīkl̥pāti
column2: Our sacrifice, our bodies, and our offspr. let Indra form together with Âdityas.

column1: ādityaiḥ indraḥ sa gaṇaḥ marut bhiḥ asmākam bhūtu avitā tanūnām
column2: With the Âdityas, with the band of Maruts, may Indra be Protector of our bodies.

column1: hatvāya devāḥ asurān yat āyan devāḥ deva tvam abhi rakṣamāṇāḥ
column2: As when the Gods came, after they had slaughtered the Asuras, keeping safe their Godlike nature,

column1: pratyañcam arkam anayan śacībhiḥ āt it svadhām iṣirām pari apaśyan
column2: Brought the Sun hitherward with mighty powers, and looked about them on their vigorous Godhead.

column1: sūryaḥ naḥ divaḥ pātu vātaḥ antarikṣāt agniḥ naḥ pārthivebhyaḥ
column2: MAY Sûrya guard us out of heaven, and Vâta from the firmament, And Agni from terrestrial spots.

column1: joṣa savitaḥ yasya te haraḥ śatam savān arhati pāhi naḥ didyutaḥ patantyāḥ
column2: Thou Savitar whose flame deserves hundred libations, be thou pleased: From failing lightning keep us safe.

column1: cakṣuḥ naḥ devaḥ savitā cakṣuḥ naḥ uta parvataḥ cakṣuḥ dhātā dadhātu naḥ
column2: May Savitar the God, and may Parvata also give us sight; May the Creator give us sight.

column1: cakṣuḥ naḥ dhehi cakṣuṣe cakṣuḥ vi khyai tanūbhyaḥ sam ca idam vi ca paśyema
column2: Give sight unto our eye, give thou our bodies sight that they may see: May we survey, discern this world.

column1: su sandr̥śam tvā vayam prati paśyema sūrya vi paśyema nr̥ cakṣasaḥ
column2: Thus, Sûrya, may we look on thee, on thee most lovely to behold, See clearly with the eyes of men.

column1: ut asau sūryaḥ agāt ut ayam māmakaḥ bhagaḥ aham tat vidvalā patim abhi āsākṣi vi sasahiḥ
column2: YON Sun hath mounted up, and this my happy fate hate mounted high. I knowing this, as conqueror have won my husband for mine own.

column1: aham ketuḥ aham mūrdhā aham ugrā vi vācanī mama it anu kratum patiḥ sehānāyāḥ upa ācaret
column2: I am the banner and the head, a mighty arbitress am I: I am victorious, and my Lord shall be submissive to my will.

column1: mama putrāḥ śatru hanaḥ atho iti me duhitā virāṭ uta aham asmi sam jayā patyau me ślokaḥ ut tamaḥ
column2: My Sons are slayers of the foe, my Daughter is a ruling Queen: I am victorious: o'er my Lord my song of triumph is supreme.

column1: yena indraḥ haviṣā kr̥tvī abhavat dyumnī ut tamaḥ idanm tat akri devāḥ asapatnā kila abhuvam
column2: Oblation, that which Indra gave and thus grew glorious and most high,– This have I offered, O ye Gods, and rid me of each rival wife.

column1: asapatnā sapatna ghnī jayantī abhi bhūvarī ā avr̥kṣam anyāsām vacarḥ rādhaḥ astheyasām iva
column2: Destroyer of the rival wife, Sole Spouse, victorious, conqueror, The others' glory have I seized as 'twere the wealth of weaker Dames.

column1: sam ajaiṣam imāḥ aham sa patnīḥ abhi bhūvarī yathā aham asya vīrasya vi rājāni janasya ca
column2: I have subdued as conqueror these rivals, these my fellow-wives, That I may hold imperial sway over this Hero and the folk.

column1: tīvrasya abhi vayasaḥ asya pāhi sarva rathā vi harī iti iha muñca indra mā tvā yajamānāsaḥ anye ni rīraman tubhyam ime sutāsaḥ
column2: TASTE this strong draught enriched with offered viands: with all thy chariot here unyoke thy Coursers. Let not those other sacrificers stay thee, Indra: these juices shed for thee are ready.

column1: tubhyam sutāḥ tubhyam oṁ iti sotvāsaḥ tvām giraḥ śvātryāḥ ā hvayanti indra idam adya savanam juṣāṇaḥ viśvasya vidvān iha pāhi somam
column2: Thine is the juice effused, thine are the juices yet to be pressed: our resonant songs invite thee. O Indra, pleased to-day with this libation, come, thou who knowest all and drink the Soma.

column1: yaḥ uśatā manasā somam asmai sarva hr̥dā deva kāmaḥ sunoti na gāḥ indraḥ tasya parā dadāti pra śastam it cārum asmai kr̥ṇoti
column2: Whoso, devoted to the God, effuses Soma for him with yearning heart and spirit,– Never doth Indra give away his cattle: for him he makes the lovely Soma famous.

column1: anu spaṣṭaḥ bhavati eṣaḥ asya yaḥ asmai revān na sunoti somam niḥ aratnau magha vā tam dadhāti brahma dviṣaḥ hanti ananu diṣṭaḥ
column2: He looks with Ioving favour on the mortal who, like a rich man, pours for him the Soma. Maghavan in his bended arm supports him: he slays, unasked, the men who hate devotion.

column1: aśvayantaḥ gavyantaḥ vājayantaḥ havāmahe tvā upa gantavai oṁ iti ābhūṣantaḥ te su matau navāyām vayam indra tvā śunam huvema
column2: We call on thee to come to us, desirous of goods and spoil, of cattle, and of horses. For thy new love and favour are we present: let us invoke thee, Indra, as our welfare.

column1: muñcāmi tvā haviṣā jīvanāya kam ajñāta yakṣmāt uta rāja yakṣmāt grāhi ḥ jagrāha yadi vā etat enam tasyāḥ indrāgnī iti pra mumuktam enam
column2: FOR life I set thee free by this oblation from the unknown decline and from Consumption; Or, if the grasping demon have possessed him, free him from her, O Indra, thou and Agni.

column1: yadi kṣita āyuḥ yadi vā parāitaḥ yadi mr̥tyoḥ antikam ni itaḥ eva tam ā harāmi niḥ r̥teḥ upa sthāt aspārṣam enam śata śāradāya
column2: Be his days ended, be he now departed, be he brought very near to death already, Out of Destruction's lap again I bring him, save him for life to last a hundred autumns.

column1: sahasra akṣeṇa śata śāradena śata āyuṣā haviṣā ā ahārṣam enam śatam yathā imam śaradaḥ nayāti indraḥ viśvasya duḥ itasya pāram
column2: With hundred-eyed oblation, hundred-autumned, bringing a hundred lives, have I restored him, That Indra for a hundred years may lead him safe to the farther shore of all misfortune.

column1: śatam jīva śaradaḥ vardhamānaḥ śatam hemantān śatam oṁ iti vasantān śatam indrāgnī iti savitā br̥haspatiḥ śata āyuṣā haviṣā imam punaḥ duḥ
column2: Live, waxing in thy strength, a hundred autumns, live through a hundred springs, a hundred winters. Through hundred-lived oblation Indra, Agni, Br̥ihaspati, Savitar yield him for a hundred!

column1: ā ahārṣam tvā avidam tvā punaḥ ā agāḥ punaḥ nava sarva aṅga sarvam te cakṣuḥ sarvam āyuḥ ca te avidam
column2: So have I found and rescued thee thou hast returned with youth renewed. Whole in thy members! I have found thy sight and all thy life for thee.

column1: brahmaṇā agniḥ sām vidānaḥ rakṣaḥ hā bādhatām itaḥ amīvā yaḥ te garbham duḥ nāmā yonim āśaye
column2: MAY Agni, yielding to our prayer, the Raksas-slayer, drive away The malady of evil name that hath beset thy labouring womb.

column1: yaḥ te garbham amīvā duḥ nāmā yonim āśaye agniḥ tam brahmaṇā saha niḥ kravya adam anīnaśat
column2: Agni, concurring in the prayer, drive off the eater of the flesh, The malady of evil name that hath attacked thy babe and womb.

column1: yaḥ te hanti patayantam ni satsnum yaḥ sarīsr̥pam jātam yaḥ te jighāṁsati tam itaḥ nāśayāmasi
column2: That which destroys the sinking germ, the settled, moving embryo, That which will kill the babe at birth,even this will we drive far away.

column1: yaḥ te ūrū iti vi harati antarā dampatī itidam patī śaye yonim yaḥ antaḥ ārel̥hi tam itaḥ nāśayāmasi
column2: That which divides thy legs that it may lie between the married pair, That penetrates and licks thy side,– even this will we exterminate.

column1: yaḥ tvā bhrātā patiḥ bhūtvā jāraḥ bhūtvā ni padyate pra jām yaḥ te j ighāṁsati tam itaḥ nāśayāmasi
column2: What rests by thee in borrowed form of brother, lover, or of lord, And would destroy thy Progeny,– even this will we exterminate.

column1: yaḥ tvā svapnena tamasā mohayitvā ni padyate pra jām yaḥ te ji ghāṁsati tam itaḥ nāśayāmasi
column2: That which through sleep or darkness hath deceived thee and lies down by thee, And will destroy thy progeny,– -even this will we exterminate.

column1: akṣībhyām te nāsikābhyām karṇābhyām chubukāt adhi yakṣmam śīrṣaṇyam mastiṣkāt jihvāyāḥ vi vr̥hāmi te
column2: FROM both thy nostrils, from thine eyes, from both thine ears and from thy chin, Forth from thy head and brain and tongue I drive thy malady away.

column1: grīvābhyaḥ te uṣṇihābhyaḥ kīkasābhyaḥ anūkyāt yakṣmam doṣaṇyam aṁsābhyām bāhu bhyām vi vr̥hāmi te
column2: From the neck-tendons and the neck, from the breast-bones and from the spine, From shoulders, upper, lower arms, I drive thy malady away.

column1: āntrebhyaḥ te gudābhyaḥ vaniṣṭhoḥ hr̥dayāt adhi yakṣmam matasnābhyām yaknaḥ plāśi bhyaḥ vi vr̥hāmi te
column2: From viscera and all within, forth from the rectum, from the heart, From kidneys, liver, and from spleen, I drive thy malady away.

column1: ūru bhyām te aṣṭhīvat bhyām pārṣṇi bhyām pra padābhyām yakṣmam śroṇi bhym bhāsadāt bhaṁsasaḥ vi vr̥hāmi te
column2: From thighs, from knee-caps, and from heels, and from the forepart of the feet, From hips from stomach, and from groin I drive thy malady away.

column1: mehanāt vanam karaṇāt loma bhyaḥ te nakhebhyaḥ yakṣmam sarvasmāt ātmanaḥ tam idam vi vr̥hāmi te
column2: From what is voided from within, and from thy hair, and from they nails, From all thyself from top to toe, I drive thy malady away.

column1: aṅgāt aṅgāt lomnaḥ lomnaḥ jātam parvaṇi parvaṇi yakṣmam sarvasmāt ātmanaḥ tam idam vi vr̥hāmi te
column2: From every member, every hair, disease that comes in every joint, From all thyself, from top to toe, I drive thy malady away.

column1: apa ihi manasaḥ pate apa krāma paraḥ cara paraḥ niḥ r̥tyai ā cakṣva bahudhā jīvataḥ manaḥ
column2: AVAUNT, thou Master of the mind Depart, and vanish far away. Look on Destruction far from hence. The live man's mind is manifold.

column1: bhadram vai varam vr̥ṇate bhadram yuñjanti dakṣiṇam bhadram vaivasvate cakṣuḥ bahu trā jīvataḥ manaḥ
column2: A happy boon do men elect, a mighty blessing they obtain. Bliss with Vaivasvata they see. The live man's mind seeks many a place.

column1: yat āśasā niḥ śasā abhi śasā upa ārima jāgrataḥ yat svapantaḥ agniḥ viśvāni apa duḥ kr̥tāni ajuṣṭāni āre asmat dādhātu
column2: If by address, by blame, by imprecation we have committed sin, awake or sleeping, All hateful acts of ours, all evil doings may Agni bear away to distant places.

column1: yat indra brahmaṇaḥ pate abhi droham carāmasi pra cetāḥ naḥ āṅgirasaḥ dviṣatām pātu aṁhasaḥ
column2: When, Indra, Brahmaṇaspati, our deeds are wrongful and unjust, May provident Ângirasa prevent our foes from troubling, us.

column1: ajaiṣma adya asanāma ca abhūma anāgasaḥ vayam jāgrat svapnaḥ sam kalpaḥ pāpaḥ yam dviṣmaḥ tam saḥ r̥cchatu yaḥ naḥ dveṣṭi tam r̥cchatu
column2: We have prevailed this day and won: we are made free from sin and guilt. Ill thoughts, that visit us awake or sleeping, seize the man we hate, yea, seize the man who hateth us.

column1: devāḥ kapotaḥ iṣitaḥ yat icchan dūtaḥ niḥ r̥tyāḥ idam ājagāma tasmai arcāma kr̥ṇavāma niḥ kr̥tim śam naḥ astu dvi pade śam catuḥ pade
column2: GODS, whatsoe'er the Dove came hither seeking, sent to us as the envoy of Destruction, For that let us sing hymns and make atonement. Well be it with our quadrupeds and bipeds.

column1: śivaḥ kapotaḥ iṣitaḥ naḥ astu anāgāḥ devāḥ śakunaḥ gr̥heṣu agniḥ hi vipraḥ juṣatām haviḥ naḥ pari hetiḥ pakṣiṇī naḥ vr̥ṇaktu
column2: Auspicious be the Dove that hath been sent us, a harmless bird, ye Gods, within our dwelling. May Agni, Sage, be pleased with our oblation, and may the Missile borne on wings avoid us.

column1: hetiḥ pakṣiṇī na dabhāti asmān āṣṭryām padam kr̥ṇute agni dhāne śam naḥ gobhyaḥ ca puruṣebhyaḥ ca astu mā naḥ hiṁsīt iha devāḥ kapotaḥ
column2: Let not the Arrow that hath wings distract us: beside the fire-place, on the hearth it settles. May, it bring welfare to our men and cattle: here let the Dove, ye Gods, forbear to harm us.

column1: yat ulūkaḥ vadati mogham etat yat kapotaḥ padam agnau kr̥ṇoti yasya dūtaḥ pra hitaḥ eṣaḥ etat tasmai yamāya namaḥ astu mr̥tyave
column2: The screeching of the owl is ineffective and when beside the fire the Dove hath settled, To him who sent it hithcr as an envoy, to him be reverence paid, to Death, to Yama.

column1: r̥cā kapotam nudata pra nodam iṣam madantaḥ pari gām nayadhvam sam yopayantaḥ duḥ itāni viśvā hitvā naḥ ūrjam pra patāt patiṣṭhaḥ
column2: Drive forth the Dove, chase it with holy verses: rejoicing, bring ye hither food and cattle, Barring the way against all grief and trouble. Let the swift bird fly forth and leave us vigour.

column1: r̥ṣabham mā samānānām sa patnānām vi sasahim hantāram śatrūṇām kr̥dhi vi rājam go patim gavām
column2: MAKE me a bull among my peers, make me my rivals, conqueror: Make me the slayer of my foes, a sovran ruler, lord of kine

column1: aham asmi sapatna hā indraḥ iva ariṣṭaḥ akṣataḥ adhaḥ sa patnāḥ me padoḥ ime sarve abhi sthitāḥ
column2: I am my rivals' slayer, like Indra unwounded and unhurt, And all these enemies of mine are vanquished and beneath my feet.

column2: Here, verily, I bind you fast, as the two bow-ends with the string. Press down these men, O Lord of Speech, that they may humbly speak to me.

column1: abhi bhūḥ aham ā agamam viśva karmeṇa dhāmnā ā vaḥ cittam ā vaḥ vratam ā vaḥ aham sam itim dade
column2: Hither I came as conqueror with mighty all-effecting power, And I have mastered all your thought, your synod, and your holy work.

column1: yoga kṣemam vaḥ ādāya aham bhūyāsam ut tamaḥ ā vaḥ mūrdhānam akramīm adhaḥ padāt me ut vadata maṇḍūkāḥ iva udakāt maṇḍūkāḥ udakāt iva
column2: May I be highest, having gained your strength in war, your skill in peace my feet have trodden on your heads. Speak to me from beneath my feet, as frogs from out the water croak, as frogs from out the water croak.

column1: tubhya idam indra pari sicyate madhu tvam sutasya kalaśasya rājas i tvam rayim puru vīrām oṁ iti naḥ kr̥dhi tvam tapaḥ pari tapya ajayaḥ [svar iti]svaḥ
column2: THIS pleasant meath, O Indra, is effused for thee: thou art the ruling Lord of beaker and of juice. Bestow upon us wealth with many hero sons: thou, having glowed with Fervour, wortnest heavenly light.

column1: svaḥ jitam mahi mandānam andhasaḥ havāmahe pari śakram sutān upa imam naḥ yajñam iha bodhi ā gahi spr̥dhaḥ jayantam magha vānam īmahe
column2: Let us call Ṣakra to libations here effused, winner of light who joyeth in the potent juice. Mark well this sacrifice of ours and come to us: we pray to Maghavan the Vanquisher of hosts.

column1: somasya rājñaḥ varuṇasya dharmaṇi br̥haspateḥ anu matyāḥ oṁ iti śarmaṇi tava aham adya magha van upa stutau dhātaḥ vi dhātariti vi dhātaḥ kalaśān abhakṣayam
column2: By royal Soma's and by Varuṇa's decree, under Br̥ihaspati's and Anumati's guard, This day by thine authority, O Maghavan, Maker, Disposer thou! have I enjoyed the jars.

column1: pra sūtaḥ bhakṣam akaram carau api stomam ca imam prathamaḥ sūriḥ ut mr̥je sute sātena yadi ā agamam vām prati viśvāmitrajamadagnī iti dame
column2: I, too, urged on, have had my portion, in the bowl, and as first Prince I drew forth this my hymn of praise, When with the prize I came unto the flowing juice, O Viṣvâmitra, Jamadagni, to your home.

column1: vātasya nu mahimānam rathasya rujan eti stanayan asya ghoṣaḥ di vi spr̥k yāti aruṇāni kr̥ṇvan uto iti eti pr̥thivyā reṇum asyan
column2: O THE Wind's chariot, O its power and glory! Crashing it goes and hath a voice of thunder. It makes the regions red and touches heaven, and as it moves the dust of earth is scattered.

column1: sam pra īrate anu vātasya vi sthāḥ ā enam gacchanti samanam na yoṣāḥ tābhiḥ sa yuk sa ratham devaḥ īyate asya viśvasya bhuvanasya rājā
column2: Along the traces of the Wind they hurry, they come to him as dames to an assembly. Borne on his car with these for his attendants, the God speeds forth, the universe's Monarch.

column2: Travelling on the paths of air's midregion, no single day doth he take rest or slumber. Holy and earliest-born, Friend of fhe waters, where did he spring and from what region came he?

column1: ātmā devānām bhuvanasya garbhaḥ yathāvaśam carati devaḥ eṣaḥ ghoṣāḥ it asya śr̥ṇvire na rūpam tasmai vātāya haviṣā vidhema

column2: THOU, mighty Agni, gatherest up all that is precious for thy friend. Bring us all treasures as thou art enkindled in libation's place

column2: Assemble, speak together: let your minds be all of one accord, As ancient Gods unanimous sit down to their appointed share.

column2: The place is common, common the assembly, common the mind, so be their thought united. A common purpose do I lay before you, and worship with your general oblation.

column2: One and the same be your resolve, and be your minds of one accord. United be the thoughts of all that all may happily agree.

column1: <b>(ऋव्_१०,९२)यज्ञस्य वः रथ्यम् विश्पतिम् विशाम् होतारम् अक्तोः अतिथिम् विभावसुम् शोचन् शुष्कासु हरिणीषु जर्भुरत् वृषा केतुः यजतः द्याम् अशायत
column2: I PRAISE your Charioteer of sacrifice, the Lord of men, Priest of the tribes, refulgent, Guest of night. Blazing amid dry plants, snatching amid the green, the Strong, the Holy Herald hath attained to heaven.

column1: agnim īl̥e puraḥ hitam yajñasya devam r̥tvijam hotāram ratna dhātamam
column2: Agni I praise, the household priest, God, minister of sacrifice, Invoker, best bestowing wealth.

column1: agniḥ pūrvebhiḥ r̥ṣi bhiḥ īḍyaḥ nūtanaiḥ uta saḥ devān ā iha vakṣati
column2: Agni is worthy to be praised, By present as by seers of old: May he to us conduct the gods.

column1: agninā rayim aśnavat poṣam eva dive dive yaśasam vīravat tamam
column2: Through Agni may we riches gain, And day by day prosperity Replete with fame and manly sons.

column1: agne yam yajñam adhvaram viśvataḥ pari bhūḥ asi saḥ it deveṣu gacchati
column2: The worship and the sacrifice, Guarded by thee on every side, Go straight, O Agni, to the gods.

column1: agniḥ hotā kavi kratuḥ satyaḥ citraśravaḥ tamaḥ devaḥ devebhiḥ ā gamat
column2: May Agni, the invoker, wise And true, of most resplendent fame, The god, come hither with the gods.

column1: yat aṅga dāśuṣe tvam agne bhadram kariṣyasi tava it tat satyam aṅgiraḥ
column2: Whatever good thou wilt bestow, O Agni, on the pious man, That gift comes true, O Angiras.

column1: upa tvā agne dive dive doṣāvastaḥ dhiyā vayam namaḥ bharantaḥ ā imasi
column2: To thee, O Agni, day by day, O thou illuminer of gloom, With thought we, bearing homage, come:

column1: rājantam adhvarāṇām gopām r̥tasya dīdivim vardhamānam sve dame
column2: To thee the lord of sacrifice, The radiant guardian of the Law, That growest in thine own abode.

column1: saḥ naḥ pitāiva sūnave agne su upāyanaḥ bhava sacasva naḥ svastaye
column2: So, like a father to his son, Be easy of approach to us; Agni, for weal abide with us.

column1: indrasya nu vīryāṇi pra vocam yāni cakāra prathamāni vajrī ahan ahim anu apaḥ tatarda pra vakṣaṇāāḥ abhinat parvatānām
column2: I will proclaim the manly deeds of Indra, The first that he performed, the lightning-wielder. He slew the serpent, then discharged the waters, And cleft the caverns of the lofty mountains.

column1: ahan ahim parvate śiśriyāṇam tvaṣṭā asmai vajram svaryam tatakṣa vāśrāḥ iva dhenavaḥ syandamānāḥ añjaḥ samudram ava jagmuḥ āpaḥ
column2: He slew the serpent lying on the mountain: For him the whizzing bolt has Tvaṣṭar fashioned. Like lowing cows, with rapid current flowing, The waters to the ocean down have glided.

column1: vr̥ṣa yamāṇaḥ avr̥ṇīta somam tri kadrukeṣu apibat sutasya ā sāyakam maghavā adatta vajram ahan enam prathama jām ahīnām
column2: Impetuous like a bull he chose the Soma, And drank in threefold vessels of its juices. The bounteous god grasped lightning for his missile; He struck down dead that first-born of the serpents.

column1: yat indra ahan prathama jām ahīnām āt māyinām amināḥ pra uta māyāḥ āt sūryam janayan dyām uṣāsam tādītnā śatrum na kilā vivitse
column2: When thou hadst slain the first-born of the serpents, And thwarted all the wiles of crafty schemers, Anon disclosing sun, and dawn, and heaven, Thou truly foundest not a foe, O Indra.

column1: ahan vr̥tram vr̥tra taram vi aṁsam indraḥ vajreṇa mahatā vadhena skandhāṁsi iva kuliśena vi vr̥kṇā ahiḥ śayate upa pr̥k pr̥thivyāḥ
column2: Indra slew Vṛtra and one worse than Vṛtra, Vyaṃsa, with lightning, his resistless weapon: Like trunks of trees, with axes hewn in pieces, The serpent clinging to the earth lay prostrate.

column1: ayoddhāiva duḥ madaḥ ā hi juhve mahāvīram tuvi bādham r̥jīṣam na tārīt asya sam r̥tim vadhānām sam rujānāḥ pipiṣe indra śatruḥ
column2: He like a drunken coward challenged Indra, The headlong, many-crushing, mighty hero. He parried not the onset of the weapons: The foe of Indra, falling, crushed the channels.

column2: Footless and handless he with Indra battled, Who smote him then upon his back with lightning. But, impotent, he strove to match the hero: He lay with scattered limbs in many places.

column2: As thus he lay, like broken reed, the waters, Now courage taking, surge across his body. He lies beneath the very feet of rivers Which Vṛtra with his might had close encompassed.

column2: The strength began to fail of Vṛtra's mother, For Indra had cast down his bolt upon her. Above the mother was, the son was under; And like a cow beside her calf lies Dānu.

column2: The waters deep have hidden Vṛtra's body, Plunged in the midst of never-ceasing torrents That stand not still, but ever hasten onward: Indra's fierce foe sank down to lasting darkness.

column2: Enclosed by demons, guarded by a serpent, The waters stood like cows by Paṇi captured. The waters' orifice that was obstructed. When Vṛtra he had smitten, Indra opened.

column1: aśvyaḥ vāraḥ abhavaḥ tat indra sr̥ke yat tvā prati ahan devaḥ ekaḥ ajayaḥ gāḥ ajayaḥ śūra somam ava asr̥jaḥ sartave sapta sindhūn
column2: A horse's tail thou didst become, O Indra, When, on his spear impaled, as god unaided, The cows, O hero, thou didst win and Soma, And free the seven streams to flow in torrents.

column2: Him lightning then availèd not nor thunder, Nor mist, nor hailstorm which around he scattered: When Indra and the serpent fought in battle, The bounteous god gained victory for ever.

column1: aheḥ yātāram kam apaśyaḥ indra hr̥di yat te jaghnuṣaḥ bhīḥ agacchat nava ca yam navatim ca sravantīḥ śyenaḥ na bhītaḥ ataraḥ rajāṁsi
column2: Whom saw'st thou as avenger of the serpent, As terror seized thy heart when thou hadst slain him, And thou didst cross the nine and ninety rivers And air's broad spaces, like a hawk affrighted?

column1: indraḥ yātaḥ ava sitasya rājā śamasya ca śr̥ṅgiṇaḥ vajra bāhuḥ saḥ it oṁ iti rājā kṣayati carṣaṇīnām arān na nemiḥ pari tā babhūva
column2: Indra is king of all that's fixed and moving, Of tame and horned beasts, the thunder-wielder. He truly rules, as king of busy mortals; Them he encompasses as spokes the felly.

column1: sam pūṣan adhvanaḥ tira vi aṁhaḥ vi mucaḥ napāt sakṣva deva pra naḥ puraḥ
column2: O Pūṣan pass along the roads, Free us, son of release, from care. Guide us, going before, O god.

column2: The wicked, ill-intentioned wolf, Pūṣan, that lies in wait for us. Him from our path smite thou away.

column2: Tread under foot the burning brand Of crafty and malignant men, The miscreants whoe'er they be.

column2: Pūṣan, that help of thine we claim, O wonder-working, sapient god, Wherewith our fathers thou didst aid.

column2: May I attain that wealth renowned and ample, With many heroes, troops of friends, and horses, O Dawn, that shinest forth with wondrous glory. Urged on by mighty strength, auspicious lady.

column2: Born newly again and again though ancient, Herself adorning with the selfsame colour, The goddess wears away the life of mortals, Like stakes diminished by a skilful gambler.

column2: The ends of heaven disclosing, she awakens; To distance far she banishes her sister. Diminishing the years of life, the maiden Flushes afar with the light of her lover.

column2: Gracious and bright, spreading her rays like cattle, As a river its flood, afar she glimmers. Infringing not the gods' unchanging statutes, She flushes radiant with the beams of Sūrya.

column2: O Dawn, bring us that brilliant wealth, O thou that bearest rich rewards, Whereby both sons and grandsons we may well maintain.

column2: Yoke, Dawn, to-day thy ruddy steeds, O thou that bearest rich rewards: Then on thy car to us all fortune's gifts convey.

column2: This light has come, of all the lights the fairest: The brilliant brightness has been born effulgent. Urged onward for god Savitar's uprising, Night now has yielded up her place to morning.

column2: Bringing a radiant calf she comes resplendent: To her the Black one has given up her mansions. Akin, immortal, following each the other, Morning and Night fare on, exchanging colours.

column2: The sisters' pathway is the same, unending: Taught by the gods alternately they tread it. Fair-shaped, of form diverse, yet single-minded, Morning and Night clash not, nor do they tarry.

column2: Bright leader of glad sounds she shines effulgent: Widely she has unclosed for us her portals. Pervading all the world she shows us riches: Dawn has awakened every living creature.

column2: Men lying on the ground she wakes to action: Some rise to seek enjoyment of great riches, Some, seeing little, to behold the distant: Dawn has awakened every living creature.

column1: kṣatrāya tvam śravase tvam mahīyai iṣṭaye tvam artham iva tvam ityai vi sadr̥śā jīvitā abhi pracakṣe uṣāḥ ajīgaḥ bhuvanāni viśvā
column2: One for dominion, and for fame another; Another is aroused for winning greatness; Another seeks the goal of varied nurture: Dawn has awakened every living creature.

column1: eṣā divaḥ duhitā prati adarśi vi ucchantī yuvatiḥ śukra vāsāḥ viśvasya īśānā pārthivasya vasvaḥ uṣaḥ adya iha su bhage vi uccha
column2: Daughter of Heaven, she has appeared before us, A maiden shining in resplendent raiment. Thou sovereign lady of all earthly treasure, Auspicious Dawn, shine here to-day upon us.

column2: The path of those that have gone by she follows, The first of endless dawns to come hereafter. The living at her rising she arouses; The dead she never wakens from their slumber.

column2: O Dawn, since thou hast made them kindle Agni, Since thou hast shone forth with the light of Sūrya, Since thou the sacrificer hast awakened: Thou hast performed among the gods good service.

column2: How distant is the time when she comes midway Between the past and those to shine in future? The earlier dawns right willingly she follows. Expected, she fulfils the later's wishes.

column2: Gone are those mortals who in former ages Beheld the flushing of the early morning; We living men now look upon her shining: Those will be born who shall hereafter see her.

column2: Dispelling foes, observer of world order, Born in due season, giver of enjoyment, Wafting oblations, bringing wealth and fortune, Shine brightly here to-day, O Dawn, upon us.

column2: The goddess Dawn has flushed in former ages, And here to-day the bounteous maiden flushes: So also may she flush in days hereafter. With powers her own she fares, immortal, ageless.
