column2: Non-being then existed not nor being: There was no air, nor sky that is beyond it. What was concealed? Wherein? In whose protection? And was there deep unfathomable water?

column1: na mr̥tyuḥ āsīt amr̥tam na tarhi na rātryāḥ ahnaḥ āsīt pra ketaḥ ānīt avātam svadhayā tat ekam tasmāt ha anyat na paraḥ kim cana āsa
column2: Death then existed not nor life immortal; Of neither night nor day was any token. By its inherent force the One breathed windless: No other thing than that beyond existed.

column1: tamaḥ āsīt tamasā gūl̥ham agre apra ketam salilam sarvam āḥ idam tucchyena ābhu api hitam yat āsīt tapasaḥ tat mahinā ajāyata ekam
column2: Darkness there was at first by darkness hidden; Without distinctive marks, this all was water. That which, becoming, by the void was covered. That One by force of heat came into being.

column1: kāmaḥ tat agre sam avartata adhi manasaḥ retaḥ prathamam yat āsīt sataḥ bandhum asati niḥ avindan hr̥di pratīṣyā kavayaḥ manīṣā
column2: Desire entered the One in the beginning: It was the earliest seed, of thought the product. The sages searching in their hearts with wisdom, Found out the bond of being in non-being.

column1: tiraścīnaḥ vi tataḥ raśmiḥ eṣām adhaḥ svit āsī3t upari svit āsī3t retaḥ dhāḥ āsan mahimānaḥ āsan svadhā avastāt pra yatiḥ parastāt
column2: Their ray extended light across the darkness: But was the One above or was it under? Creative force was there, and fertile power: Below was energy, above was impulse.

column1: kaḥ addhā veda kaḥ iha pra vocat kutaḥ ājātā kutaḥ iyam vi sr̥ṣṭiḥ arvāk devāḥ asya vi sarjanena atha kaḥ veda yataḥ ābabhūva
column2: Who knows for certain? Who shall here declare it? Whence was it born, and whence came this creation? The gods were born after this world's creation: Then who can know from whence it has arisen?

column1: iyam vi sr̥ṣṭiḥ yataḥ ābabhūva yadi vā dadhe yadi vā na yaḥ asya adhi akṣaḥ parame vi oman saḥ aṅga veda yadi vā na veda
column2: None knoweth whence creation has arisen; And whether he has or has not produced it: He who surveys it in the highest heaven, He only knows, or haply he may know not.

column1: araṇyāni araṇyānyi asau yā pra iva naśyasi kathā grāmam na pr̥cchasi na tvā bhīḥ iva vindataiṁśn
column2: O forest nymph, O forest nymph, Thou seemest to have lost thy way: Why dost not for the village ask? Has fear, perchance, now entered thee ?

column1: vr̥ṣāravāya vadate yat upa avati ciccikaḥ āghāṭibhiḥ iva dhāvayan araṇyāniḥ mahīyate
column2: When to the owl's loud-sounding hoot The parrot makes an answering cry, And hops, as to the cymbal's clash, Then Araṇyānī heaves with joy.

column1: uta gāvaḥ iva adanti uta veśma ivadr̥śyate uto iti araṇyāniḥ sāyam śakaṭīḥ iva sarjati
column2: Sounds as of cows that graze are heard, A dwelling house appears to loom, And Araṇyānī, forest nymph, Creaks like a cart at eventide.

column1: gām aṅga eṣaḥ ā hvayati dāru aṅga eṣaḥ apa avadhīt vasan araṇyānyām sāyam akrukṣat iti manyate
column2: Here some one calls his cow to him, Another there is felling wood: Who in the forest bides at eve Thinks to himself,"I heard a cry."

column1: na vai araṇyāniḥ hanti anyaḥ ca it na abhi gacchati svādoḥ phalasya jagdhvāya yathākāmam ni padyate
column2: Never does Araṇyānī hurt, Unless one goes too near to her; When she has eaten of sweet fruit. At her own will she goes to rest.

column1: āñjana gandhim surabhim bahu annām akr̥ṣi valām pra aham mr̥gāṇām mātaram araṇyānim aśaṁsiṣam
column2: Sweet-scented, redolent of balm, Replete with food, though tilling not, Mother of beasts, the forest nymph, Her I have magnified with praise.

column1: vātasya nu mahimānam rathasya rujan eti stanayan asya ghoṣaḥ di vi spr̥k yāti aruṇāni kr̥ṇvan uto iti eti pr̥thivyā reṇum asyan
column2: Of Vāta's car I now will praise the greatness: Rending it speeds along; its noise is thunder. Touching the sky it flies, creating lightnings; Scattering dust it traverses earth's ridges.

column1: sam pra īrate anu vātasya vi sthāḥ ā enam gacchanti samanam na yoṣāḥ tābhiḥ sa yuk sa ratham devaḥ īyate asya viśvasya bhuvanasya rājā
column2: The hosts of Vāta onward speed together: They haste to him as women to a concourse. The god with them upon the same car mounted, The king of all this universe speeds onward.

column1: antarikṣe pathi bhiḥ īyamānaḥ na ni viśate katamat cana ahariti apām sakhā prathama jāḥ r̥ta vā kva svit jātaḥ kutaḥ ā babhūva
column2: In air, along his pathways speeding onward, Never on any day he tarries resting. The first-born order-loving friend of waters: Where was he born, and whence has he arisen?

column1: ātmā devānām bhuvanasya garbhaḥ yathāvaśam carati devaḥ eṣaḥ ghoṣāḥ it asya śr̥ṇvire na rūpam tasmai vātāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: Of gods the breath, and of the world the offspring, This god according to his liking wanders. His sound is heard, his form is never looked on: That Vāta let us worship with oblation.

column1: vāyo iti ā yāhi darśata ime somāḥ araṁ kr̥tāḥ teṣām pāhi śrudhi havam
column2: Come hither, O Vâyu, thou beautiful one 1! These Somas are ready, drink of them, hear our call!

column1: vāyo iti ukthebhiḥ jarante tvām accha jaritāraḥ suta somāḥ ahaḥ vidaḥ
column2: O Vâyu, the praisers celebrate thee with hymns, they who know the feast-days 1, and have prepared the Soma.

column1: vāyo iti tava pra pr̥ñcatī dhenā jigāti dāśuṣe urūcī soma pītaye
column2: O Vâyu, thy satisfying stream 1 goes to the worshipper, wide-reaching, to the Soma-draught.

column1: indravāyūiti ime sutāḥ upa prayaḥ bhiḥ ā gatam indavaḥ vām uśanti hi
column2: O Indra and Vâyu, these (libations of Soma) are poured out; come hither for the sake of 1 our offerings, for the drops (of Soma) long for you.

column1: vāyo iti indraḥ ca cetathaḥ sutānām vājinīvasūitivājinī vasū tau ā yātam upa dravat
column2: O Indra and Vâyu, you perceive the libations, you who are rich in booty 1; come then quickly hither!

column1: vāyo iti indraḥ ca sunvataḥ ā yātam upa niḥ kr̥tam makṣu itthā dhiyā narā
column2: O Vâyu and Indra, come near to the work 1 of the sacrificer, quick, thus is my prayer 2, O ye men!

column1: mitram huve pūta dakṣam varuṇam ca riśādasam dhiyam ghr̥tācīm sādhantā
column2: I call Mitra, endowed with holy strength 1, and Varuna, who destroys all enemies; who both fulfil a prayer accompanied by fat offerings 2.

column1: r̥tena mitrāvaruṇau r̥tāvr̥dhau r̥ta spr̥śā kratum br̥hantam āśātheiti
column2: On the right way, O Mitra and Varuna, you have obtained great wisdom, you who increase the right and adhere to the right 1;

column1: kavī iti naḥ mitrāvaruṇā tuvi jātau uru kṣayā dakṣam dadhāteiti apasam
column2: These two sages, Mitra and Varuna, the mighty, wide-ruling, give us efficient strength.

column1: yuñjanti bradhnam aruṣam carantam pari tasthuṣaḥ rocante rocanā divi
column2: Those who stand around 2 him while he moves on, harness the bright red (steed) 1; the lights in heaven shine forth 3.

column1: yuñjanti asya kāmyā harī iti vipakṣasā rathe śoṇā dhr̥ṣṇū iti nr̥ vāhasā
column2: They harness to the chariot on each side his (Indra's) 1 two favourite bays, the brown, the bold, who can carry the hero.

column1: ketum kr̥ṇvan aketave peśaḥ maryāḥ apeśase sam uṣat bhiḥ ajāyathāḥ
column2: Thou who createst light where there was no light, and form, O men 1! where there was no form, hast been born together with the dawns 2.

column1: āt aha svadhām anu punaḥ garbha tvam āīrire dadhānāḥ nāma yajñiyam
column2: Thereupon 1 they (the Maruts), according to their wont 2, assumed again the form of new-born babes 3, taking their sacred name.

column1: vīl̥u cit ārujatnu bhiḥ guhā cit indra vahni bhiḥ avindaḥ usriyāḥ anu
column2: Thou, O Indra, with the swift Maruts 1, who break even through the stronghold 2, hast found even in their hiding-place the bright ones 3 (days or clouds).

column1: deva yantaḥ yathā matim accha vidat vasum giraḥ mahām anūṣata śrutam
column2: The pious singers 1 (the Maruts) have, after their own mind 2, shouted towards the giver of wealth, the great, the glorious (Indra).

column1: indreṇa sam hi dr̥kṣase sam jagmānaḥ abibhyuṣā mandū iti samāna varcasā
column2: Mayest thou 1 (host of the Maruts) be verily seen 2 coming together with Indra, the fearless: you are both happy-making, and of equal splendour.

column1: anavadyaiḥ abhidyu bhiḥ makhaḥ sahasvat arcati gaṇaiḥ indrasya kāmyaiḥ
column2: With the beloved hosts of Indra, with the blameless, hasting 2 (Maruts), the sacrificer 1 cries aloud.

column1: ataḥ parijman ā gahi divaḥ vā rocanāt adhi sam asmin r̥ñjate giraḥ
column2: From yonder, O traveller (Indra), come hither, or from the light of heaven 1; the singers all yearn for it;—

column1: itaḥ vā sātim īmahe diva vā pārthivāt adhi indram mahaḥ vā rajasaḥ
column2: Or we ask Indra for help from here, or from heaven, or from above the earth, or from the great sky.

column1: prati tyam cārum adhvaram go pīthāya pra hūyase marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: Thou art called forth to this fair sacrifice for a draught of milk 1; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: nahi devaḥ na martyaḥ mahaḥ tava kratum paraḥ marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: No god indeed, no mortal, is beyond the might 1 of thee, the mighty one; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: ye mahaḥ rajasaḥ viduḥ viśve devāsaḥ adruhaḥ marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: They who know of the great sky 1, the Visve Devas 2 without guile 3; with those Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: ye ugrāḥ arkam ānr̥cuḥ anādhr̥ṣṭāsaḥ ojasā marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: The strong ones who sing their song 1, unconquerable by force; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: ye śubhrāḥ ghora varpasaḥ su kṣatrāsaḥ riśādasaḥ marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: They who are brilliant, of terrible designs, powerful, and devourers of foes; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: ye nākasya adhi rocane divi devāsaḥ āsate marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: They who in heaven are enthroned as gods, in the light of the firmament 1; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: ye īṅkhayanti parvatān tiraḥ samudram arṇavam marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: They who toss the clouds 1 across the surging sea 2; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: ā ye tanvanti raśmi bhiḥ tiraḥ samudram ojasā marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: They who shoot with their darts (lightnings) across the sea with might; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: abhi tvā pūrva pītaye sr̥jāmi somyam madhu marut bhiḥ agne ā gahi
column2: I pour out to thee for the early draught1 the sweet (juice) of Soma; with the Maruts come hither, O Agni!

column1: krīl̥am vaḥ śardhaḥ mārutam anarvāṇam rathe śubham kaṇvāḥ abhi pra gāyata
column2: Sing forth, O Kanvas, to the sportive host of your Maruts, brilliant on their chariots, and unscathed 1,—

column1: ye pr̥ṣatībhiḥ r̥ṣṭi bhiḥ sākam vāśībhiḥ añji bhiḥ ajāyanta sva bhānavaḥ
column2: They who were born together, self-luminous, with the spotted deer (the clouds) 1, the spears, the daggers, the glittering ornaments 2.

column1: iha iva śr̥ṇva eṣām kaśāḥ hasteṣu yat vadān ni yāman citram r̥ñjate
column2: I hear their 1 whips, almost close by, when they crack them in their hands; they gain splendour 2 on their way 3.

column1: pra vaḥ śardhāya ghr̥ṣvaye tveṣa dyumnāya śuṣmiṇe devattam brahma gāyata
column2: Sing forth the god-given prayer to the wild 1 host of your Maruts, endowed with terrible vigour 2 and strength.

column1: pra śaṁsa goṣu aghnyam krīl̥am yat śardhaḥ mārutam jambhe rasasya vavr̥dhe
column2: Celebrate the bull among the cows (the storm among the clouds) 1, for it is the sportive host of the Maruts; he grew as he tasted the rain 2.

column1: kaḥ vaḥ varṣiṣṭhaḥ ā naraḥ divaḥ ca gmaḥ ca dhūtayaḥ yat sīm antam na dhūnutha
column2: Who, O ye men, is the strongest among you here, ye shakers of heaven and earth, when you shake them like the hem of a garment 1?

column1: ni vaḥ yāmāya mānuṣaḥ dadhre ugrāya manyave jihīta parvataḥ giriḥ
column2: At your approach the son of man holds himself down; the gnarled cloud 1 fled at your fierce anger.

column1: yeṣām ajmeṣu pr̥thivī jujurvān iva viśpatiḥ bhiyā yāmeṣu rejate
column2: They at whose racings 1 the earth, like a hoary king, trembles for fear on their ways,

column1: sthiram hi jānam eṣām vayaḥ mātuḥ niḥ etave yat sīm anu dvitā śavaḥ
column2: Their birth is strong indeed: there is strength to come forth from their mother, nay, there is vigour twice enough for it 1.

column1: ut oṁ iti tye sūnavaḥ giraḥ kāṣṭhāḥ ajmeṣu atnata vāśrāḥ abhi jñu yātave
column2: And these sons, the singers 1, stretched out the fences in their racings 2; the cows had to walk knee-deep.

column1: tyam cit gha dīrgham pr̥thum mihaḥ napātam amr̥dhram pra cyavayanti yāma bhiḥ
column2: They cause this long and broad unceasing rain 1 to fall on their ways.

column1: marutaḥ yat ha vaḥ balam janān acucyavītana girīn acucyavītana
column2: O Maruts, with such strength as yours, you have caused men to tremble 1, you have caused the mountains to tremble.

column1: yat ha yānti marutaḥ sam ha bruvate adhvan ā śr̥ṇoti kaḥ cit eṣām
column2: As the Maruts pass 1 along, they talk together on the way: does any one hear them?

column1: pra yāta śībham āśubhiḥ santi kaṇveṣu vaḥ duvaḥ tatro iti su mādayādhvai
column2: Come fast on your quick steeds! there are worshippers 1 for you among the Kanvas: may you well rejoice among them.

column1: asti hi sma madāya vaḥ smasi sma vayam eṣām viśvam cit āyuḥ jīvase
column2: Truly there is enough for your rejoicing. We always are their servants, that we may live even the whole of life.

column1: kat ha nūnam kadha priyaḥ pitā putram na hastayoḥ dadhidhve vr̥kta barhiṣaḥ
column2: What then now? When 1 will you take (us) as a dear father takes his son by both hands, O ye gods, for whom the sacred grass has been trimmed 2?

column1: kva nūnam kat vaḥ artham gantā divaḥ na pr̥thivyāḥ kva vaḥ gāvaḥ na raṇyanti
column2: Where now? On what errand of yours are you going, in heaven, not on earth 1? Where are your cows sporting?

column1: kva vaḥ sumnā navyāṁsi marutaḥ kva suvitā kva viśvāni saubhagā
column2: Where are your newest favours 1, O Maruts? Where the blessings? Where all delights?

column1: yat yūyam pr̥śni mātaraḥ martāsaḥ syātana stotā vaḥ amr̥taḥ syāt
column2: If you, sons of Prisni, were mortals, and your praiser an immortal 1,—

column1: mā vaḥ mr̥gaḥ na yavase jaritā bhūt ajoṣyaḥ pathā yamasya gāt upa
column2: Then never 1 should your praiser be unwelcome, like a deer in pasture grass 2, nor should he go on the path of Yama 3.

column1: mo iti su ṇaḥ parāparā niḥ r̥tiḥ duḥ hanā vadhīt padīṣṭa tr̥ṣṇayā saha
column2: Let not one sin 1 after another, difficult to be conquered, overcome us; may it depart 2 together with greed.

column1: satyam tveṣāḥ ama vantaḥ dhanvam cit ā rudriyāsaḥ miham kr̥ṇvanti avātām
column2: Truly they are terrible and powerful; even to the desert the Rudriyas bring rain that is never dried up 1.

column1: vāśrāiva vi dyut mimāti vatsam na mātā siṣakti yat eṣām vr̥ṣṭiḥ asarji
column2: The lightning lows like a cow, it follows as a mother follows after her young, when the shower (of the Maruts) has been let loose 1.

column1: divā cit tamaḥ kr̥ṇvanti parjanyena uda vāhena yat pr̥thivīm vi undanti
column2: Even by day the Maruts create darkness with the water-bearing cloud 1, when they drench the earth.

column1: adha svanāt marutām viśvam ā sadma pārthivam arejanta pra mānuṣāḥ
column2: Then from the shouting of the Maruts over the whole space of the earth 1, men reeled forward.

column1: marutaḥ vīl̥upāṇi bhiḥ citrāḥ rodhasvatīḥ anu yāta īm akhidrayāma bhiḥ
column2: Maruts on your strong-hoofed never-wearying 3 steeds 1 go after those bright ones (the clouds), which are still locked up 2.

column1: sthirāḥ vaḥ santu nemayaḥ rathāḥ aśvāsaḥ eṣām su saṁskr̥tāḥ abhīśavaḥ
column2: May your fellies be strong, the chariots, and their horses, may your reins 1 be well-fashioned.

column1: accha vada tanā girā jarāyai brahmaṇaḥ patim agnim mitram na darśatam
column2: Speak forth for ever with thy voice to praise the Lord of prayer 1, Agni, who is like a friend 2, the bright one.

column1: mimīhi ślokam āsye parjanyaḥ iva tatanaḥ gāya gāyatram ukthyam
column2: Fashion a hymn in thy mouth! Expand like the cloud 1! Sing a song of praise.

column1: vandasva mārutam gaṇam tveṣam panasyum arkiṇam asme iti vr̥ddhāḥ asan iha
column2: Worship the host of the Maruts, the terrible. . the glorious, the musical 1. May they be magnified here among us 2.

column1: pra yat itthā parāvataḥ śociḥ na mānam asyatha kasya kratvā marutaḥ kasya varpasā kam yātha kam ha dhūtayaḥ
column2: When you thus from afar cast forwards your measure 1, like a blast of fire, through whose wisdom is it, through whose design 2? To whom do you go, to whom, ye shakers (of the earth)?

column1: sthirā vaḥ santu āyudhā parānude vīl̥u uta prati skabhe yuṣmākam astu taviṣī panīyasī mā martyasya māyinaḥ
column2: May your weapons be firm to attack, strong also to withstand. May yours be the more glorious power, nor that of the deceitful mortal.

column1: parā ha yat sthiram hatha naraḥ vartayatha guru vi yāthana vaninaḥ pr̥thivyāḥ vi āśāḥ parvatānām
column2: When you overthrow what is firm, O ye men, and whirl about what is heavy, you pass 1 through the trees of the earth, through the clefts of the rocks 2.

column1: nahi vaḥ śatruḥ vivide adhi dyavi na bhūmyām riśādasaḥ yuṣmākam astu taviṣī tanā yujā rudrāsaḥ nu cit ādhr̥ṣe
column2: No real foe of yours is known in heaven, nor on earth, ye devourers of foes! May power be yours, together with your race 1! O Rudras, can it be defied 2?

column1: pra vepayanti parvatān vi viñcanti vanaspatīn pro iti ārata marutaḥ durmadāḥ iva devāsaḥ sarvayā viśā
column2: They make the rocks tremble, they tear asunder the kings of the forest 1. Come on, Maruts, like madmen, ye gods, with your whole tribe.

column1: upo iti ratheṣu pr̥ṣatīḥ ayugdhvam praṣṭiḥ vahati rohitaḥ ā vaḥ yāmāya pr̥thivī cit aśrot abībhayanta mānuṣāḥ
column2: You have harnessed the spotted deer to your chariots, a red one draws as leader 1; even the earth listened 2 at your approach, and men were frightened.

column1: ā vaḥ makṣu tanāya kam rudrāḥ avaḥ vr̥ṇīmahe ganta nūnam naḥ avas yathā purā itthā kaṇvāya bibhyuṣe
column2: O Rudras, we quickly desire your help for our race. Come now to us with help, as of yore; thus now for the sake of the frightened Kanva 1.

column1: yuṣmāiṣitaḥ marutaḥ martya iṣitaḥ ā yaḥ naḥ abhvaḥ īṣate vi tam yuyota śavasā vi ojasā vi yuṣmākābhiḥ ūti bhiḥ
column2: Whatever fiend, roused by you or roused by men, attacks us, deprive him of power, of strength, and of your favours 1.

column1: asāmi hi pra yajyavaḥ kaṇvam dr̥ pra cetasaḥ asāmi bhiḥ marutaḥ ā naḥ ūti bhiḥ ganta vr̥ṣṭim na vi dyutaḥ
column2: For you, chasing and wise Maruts, have wholly protected 1 Kanva. Come to us, Maruts, with your whole favours, as lightnings 2 (go in quest of) the rain.

column1: asāmi ojaḥ bibhr̥tha su dānavaḥ asāmi dhūtayaḥ śavaḥ r̥ṣi dviṣe marutaḥ pari manyave iṣum na sr̥jata dviṣam
column2: Bounteous givers, you carry whole strength, whole power, ye shakers (of the world). Send, O Maruts, against the wrathful enemy of the poets an enemy, like an arrow 1.

column1: kat rudrāya pra cetase mīl̥huḥ tamāya tavyase vocema śam tamam hr̥de
column2: What could we say to Rudra, the wise, the most liberal, the most powerful, that is most welcome to his heart,—

column1: yathā naḥ aditiḥ karat paśve nr̥ bhyaḥ yathā gave yathā tokāya rudriyam
column2: So that Aditi 1 may bring Rudra's healing to the cattle, to men, to cow, and kith,

column1: yathā naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ yathā rudraḥ ciketati yathā viśve sa joṣasaḥ
column2: So that Mitra, that Varuna, that Rudra hear us, and all the united Maruts 1.

column1: gātha patim medha patim rudram jalāṣa bheṣajam tat śam yoḥ sumnam īmahe
column2: We implore Rudra, the lord of songs, the lord of animal sacrifices 1, the possessor of healing medicines 2, for health, wealth 3, and his favour.

column1: yaḥ śukraḥ iva sūryaḥ hiraṇyam iva rocate śreṣṭhaḥ devānām vasuḥ
column2: He who shines like the bright sun, and like gold, who is the best Vasu among the gods,

column1: śan naḥ karati arvate su gam meṣāya meṣye nr̥ bhyaḥ nāri bhyaḥ gave
column2: May he bring health to our horse, welfare to ram and ewe, to men, to women, and to the cow!

column1: asme iti soma śriyam adhi ni dhehi śatasya nr̥ṇām mahi śravaḥ tuvi nr̥mṇam
column2: Bestow on us, O Soma, the happiness of a hundred men, great glory of strong manhood 1;

column1: mā naḥ soma paribādhaḥ mā arātayaḥ juhuranta ā naḥ indo iti vāje bhaja
column2: O Soma 1, let not those who harass and injure overthrow us; O Indu, help us to booty!

column1: yāḥ te pra jāḥ amr̥tasya parasmin dhāman r̥tasya mūrdhā nābhā soma venaḥ ābhūṣantīḥ soma vedaḥ
column2: Whatever beings are thine, the immortal, in the highest place of the law, on its summit 1, in its centre, O Soma, cherish them, remember them who honour thee.

column1: vr̥ṣṇe śardhāya su makhāya vedhase nodhaḥ su vr̥ktim pra bhara marut bhyaḥ apaḥ na dhīraḥ manasā su hastyaḥ giraḥ sam añje vidatheṣu ābhuvaḥ
column2: For the manly host, the joyful, the wise, for the Maruts bring thou, O Nodhas 1, a pure offering 2. I prepare songs, like as a handy priest 3, wise in his mind, prepares the water, mighty at sacrifices.

column1: te jajñire divaḥ r̥ṣvāsaḥ ukṣaṇaḥ rudrasya maryā asurāḥ arepasaḥ pāvakāsaḥ śucayaḥ sūryāḥ iva satvānaḥ na drapsinaḥ ghora varpasaḥ
column2: They are born, the tall bulls of Dyu 1 (heaven), the manly youths 2 of Rudra, the divine, the blameless, pure, and bright like suns; scattering raindrops, full of terrible designs, like giants 3.

column1: yuvānaḥ rudrāḥ ajarāḥ abhok hanaḥ vavakṣuḥ adhri gāvaḥ parvatāḥ iva dr̥l̥hā cit viśvā bhuvanāni pārthivā pra cyāvayanti divyāni majmanā
column2: The youthful Rudras, they who never grow old, the slayers of the demon 1, have grown irresistible like mountains. They throw down with their strength all beings, even the strongest, on earth and in heaven.

column1: citraiḥ añji bhiḥ vapuṣe vi añjate vakṣaḥ su rukmān adhi yetire śubhe aṁseṣu eṣām ni mimr̥kṣuḥ r̥ṣṭayaḥ sākam jajñire svadhayā divaḥ naraḥ
column2: They deck themselves with glittering ornaments 1 for a marvellous show; on their chests they fastened gold (chains) for beauty 2; the spears on their shoulders pound to pieces 3; they were born together by themselves 4, the men of Dyu.

column1: īśāna kr̥taḥ dhunayaḥ riśādasaḥ vātān vi dyutaḥ taviṣībhiḥ akrata duhanti ūdhaḥ divyāni dhūtayaḥ bhūmim pinvanti payasā pari jrayaḥ
column2: They who confer power 1, the roarers 2, the devourers of foes, they made winds and lightnings by their powers. The shakers milk the heavenly udders (clouds), they sprinkle the earth all round with milk (rain).

column1: pinvanti apaḥ marutaḥ su dānavaḥ payaḥ ghr̥ta vat vidatheṣu ābhuvaḥ atyam na mihe vi nayanti vājinam utsam duhanti stanayantam akṣitam
column2: The bounteous 1 Maruts pour forth 2 water, mighty at sacrifices, the fat milk (of the clouds). They seem to lead 3 about the powerful horse, the cloud, to make it rain; they milk the thundering, unceasing spring 4

column1: mahiṣāsaḥ māyinaḥ citra bhānavaḥ girayaḥ na sva tavasaḥ raghu syadaḥ mr̥gāḥ iva hastinaḥ svādatha vanā yat āruṇīṣu taviṣīḥ ayugdhvam
column2: Mighty they are, powerful, of beautiful splendour, strong in themselves 1 like mountains, (yet) swiftly gliding along;—you chew up forests, like wild elephants 2, when you have assumed your powers among the red flames 3.

column1: siṁhāḥ iva nānadati pra cetasaḥ piśāḥ iva su piśaḥ viśva vedasaḥ kṣapaḥ jinvantaḥ pr̥ṣatībhiḥ r̥ṣṭi bhiḥ sam it sa bādhaḥ śavasā ahi manyavaḥ
column2: Like lions they roar, the wise Maruts, they are handsome like gazelles 1, the all-knowing. By night 2 with their spotted deer (rain-clouds) and with their spears (lightnings) they rouse the companions together, they whose ire through strength is like the ire of serpents.

column1: rodasī iti ā vadata gaṇa śriyaḥ nr̥ sācaḥ śūrāḥ śavasā ahi manyavaḥ ā vandhureṣu amatiḥ na darśatā vidyut na tasthau marutaḥ ratheṣu vaḥ
column2: You who march in companies, the friends of man, heroes, whose ire through strength is like the ire of serpents 1, salute heaven and earth 2! On the seats on your chariots, O Maruts, the lightning stands, visible like light 3.

column1: viśva vedasaḥ rayi bhiḥ sam okasaḥ sam miślāsaḥ taviṣībhiḥ vi rapśinaḥ astāraḥ iṣum dadhire gabhastyoḥ ananta śuṣmāḥ vr̥ṣa khādayaḥ naraḥ
column2: All-knowing, surrounded with wealth, endowed with powers, singers 1, men of endless prowess armed with strong rings 2, they, the archers, have taken the arrow in their fists.

column1: hiraṇyayebhiḥ pavi bhiḥ payaḥ vr̥dhaḥ ut jighnante āpathyaḥ na parvatān makhāḥ ayāsaḥ sva sr̥taḥ dhruva cyutaḥ dudhra kr̥taḥ marutaḥ bhrājat r̥ṣṭayaḥ
column2: The Maruts who with the golden tires of their wheels increase the rain, stir up the clouds like wanderers on the road. They are brisk, indefatigable 1, they move by themselves; they throw down what is firm, the Maruts with their brilliant spears make (everything) to reel 2.

column1: ghr̥ṣum pāvakam vaninam vi carṣaṇim rudrasya sūnum havasā gr̥ṇīmas i rajaḥ turam tavasam mārutam gaṇam r̥jīṣiṇam vr̥ṣaṇam saścata śriye
column2: We invoke with prayer 1 the offspring of Rudra, the brisk, the pure, the worshipful 2, the active. Cling 3 for happiness-sake to the strong company of the Maruts, the chasers of the sky 4, the powerful, the impetuous 5.

column1: pra nu saḥ martaḥ śavasā janān ati tasthau vaḥ ūtī marutaḥ yam āvata arvat bhiḥ vājam bharate dhanā nr̥ bhiḥ āpr̥cchyam kratum ā kṣeti puṣyati
column2: The mortal whom ye, Maruts, protected, he indeed surpasses people in strength through your protection. He carries off booty with his horses, treasures with his men; he acquires honourable 1 wisdom, and he prospers 2.

column1: carkr̥tyam marutaḥ pr̥t su dustaram dyu mantam śuṣmam maghavat su dhattana dhana spr̥tam ukthyam viśva carṣaṇim tokam puṣyema tanayam śatam himāḥ
column2: Give, O Maruts, to our lords strength glorious, invincible in battle, brilliant, wealth-acquiring, praiseworthy, known to all men 1. Let us foster our kith and kin during a hundred winters.

column1: nu sthiram marutaḥ vīra vantam r̥ti saham rayim asmāsu dhatta sahasriṇam śatinam śūśu vāṁsam prātaḥ makṣu dhiyāvasuḥ jagamyāt
column2: Will 1 you then, O Maruts, grant unto us wealth, durable, rich in men, defying all onslaughts 2?—wealth a hundred and a thousand-fold, always increasing?—May he who is rich in prayers 3 (the host of the Maruts) come early and soon!

column1: pra ye śumbhante janayaḥ na saptayaḥ yāman rudrasya sūnavaḥ su daṁsasaḥ rodasī hi marutaḥ cakrire vr̥dhe madanti vīrāḥ vidatheṣu ghr̥ṣvayaḥ
column2: Those who glance forth like wives and yoke-fellows 1, the powerful sons of Rudra on their way, they, the Maruts, have indeed made heaven and earth to grow 2; they, the strong and wild, delight in the sacrifices.

column1: te ukṣitāsaḥ mahimānam āśata divi rudrāsaḥ adhi cakrire sadaḥ arcantaḥ arkam janayantaḥ indriyam adhi śriyaḥ dadhire pr̥śni mātaraḥ
column2: When grown up 1, they attained to greatness; the Rudras have established their seat in the sky. While singing their song and increasing their vigour, the sons of Prisni have clothed themselves in beauty 2.

column1: go mātaraḥ yat śubhayante añji bhiḥ tanūṣu śubhrāḥ dadhire virukmataḥ bādhante viśvam abhi mātinam apa vartmāni eṣām anu rīyate ghr̥tam
column2: When these sons of the cow (Prisni) 1 adorn themselves with glittering ornaments, the brilliant 2 ones put bright weapons on their bodies 3. They drive away every adversary 4; fatness (rain) streams along their paths;—

column1: vi ye bhrājante su makhāsaḥ r̥ṣṭi bhiḥ pra cyavayantaḥ acyutā cit ojasā manaḥ juvaḥ yat marutaḥ ratheṣu ā vr̥ṣa vrātāsaḥ pr̥ṣatīḥ ayugdhvam
column2: When you 1, the powerful, who shine with your spears, shaking even what is unshakable by strength,—when you, O Maruts, the manly hosts 2, had yoked the spotted deer, swift as thought, to your chariots;—

column1: pra yat ratheṣu pr̥ṣatīḥ ayugdhvam vāje adrim marutaḥ raṁhayantaḥ uta aruṣasya vi syanti dhārāḥ carma iva uda bhiḥ vi undanti bhūma
column2: When you had yoked the spotted deer before your chariots, hurling 1 the stone (thunderbolt) in the fight, then the streams of the red-(horse) 2 rush forth: like a skin 3 with water they water the earth.

column1: ā vaḥ vahantu saptayaḥ raghu syadaḥ raghu patvānaḥ pra jigāta bāhu bhiḥ sīdatā barhiḥ uru vaḥ sadaḥ kr̥tam mādayadhvam marutaḥ madhvaḥ andhasaḥ
column2: May the swiftly-gliding, swift-winged horses carry you hither! Come forth with your arms 1! Sit down on the grass-pile; a wide seat has been made for you. Rejoice, O Maruts, in the sweet food 2.

column1: te avardhanta sva tavasaḥ mahi tvanā ā nākam tasthuḥ uru cakrire sadaḥ viṣṇuḥ yat ha āvat vr̥ṣaṇam mada cyutam vayaḥ na sdan adhi barhiṣi priye
column2: Strong in themselves, they grew 1 with might; they stepped to the firmament, they made their seat wide. When Vishnu 2 saved the enrapturing Soma, the Maruts sat down like birds on their beloved altar.

column1: śūrāḥ iva it yuyudhayah na jagmayaḥ śravasyavaḥ na pr̥tanāsu yetire bhayante viśvā bhuvanā marut bhyaḥ rājānaḥ iva tveṣa sandr̥śaḥ naraḥ
column2: Like 1 heroes indeed thirsting for fight they rush about; like combatants eager for glory they have striven in battles. All beings are afraid of the Maruts; they are men terrible to behold, like kings.

column1: tvaṣṭā yat vajram su kr̥tam hiraṇyayam sahasra bhr̥ṣṭim su apāḥ avartayat dhatte indraḥ nari apāṁsi kartave ahan vr̥tram niḥ apām aubjat arṇavam
column2: When the clever Tvashtar 1 had turned the well-made, golden, thousand-edged thunderbolt, Indra takes it to perform his manly deeds 2; he slew Vritra, he forced out the stream of water.

column1: ūrdhvam nunudre avatam te ojasā dādr̥hāṇam cit bibhiduḥ vi parvatam dhamantaḥ vāṇam marutaḥ su dānavah made somasya raṇyāni cakrire
column2: By their power they pushed the well 1 aloft, they clove asunder the rock (cloud), however strong. Blowing forth their voice 2 the bounteous Maruts performed, while drunk of Soma, their glorious deeds.

column1: jihmam nunudre avatam tayā diśā asiñcan utsam gotamāya tr̥ṣṇa je ā gacchanti īm avasā citra bhānavaḥ kāmam viprasya tarpayanta dhāma bhiḥ
column2: They pushed the well (cloud) athwart this way, they poured out the spring to the thirsty Gotama. The Maruts with beautiful splendour approach him with help, they in their own ways satisfied the desire of the sage.

column1: yā vaḥ śarma śaśamānāya santi tri dhātūni dāśuṣe yacchata adhi asmabhyam tāni marutaḥ vi yanta rayim naḥ dhatta vr̥ṣaṇaḥ su vīram
column2: The shelters which you have for him who praises you, grant them threefold 1 to the man who gives! Extend the same to us, O Maruts! Give us, ye heroes 2, wealth with valiant offspring!

column1: marutaḥ yasya hi kṣaye pātha divaḥ vi mahasaḥ saḥ su gopātamaḥ janaḥ
column2: O Maruts, that man in whose dwelling you drink (the Soma), ye mighty (sons) of heaven, he indeed has the best guardians 1.

column1: yajñaiḥ vā yajña vāhasaḥ viprasya vā matīnām marutaḥ śr̥ṇuta havam
column2: You who are propitiated 1 either by sacrifices or from the prayers of the sage, hear the call, O Maruts!

column1: uta vā yasya vājinaḥ anu vipram atakṣata saḥ gantā go mati vraje
column2: Aye, the powerful man to whom you have granted a sage, he will live in a stable rich in cattle 1.

column1: asya vīrasya barhiṣi sutaḥ somaḥ diviṣṭiṣu uktham madaḥ ca śasyate
column2: On the altar of this strong man (here) 1 Soma is poured out in daily sacrifices; praise and joy are sung.

column1: asya śroṣantu ā bhuvaḥ viśvāḥ yaḥ carṣaṇīḥ abhi sūram cit sasruṣīḥ iṣaḥ
column2: To him let the mighty 1 Maruts listen, to him who surpasses all men, as the flowing rain-clouds 2 pass over the sun.

column1: pūrvībhiḥ hi dadāśima śarat bhiḥ marutaḥ vayam avaḥ bhiḥ carṣaṇīnām
column2: For we, O Maruts, have sacrificed at many harvests, through the mercies 1 of the swift gods (the storm-gods).

column1: su bhagaḥ saḥ pra yajyavaḥ marutaḥ astu martyaḥ yasya prayāṁsi parṣatha
column2: May that mortal be blessed, O chasing Maruts, whose offerings you carry off 1.

column1: śaśamānasya vā naraḥ svedasya satya śavasaḥ vida kāmasya venataḥ
column2: You take notice either of the sweat of him who praises you, ye men of true strength, or of the desire of the suppliant 1.

column1: yūyam tat satya śavasaḥ āviḥ karta mahi tvanā vidhyata vi dyutā rakṣaḥ
column2: O ye of true strength, make this manifest with might! strike the fiend 1 with your lightning!

column1: gūhata guhyam tamaḥ vi yāta viśvam atriṇam jyotiḥ karta yat uśmas i
column2: Hide the hideous darkness, destroy 1 every tusky 2 fiend. Make the light which we long for!

column1: pra tvakṣasaḥ pra tavasaḥ vi rapśinaḥ anānatāḥ avithurāḥ r̥jīṣ iṇaḥ juṣṭa tamāsaḥ nr̥ tamāsaḥ añji bhiḥ vi ānajre ke cit usrāivastr̥bhiḥ
column2: Endowed with exceeding vigour and power, the singers, the never flinching, the immovable, the impetuous, the most beloved and most manly, have decked themselves with their glittering ornaments, a few only 1, like the heavens with the stars,

column1: upa hvareṣu yat acidhvam yayim vayaḥ iva marutaḥ kena cit pathā ścotanti kośāḥ upa vaḥ ratheṣu ā ghr̥tam ukṣata madhu varṇam arcate
column2: When you have seen your way through the clefts, like birds, O Maruts, on whatever road it be 1, then the casks (clouds) on your chariots trickle everywhere, and you pour out the honey-like fatness (the rain) for him who praises you.

column1: pra eṣām ajmeṣu vithurāiva rejate bhūmiḥ yāmeṣu yat ha yuñjate śubhe te krīl̥ayaḥ dhunayaḥ bhrājat r̥ṣṭayaḥ svayam mahi tvam panayanta dhūtayaḥ
column2: At their racings the earth shakes, as if broken 1, when on the (heavenly) paths they harness (their deer) for victory 2. They the sportive, the roaring, with bright spears, the shakers (of the clouds) have themselves glorified their greatness.

column1: saḥ hi sva sr̥t pr̥ṣat aśvaḥ yuvā gaṇaḥ ayā īśānaḥ taviṣī bhiḥ āv r̥taḥ asi satyaḥ r̥ṇa yāvā anedyaḥ asyāḥ dhiyaḥ pra avitā atha vr̥ṣā gaṇaḥ
column2: That youthful company (of the Maruts), with their spotted horses 1, moves by itself; hence 2 it exercises lordship, invested with powers. Thou indeed art true, thou searchest out sin 3, thou art without blemish. Therefore the manly host will help this prayer.

column1: pituḥ pratnasya janmanā vadāmasi somasya jihvā pra jigāti cakṣasā yat īm indram śami r̥kvāṇaḥ āśata āt it nāmāni yajñiyāni dadhire
column2: We speak after the kind of our old father, our tongue goes forth at the sight 1 of the Soma: when the singers (the Maruts) had joined Indra in deed 2, then only they took their holy names;—

column1: śriyase kam bhānu bhiḥ sam mimikṣire te raśmi bhiḥ te r̥kva bhiḥ su khādayaḥ te vāśī mantaḥ iṣmiṇaḥ abhīravaḥ vidre priyasya mārutasya dhāmnaḥ
column2: These Maruts, armed with beautiful rings, obtained splendours for their glory 1, they obtained 2 rays, and men to celebrate them; nay, armed with daggers, speeding along, and fearless, they found the beloved domain of the Maruts 3.

column1: imāḥ rudrāya tavase kapardine kṣayat vīrāya pra bharāmahe matīḥ yathā śam asat dvi pade catuḥ pade viśvam puṣṭam grāme asmin anāturam
column2: We offer these prayers 1 to Rudra, the strong, whose hair is braided 2, who rules over heroes 3, that he may be a blessing to man and beast, that everything in this our village may be prosperous and free from disease.

column1: mr̥l̥a naḥ rudra uta naḥ mayaḥ kr̥dhi kṣayat vīrāya namasā vidhema te yat śam ca yoḥ ca manuḥ āyeje pitā tat aśyāma tava rudra pra nītiṣu
column2: Be gracious to us, O Rudra, and give us joy, and we shall honour thee, the ruler of heroes, with worship. What health and wealth father Manu acquired by his sacrifices, may we obtain the same, O Rudra, under thy guidance.

column1: aśyāma te su matim deva yajyayā kṣayat vīrasya tava rudra mīḍhavaḥ sumna yan it viśaḥ asmākam ā cara ariṣṭa vīrāḥ juhavāma te haviḥ
column2: O bounteous Rudra, may we by sacrifice obtain the goodwill of thee, the ruler of heroes; come to our clans, well-disposed, and, with unharmed men, we shall offer our libation to thee.

column1: tveṣam vayam rudram yajña sādham vaṅkum kavim avase ni hvayāmahe āre asmat daivyam hel̥aḥ asyatu su matim it vayam asya ā vr̥ṇīmahe
column2: We call down for our help the fierce Rudra, who fulfils our sacrifice, the swift, the wise; may he drive far away from us the anger of the gods; we desire his goodwill only.

column1: divaḥ varāham aruṣam kapardinam tveṣam rūpam namasā ni hvayāmahe haste bibhrat bheṣajā vāryāṇi śarma varma chardiḥ asmabhyam yaṁsat
column2: We call down with worship the red boar of the sky, the god with braided hair, the blazing form; may he who carries in his hand the best medicines grant us protection, shield, and shelter!

column1: idam pitre marutām ucyate vacaḥ svādoḥ svādīyaḥ rudrāya vardhanam rāsva ca naḥ amr̥ta marta bhojanam tmane tokāya tanayāya mr̥l̥a
column2: This speech is spoken for the father of the Maruts, sweeter than sweet, a joy 1 to Rudra; grant to us also, O immortal, the food of mortals, be gracious to us and to our kith and kin!

column1: mā naḥ mahāntam uta mā naḥ arbhakam mā naḥ ukṣantam uta mā naḥ ukṣitam mā naḥ vadhīḥ pitaram mā uta mātaram mā naḥ priyāḥ tanvaḥ rudra ririṣaḥ
column2: Do not slay our great or our small ones, our growing or our grown ones, our father or our mother and do not hurt our own 1 bodies, O Rudra!

column1: mā naḥ toke tanaye mā naḥ āyau mā naḥ goṣu mā naḥ aśveṣu ririṣaḥ vīrān mā naḥ rudra bhāmitaḥ vadhīḥ haviṣmantaḥ sadam it tvā havāmahe
column2: O Rudra, hurt us not in our kith and kin, nor in our own life, not in our cows, nor in our horses! Do not slay our men in thy wrath: carrying libations, we call on thee always.

column1: upa te stomān paśupāḥ iva ā akaram rāsva pitaḥ marutām sumnam asme iti bhadrā hi te su matiḥ mr̥l̥ayat tamā atha vayam ava it te vr̥ṇīmahe
column2: Like a shepherd 1, I have driven these praises near to thee; O father of the Maruts, grant us thy favour! For thy goodwill is auspicious, and most gracious, hence we desire thy protection alone.

column1: āre te go ghnam uta puruṣa ghnam kṣayat vīra sumnam asme iti te astu mr̥l̥a ca naḥ adhi ca brūhi deva adha ca naḥ śarma yaccha dvi barhāḥ
column2: Let thy cow-slaying and thy man-slaying be far away 1, and let thy favour be with us, O ruler of heroes! Be gracious to us, and bless us, O god, and then give us twofold protection 2.

column1: avocāma namaḥ asmai avasyavaḥ śr̥ṇotu naḥ havam rudraḥ marutvān tat naḥ mitraḥ varuṇaḥ mamahantām aditiḥ sindhuḥ pr̥thivī uta dyauḥ
column2: We have uttered our supplication to him, desiring his help; may Rudra with the Maruts hear our call. May Mitra, Varuna, Aditi, the River, Earth, and the Sky grant us this!

column1: ā tvā juvaḥ rarahāṇāḥ abhi prayaḥ vāyo iti vahantu iha pūrva pītaye somasya ūrdhvā te anu sūnr̥tā manaḥ tiṣṭhatu jānatī niyutvatā rathena ā yāhi dāvane vāyoiti makhasya dāvane
column2: O Vâyu, may the quick racers bring thee towards the offerings, to the early drink 1 here, to the early drink of Soma! May Sûnritâ 2 (the Dawn) stand erect, approving thy mind! Come near on thy harnessed chariot to share, O Vâyu, to share in the sacrifice 3!

column1: mandantu tvā mandinaḥ vāyo iti indavaḥ asmat krāṇāsaḥ su kr̥tāḥ abhi dyavaḥ go bhiḥ krāṇāḥ abhi dyavaḥ yat ha krāṇāḥ iradhyai dakṣam sacante ūtayaḥ sadhrīcīnāḥ n i yutaḥ dāvane dhiyaḥ upa bruvate īm dhiyaḥ
column2: May the delightful drops of Soma delight thee, the drops made by us, well-made, and heaven-directed, yes, made with milk, and heaven-directed. When his performed aids assume strength for achievement, cur prayers implore the assembled steeds for gifts, yes, the prayers implore them.

column1: vāyuḥ yuṅkte rohitā vāyuḥ aruṇā vāyuḥ rathe ajirā dhuri vol̥have vahiṣṭhā dhuri vol̥have pra bodhaya puram dhim jāraḥ ā sasatīm iva pra cakṣaya rodasī iti vāsaya uṣasaḥ śravase vāsaya uṣasaḥ
column2: Vâyu yokes the two ruddy, Vâyu yokes the two red horses, Vâyu yokes to the chariot the two swift horses to draw in the yoke, the strongest to draw in the yoke. Awake Purandhi (the Morning) 1 as a lover wakes a sleeping maid, reveal heaven and earth, brighten the dawn, yes, for glory brighten the dawn.

column1: tubhyam uṣasaḥ śucayaḥ parāvati bhadrā vastrā tanvate dam su raśmi ṣu citrā navyeṣu raśmiṣu tubhyam dhenuḥ sabaḥ dughā viśvā vasūni dohate ajanayaḥ marutaḥ vakṣaṇābhyaḥ divaḥ ā vakṣaṇābhyaḥ
column2: For thee the bright dawns spread out in the distance beautiful garments, in their houses 1, in their rays, beautiful in their new rays. To thee the juice-yielding 2 cow pours out all treasures. Thou hast brought forth the Maruts from the flanks 3, yes, from the flanks of heaven.

column1: tubhyam śukrāsa śucayaḥ turaṇyavaḥ madeṣu ugrāḥ iṣaṇanta bhurvaṇi apām iṣanta bhurvaṇi tvām tsārī dasamānaḥ bhagam īṭe takva vīye tvam viśvasmāt bhuvanāt pāsi dharmaṇā asuryāt pāsi dharmaṇā
column2: For thee the white, bright, rushing Somas, strong in raptures, have rushed to the whirl, they vhave rushed to the whirl of the waters. The tired hunter asks luck of thee in the chase 1; thou shieldest 2 by thy power from every being, yes, thou shieldest by thy power from powerful spirits 3.

column1: eṣaḥ vaḥ stomaḥ marutaḥ namasvān hr̥dā taṣṭaḥ manasā dhāyi devāḥ upa īm ā yāta manasā juṣāṇāḥ yūyam hi stha namasaḥ it vr̥dhāsaḥ
column2: This reverent praise of yours, O Maruts, fashioned in the heart, has been offered by the mind 1, O gods! Come to it, pleased in your mind, for you give increase to (our) worship 2.

column1: stutāsaḥ naḥ marutaḥ mr̥l̥ayantu uta stutaḥ magha vā śam bhaviṣṭhaḥ ūrdhvā naḥ santu komyā vanāni ahāni viśvā marutaḥ jigīṣā
column2: May the Maruts when they have been praised be gracious to us, and likewise Maghavat (Indra), the best giver of happiness, when he has been praised. May our trees (our lances) 1 through our valour stand always erect, O Maruts!

column1: asmāt aham taviṣāt īṣamāṇaḥ indrāt bhiyā marutaḥ rejamānaḥ yuṣmabhyam havyā ni śitāni āsan tāni āre cakr̥ma mr̥l̥ata naḥ
column2: I am afraid of this powerful one, and trembling in fear of Indra. For you the offerings were prepared,—we have now put them away, forgive us!

column1: yena mānāsaḥ citayante usrāḥ vi uṣṭiṣu śavasā śaśvatīnām saḥ naḥ marut bhiḥ vr̥ṣabha śravaḥ dhāḥ ugraḥ ugrebhiḥ sthaviraḥ sahaḥ dāḥ
column2: Thou through whom the Mânas 1 see the mornings, whenever the eternal dawns flash forth with power 2, O Indra, O strong hero, grant thou glory to us with the Maruts, terrible with the terrible ones, strong and a giver of victory.

column1: tvam pāhi indra sahīyasaḥ nr̥r̥n bhava marut bhiḥ avayāta hel̥āḥ su praketebhiḥ sasahiḥ dadhānaḥ vidyāma iṣam vr̥janam jīra dānum
column2: O Indra, protect thou these bravest of men 1 (the Maruts), let thy anger be turned away 2 from the Maruts, for thou hast become 3 victorious together with those brilliant heroes. May we have an invigorating autumn, with quickening rain!

column1: citraḥ vaḥ astu yāmaḥ citraḥ ūtī su dānavaḥ marutaḥ ahi bhānavaḥ
column2: May your march be brilliant, brilliant through your protection, O Maruts, you bounteous givers, shining like snakes!

column1: āre sā vaḥ su dānavaḥ marutaḥ r̥ñjatī śaruḥ āre aśmā yam asyatha
column2: May that straightforward shaft of yours, O Maruts, bounteous givers, be far from us, and far the stone which you hurl!

column1: tr̥ṇa skandasya nu viśaḥ pari vr̥ṅkta su dānavaḥ ūrdhvān naḥ katar jīvase
column2: Spare, O bounteous givers, the people of Trinaskanda, lift us up that we may live!

column1: ā te pitaḥ marutām sumnam etu mā naḥ sūryasya sam dr̥śaḥ yuyothāḥ abhi naḥ vīraḥ arvati kṣameta pra jāyemahi rudra pra jābhiḥ
column2: O father of the Maruts, let thy favour come near, and do not deprive us of the sight of the sun; may the hero (Rudra) be gracious to our horse 1, and may we increase in offspring, O Rudra!

column1: tvādattebhiḥ rudra śam tamebhiḥ śatam himāḥ aśīya bheṣajebhiḥ vi asmat dveṣaḥ vi taram vi aṁhaḥ vi amīvāḥ cātayasva viṣūcīḥ
column2: May I attain to a hundred winters through the most blissful medicines which thou hast given! Put away far 1 from us all hatred, put away anguish, put away sicknesses in all directions!

column1: śreṣṭhaḥ jātasya rudra śriyā asi tavaḥ tamaḥ tavasām vajrabāho itivajra bāho parṣi naḥ pāram aṁhasaḥ svasti viśvāḥ abhi itīḥ rapasaḥ yuyodhi
column2: In beauty thou art the most beautiful of all that exists, O Rudra, the strongest of the strong, thou wielder of the thunderbolt! Carry us happily to the other shore of our anguish, and ward off all assaults of mischief 1.

column1: mā tvā rudra cukrudhāma namaḥ bhiḥ mā duḥ stutī vr̥ṣabha mā sa hūtī ut naḥ vīrān arpaya bheṣajebhiḥ bhiṣak tamam tvā bhiṣajām śr̥ṇomi
column2: Let us not incense thee, O Rudra, by our worship, not by bad praise, O hero, and not by divided praise! Raise up our men by thy medicines, for I hear thou art the best of all physicians.

column1: havīma bhiḥ havate yaḥ haviḥ bhiḥ ava stomebhiḥ rudram diṣīya r̥dūdaraḥ su havaḥ mā naḥ asyai babhruḥ su śipraḥ rīradhat manāyai
column2: He who is invoked 1 by invocations and libations, may I pay off 2 that Rudra with my hymns of praise. Let not him who is kind-hearted 3, who readily hears our call, the tawny, with beautiful cheeks, deliver us to this wrath!

column1: ut mā mamanda vr̥ṣabhaḥ marutvān tvakṣīyasā vayasā nādhamānam ghr̥ṇi iva chāyām arapāḥ aśīya vivāseyam rudrasya sumnam
column2: The manly hero with the Maruts has gladdened me, the suppliant, with more vigorous health. May I without mischief find shade, as if from sunshine 1, may I gain the favour of Rudra!

column1: kva syaḥ te rudra mr̥l̥ayākuḥ hastaḥ yaḥ asti bheṣajaḥ jalāṣaḥ apa bhartā rapasaḥ daivyasya abhi nu mā vr̥ṣabha cakṣamīthāḥ
column2: O Rudra, where is thy softly stroking hand which cures and relieves 1? Thou, the remover of all heaven-sent mischief, wilt thou, O strong hero, bear with me?

column1: pra babhrave vr̥ṣabhāya śvitīce mahaḥ mahīm su stutim īrayāmi namasya kalmalīkinam namaḥ bhiḥ gr̥ṇīmasi tveṣam rudrasya nāma
column2: I send forth a great, great hymn of praise to the bright tawny bull. Let me reverence 1 the fiery god 2 with prostrations; we celebrate the flaring name 3 of Rudra.

column1: sthirebhiḥ aṅgaiḥ puru rūpaḥ ugraḥ babhruḥ śukrebhiḥ pipiśe hiraṇyaiḥ īśānāt asya bhuvanasya bhūreḥ na vai oṁ iti yoṣat rudrāt asuryam
column2: He, the fierce god, with strong limbs, assuming many forms, the tawny Rudra, decked himself with brilliant golden ornaments. From Rudra, who is lord of this wide world, divine power 1 will never depart.

column1: arhan bibharṣi sāyakāni dhanva arhan niṣkam yajatam viśva rūpam arhan idam dayase viśvam abhvam na vai ojīyaḥ rudra tvat asti
column2: Worthily thou bearest arrows and bow, worthily, O worshipful 1, the golden, variegated chain; worthily thou cuttest every fiend 2 here to pieces, for there is nothing indeed stronger than thou, O Rudra.

column1: stuhi śrutam garta sadam yuvānam mr̥gam na bhīmam upa hatnum ugram mr̥l̥a jaritre rudra stavānaḥ anyam te asmat ni vapantu senāḥ
column2: Praise him, the famous, sitting in his chariot 1, the youthful, who is fierce and attacks like a terrible wild beast 2 (the lion). And when thou hast been praised, O Rudra, be gracious to him who magnifies thee, and let thy armies 3 mow down others than us!

column1: kumāraḥ cit pitaram vandamānam prati nanāma rudra upa yantam bhūreḥ dātāram sat patim gr̥ṇīṣe stutaḥ tvam bheṣajā rāsi asme iti
column2: O Rudra, a boy indeed makes obeisance to his father who comes to greet him 1: I praise the lord of brave men, the giver of many gifts, and thou, when thou hast been praised, wilt give us thy medicines.

column1: yā vaḥ bheṣajā marutaḥ śucīni yā śam tamā vr̥ṣaṇaḥ yā mayaḥ bhu yāni manuḥ avr̥ṇīta pitā naḥ tā śam ca yoḥ ca rudrasya vaśmi
column2: O Maruts, those pure medicines of yours, the most beneficent and delightful, O heroes, those which Manu 1, our father, chose, those I crave from Rudra, as health and wealth.

column1: pari naḥ hetiḥ rudrasya vr̥jyāḥ pari tveṣasya duḥ matiḥ mahī gāt ava sthirā maghavat bhyaḥ tanuṣva mīḍhavaḥ tokāya tanayāya mr̥l̥a
column2: May the weapon of Rudra avoid us 1, may the great anger of the flaring one pass us by. Unstring thy strong bows 2 for the sake of our liberal lords, O bounteous Rudra, be gracious to our kith and kin.

column1: eva babhro iti vr̥ṣabha cekitāna yathā deva na hr̥ṇīṣe na haṁsi havana śrut naḥ rudra iha bodhi br̥hat vadema vidathe su vīrāḥ
column2: Thus, O tawny and manly god, showing thyself 1, so as neither to be angry nor to kill, be mindful of our invocations 2, and, rich in brave sons, we shall magnify thee in the congregation.

column1: dhārāvarāḥ marutaḥ ghr̥ṣṇu ojasaḥ mr̥gāḥ na bhīmāḥ taviṣībhiḥ arcinaḥ agnayaḥ na śuśucānāḥ r̥jīṣiṇaḥ bhr̥mim dhamantaḥ apa gāḥ avr̥ṇvata
column2: The Maruts charged with rain 1, endowed with fierce force, terrible like wild beasts 2, blazing 3 in their strength 4, brilliant like fires, and impetuous 5, have uncovered the (rain-giving) cows by blowing away the cloud 6.

column1: dyāvaḥ na str̥ bhiḥ citayanta khādinaḥ vi abhriyāḥ na dyutayanta vr̥ṣṭayaḥ rudraḥ yat vaḥ marutaḥ rukma vakṣasaḥ vr̥ṣā ajani pr̥śnyāḥ śukre ūdhani
column2: The (Maruts) with their rings 1 appeared like the heavens with their stars 2, they shone wide like streams from clouds as soon as Rudra, the strong man, was born for you, O golden-breasted Maruts, in the bright lap of Prisni 3.

column1: ukṣante aśvān atyān iva ājiṣu nadasya karṇaiḥ turayante āśu bhiḥ h iraṇya śiprāḥ marutaḥ davidhvataḥ pr̥kṣam yātha pr̥ṣatībhiḥ sa manyavaḥ
column2: They wash 1 their horses like racers in the courses, they hasten with the points of the reed 2 on their quick steeds. O golden jawed 3 Maruts, violently shaking (your jaws), you go quick 4 with your spotted deer 5, being friends of one mind.

column1: pr̥kṣe tā viśvā bhuvanā vavakṣire mitrāya vā sadam ā jīra dānavaḥ pr̥ṣat aśvāsaḥ anavabhra rādhasaḥ r̥jipyāsaḥ na vayuneṣu dhūḥ sadaḥ
column2: Those Maruts have grown to feed 1 all these beings, or, it may be, (they have come) hither for the sake of a friend, they who always bring quickening rain. They have spotted horses, their bounties cannot be taken away, they are like headlong charioteers on their ways 2.

column1: indhanva bhiḥ dhenu bhiḥ rapśadūdha bhiḥ adhvasma bhiḥ pathi bhiḥ bhrājat r̥ṣṭayaḥ ā haṁsāsaḥ na svasarāṇi gantana madhoḥ madāya marutaḥ sa manyavaḥ
column2: O Maruts, wielding your brilliant spears, come hither on smooth 1 roads with your fiery 2 cows (clouds) whose udders are swelling; (come hither), being of one mind, like swans toward their nests, to enjoy the sweet offering.

column1: ā naḥ brahmāṇi marutaḥ sa manyavaḥ narām na śaṁsaḥ savanāni gantana aśvām iva pipyata dhenum ūdhani kartā dhiyam jaritre vāja peśasam
column2: O one-minded Maruts, come to our prayers, come to our libations like (Indra) praised by men 1![paragraph continues] Fulfil (our prayer) like the udder of a barren cow 2, and make the prayer glorious by booty to the singer.

column1: tam naḥ dāta marutaḥ vājinam rathe āpānam brahma citayat dive dive iṣam stotr̥ bhyaḥ vr̥janeṣu kārave sanim medhām ariṣṭam dustaram sahaḥ
column2: Grant us this strong horse for our chariot, a draught 1 that rouses our prayers, from day to day, food to the singers, and to the poet in our homesteads 2 luck 3, wisdom, inviolable and invincible strength.

column1: yat yuñjate marutaḥ rukma vakṣasaḥ aśvān ratheṣu bhage ā su dānavaḥ dhenuḥ na śiśve svasareṣu pinvate janāya rāta haviṣe mahīm iṣam
column2: When the gold-breasted Maruts harness the horses to their chariots, bounteous 1 in wealth, then it is as if a cow in the folds poured out 2 to her calf copious food, to every man who has offered libations.

column1: yaḥ naḥ marutaḥ vr̥ka tāti martyaḥ ripuḥ dadhe vasavaḥ rakṣata riṣaḥ vartayata vapuṣā cakriyā abhi tam ava rudrāḥ aśasaḥ hantana vadhariti
column2: Whatever mortal enemy may have placed us among wolves 1, shield us from hurt, ye Vasus! Turn the wheels with burning heat2 against him, and strike down the weapon of the impious fiend, O Rudras!

column1: citram tat vaḥ marutaḥ yāma cekite pr̥śnyāḥ yat ūdhaḥ api āpayaḥ duhuḥ yat vā nide navamānasya rudriyāḥ tritam jarāya juratām adābhyāḥ
column2: Your march, O Maruts, appears brilliant, whether even friends have milked the udder of Prisni, or whether, O sons of Rudra, you mean to blame him who praises you, and to weaken those who are weakening Trita, O unbeguiled heroes 1.

column1: tān vaḥ mahaḥ marutaḥ eva yāvnaḥ viṣṇoḥ eṣasya pra bhr̥the havāmahe hiraṇya varṇān kakuhān yata srucaḥ brahmaṇyantaḥ śaṁsyam rādhaḥ īmahe
column2: We invoke you, the great Maruts, the constant wanderers, at the offering of the rapid Vishnu 1; holding ladles (full of libations) and prayerful we ask the golden-coloured and exalted Maruts for glorious wealth.

column1: te daśa gvāḥ prathamāḥ yajñam ūhire te naḥ hinvantu uṣasaḥ vi uṣṭiṣu uṣāḥ na rāmīḥ aruṇaiḥ apa ūrṇute mahaḥ jyotiṣā śucatā go arṇasā
column2: The Dasagvas (Maruts?) 1 carried on 2 the sacrifice first; may they rouse us at the break of dawn. Like the dawn, they uncover the dark nights with the red (rays), the strong ones, with their brilliant light, as with a sea of milk.

column1: te kṣoṇībhiḥ aruṇebhiḥ na añji bhiḥ rudrāḥ r̥tasya sadaneṣu vavr̥dhuḥ ni meghamānāḥ atyena pājasā su candram varṇam dadhire su peśasam
column2: With the (morning) clouds, as if with glittering red ornaments 1, these Maruts have grown great in the sacred places 2. Streaming down with rushing splendour 3, they have assumed their bright and brilliant colour.

column1: tān iyānaḥ mahi varūtham ūtaye upa gha it enā namasā gr̥ṇīmasi tritaḥ na yān pañca hotr̥r̥r̥n abhiṣṭaye āvavartat avarān cakriyā avase
column2: Approaching 1 them for their great protection to help us, we invoke them with this worship, they whom Trita may bring near, like the five Hotri priests for victory 2, descending on their chariot to help.

column1: yayā radhram pārayatha ati aṁhaḥ yayā nidaḥ muñcatha vanditāram arvācī sā marutaḥ yā vaḥ ūtiḥ o iti su vāśrāiva su matiḥ jigātu
column2: May that grace of yours by which you help the wretched 1 across all anguish, and by which you deliver the worshipper from the reviler, come hither, O Maruts; may your favour approach us like a cow (going to her calf)!

column1: pra śyāva aśva dhr̥ṣṇu yā arca marut bhiḥ r̥kva bhiḥ ye adrogham anu svadham śravaḥ madanti yajñiyāḥ
column2: O Syâvâsva, sing boldly with 1 the Maruts, the singers who, worthy themselves of sacrifice, rejoice in their guileless glory 2 according to their nature.

column1: te hi sthirasya śavasaḥ sakhāyaḥ santi dhr̥ṣṇu yā te yāman ā dhr̥ṣat vinaḥ tmanā pānti śaśvataḥ
column2: They are indeed boldly the friends of strong power; they on their march protect all who by themselves are full of daring 1.

column1: te spandrāsaḥ na ukṣaṇaḥ ati skandanti śarvarīḥ marutām adha mahaḥ divi kṣamā ca manmahe
column2: Like rushing bulls, these Maruts spring over 1 the dark cows (the clouds) 2, and then we perceive the might of the Maruts in heaven and on earth.

column1: marut su vaḥ dadhīmahi stomam yajñam ca dhr̥ṣṇu yā viśve ye mānuṣā yugā pānti martyam riṣaḥ
column2: Let us boldly offer praise and sacrifice to your Maruts, to all them who protect the generation of men, who protect the mortal from injury.

column1: arhantaḥ ye su dānavaḥ naraḥ asāmi śavasaḥ pra yajñam yajñiyebhyaḥ divaḥ arca marut bhyaḥ
column2: They who are worthy, bounteous, men of perfect strength, to those heavenly Maruts who are worthy of sacrifice, praise the sacrifice!

column1: ā rukmaiḥ ā yudhā naraḥ r̥ṣvāḥ r̥ṣṭīḥ asr̥kṣata anu enān aha vi dyutaḥ marutaḥ jajjhatīḥ iva bhānuḥ arta tmanā divaḥ
column2: The tall men 1, coming near with their bright chains, and their weapon, have hurled forth their spears. Behind these Maruts there came by itself the splendour of heaven, like laughing lightnings 2.

column1: ye vavr̥dhanta pārthivāḥ ye urau antarikṣe ā vr̥jane vā nadīnām sadha sthe vā mahaḥ divaḥ
column2: Those who have grown up on earth, or in the wide sky, or in the realm of the rivers, or in the abode of the great heaven,

column1: śardhaḥ mārutam ut śaṁsa satya śavasam r̥bhvasam uta sma te śubhe naraḥ pra spandrāḥ yujata tmanā
column2: Praise that host of the Maruts, endowed with true strength and boldness 1, whether those rushing heroes have by themselves harnessed (their horses) for triumph,

column1: uta sma te paruṣṇyām ūrṇāḥ vasata śundhyavaḥ uta pavyā rathānām adrim bhindanti ojasā
column2: Or whether these brilliant Maruts have in the (speckled) cloud clothed themselves in wool 1, whether by their strength they cut the mountain asunder with the tire of their chariot;

column1: āpathayaḥ vi pathayaḥ antaḥ pathāḥ anu pathāḥ etebhiḥ mahyam nāma bhiḥ yajñam vi stāraḥ ohate
column2: Call them comers, or goers, or enterers, or followers, under all these names, they watch on the straw 1 for my sacrifice.

column1: adha naraḥ ni ohate adha ni yutaḥ ohate adha pārāvatāḥ iti citrā rūpāṇi darśyā
column2: The men (the Maruts) watch, and their steeds watch. Then, so brilliant are their forms to be seen, that people say, Look at the strangers 1!

column1: chandaḥ stubhaḥ kubhanyavaḥ utsam ā kīriṇaḥ nr̥tuḥ te me ke cit na tāyavaḥ ūmāḥ āsan dr̥śi tviṣe
column2: In measured steps 1 and wildly shouting 2 the gleemen 3 have danced toward the well (the cloud). They who appeared one by one like thieves, were helpers to me to see the light 4.

column1: yaḥ r̥ṣvāḥ r̥ṣṭi vidyutaḥ kavayaḥ santi vedhasaḥ tam r̥ṣe mārutam gaṇam namasya ramaya girā
column2: Worship, therefore, O seer, that host of Maruts, and keep and delight them with your voice, they who are themselves wise 1 poets, tall heroes armed with lightning-spears.

column1: accha r̥ṣe mārutam gaṇam dānā mitram na yoṣaṇā divaḥ vā dhr̥ṣṇavaḥ ojasā stutāḥ dhībhiḥ iṣaṇyata
column2: Approach, O seer, the host of Maruts, as a woman approaches a friend, for a gift 1; and you, Maruts, bold in your strength 2, hasten hither, even from heaven, when you have been praised by our hymns.

column1: nu manvānaḥ eṣām devān accha na vakṣaṇā dānā saceta sūri bhiḥ yāma śrutebhiḥ añji bhiḥ
column2: If he, after perceiving them, has approached them as gods with an offering, then may he for a gift remain united with the brilliant (Maruts), who by their ornaments are glorious on their march.

column1: pra ye me bandhu eṣe gām vocanta sūrayaḥ pr̥śnim vocanta mātaram adha pitaram iṣmiṇam rudram vocanta śikvasaḥ
column2: They, the wise 1 Maruts, the lords, who, when there was inquiry for their kindred, told me of the cow, they told me of Prisni as their mother, and of the strong Rudra as their father.

column1: sapta me sapta śākinaḥ ekam ekā śatā daduḥ yamunāyām adhi śr̥utam ut rādhaḥ gavyam mr̥je ni rādhaḥ aśvyam mr̥je
column2: The seven and seven heroes 1 gave me each a hundred. On the Yamunâ I clear off glorious wealth in cows, I clear wealth in horses.

column1: kaḥ veda jānam eṣām kaḥ vā purā sumneṣu āsa marutām yat yuyujre k ilāsyaḥ
column2: Who knows their birth? or who was of yore in the favour of the Maruts, when they harnessed the spotted deer 1?

column1: ā etān ratheṣu tasthuṣaḥ kaḥ śuśrāva kathā yayuḥ kasmai sasruḥ su dāse anu āpayaḥ il̥ābhiḥ vr̥ṣṭayaḥ saha
column2: Who has heard them when they had mounted their chariots, how they went forth? For the sake of what liberal giver (Sudâs) did they run, and their comrades followed 1, (as) streams of rain (filled) with food?

column1: te me āhuḥ ye āyayuḥ upa dyu bhiḥ vi bhiḥ made naraḥ maryāḥ arepasaḥ imān paśyan iti stuhi
column2: They themselves said to me when day by day 1 they came to the feast with their birds 2: they (the Maruts) are manly youths and blameless; seeing them, praise them thus;

column1: ye añjiṣu ye vāśīṣu sva bhānavaḥ srakṣu rukmeṣu khādiṣu śrāyāḥ ratheṣu dhanva su
column2: They who shine by themselves in their ornaments 1, their daggers, their garlands, their golden chains, their rings, going 2 on their chariots and on dry land.

column1: yuṣmākam sma rathān anu mude dadhe marutaḥ jīra dānavaḥ vr̥ṣṭī dyāvaḥ yatīḥ iva
column2: O Maruts, givers of quickening rain, I am made to rejoice, following after your chariots, as after days 1 going with rain.

column1: ā yam naraḥ su dānavaḥ dadāśuṣe divaḥ kośam acucyavuḥ vi parjanyam sr̥jantiḥrodasī itiḥanuḥdhanvanāḥyantiḥvr̥ṣṭayaḥ
column2: The bucket which the bounteous heroes shook down from heaven for their worshipper, that cloud they send 1 along heaven and earth, and showers follow on the dry land.

column1: tatr̥dānāḥ sindhavaḥ kṣodasā rajaḥ pra sasruḥ dhenavaḥ yathā syannāḥ aśvāḥ iva adhvanaḥ vi mocane vi yat vartante enyaḥ
column2: The rivers having pierced 1 the air with a rush of water, went forth like milk-cows; when your spotted deer roll about 2 like horses that have hasted to the resting-place on their road.

column1: ā yāta marutaḥ divaḥ ā antarikṣāt amāt uta mā ava sthāta parāvataḥ
column2: Come hither, O Maruts, from heaven, from the sky, even from near 1; do not go far away!

column1: iti it sumnam astu vaḥ
column2: Let not the Rasâ, the Anitabhâ, the Kubhâ, the Krumu, let not the Sindhu delay you! Let not the marshy Sarayu prevent you! May your favour be with us alone!

column1: tam vaḥ śardham rathānām tveṣam gaṇam mārutam navyasīnām anu pra yanti vr̥ṣṭayaḥ
column2: The showers come forth after the host of your chariots, after the terrible Marut-host of the ever-youthful heroes 1.

column1: śardham śardham vaḥ eṣām vrātam vrātam gaṇam gaṇam suśasti bhiḥ anu krāmema dhīti bhiḥ
column2: Let us then follow with our praises and our prayers each host of yours, each troop, each company 1.

column1: kasmai adya su jātāya rāta havyāya pra yayuḥ enā yāmena marutaḥ
column2: To what well-born generous worshipper have the Maruts gone to-day on that march,

column1: prati vaḥ vr̥ṣat añjayaḥ vr̥ṣṇe śardhāya mārutāya bharadhvam havyā vr̥ṣa prayāvṇe
column2: Bring forward, O strongly-anointed 1 (priests), your libations to the strong host of the Maruts, the strongly advancing.

column1: vr̥ṣaṇaśvena marutaḥ vr̥ṣa psunā rathena vr̥ṣa nābhinā ā śyenāsaḥ na pakṣiṇaḥ vr̥thā naraḥ havyā naḥ vītayegata
column2: O Maruts, O heroes, come quickly hither, like winged hawks, on your chariot with strong horses, of strong shape, with strong naves, to enjoy our libations.

column1: samānam añji eṣām vi bhrājante rukmāsaḥ adhi bāhuṣu davidyutati r̥ṣṭayaḥ
column2: Their anointing is the same, the golden chains shine on their arms, their spears sparkle.

column1: te ugrāsaḥ vr̥ṣaṇaḥ ugra bāhavaḥ nakiḥ tanūṣu yetire sthirā dhanvān i āyudhā ratheṣu vaḥ anīkeṣu adhi śriyaḥ
column2: These strong, manly, strong-armed Maruts, do not strive among themselves; firm are the bows, the weapons on your chariot, and on your faces are splendours.

column1: yeṣām arṇaḥ na sa prathaḥ nāma tveṣam śaśvatām ekam it bhuje vayaḥ na pitryam sahaḥ
column2: They whose terrible name 1, wide-spreading like the ocean, is the one of all that is of use, whose strength is like the vigour of their father,

column1: tān vandasva marutaḥ tān upa stuhi teṣām hi dhunīnām arāṇām na caramaḥ tat eṣām dānā mahnā tat eṣām
column2: Worship these Maruts, and praise them! Of these shouters, as of moving spokes 1, no one is the last; this is theirs by gift, by greatness 2 is it theirs.

column1: su bhagaḥ saḥ vaḥ ūtiṣu āsa pūrvāsu marutaḥ vi uṣṭiṣu yaḥ vā nūnam uta asati
column2: Happy is he who was under your protection, O Maruts, in former mornings, or who may be so even now.

column1: yasya vā yūyam prati vājinaḥ naraḥ ā havyā vītaye gatha abhi saḥ dyumnaiḥ uta vājasāti bhiḥ sumnā vaḥ dhūtayaḥ naśat
column2: Or he, O men, whose libations you went to enjoy; that mighty one, O shakers, will obtain your favours with brilliant riches and booty.

column1: yathā rudrasya sūnavaḥ divaḥ vaśanti asurasya vedhasaḥ yuvānaḥ tathā it asat
column2: As the sons of Rudra, the servants of the divine Dyu 1, win it, O youths, so shall it be.

column1: ye ca arhanti marutaḥ su dānavaḥ smat mīl̥huṣaḥ caranti ye ataḥ cit ā naḥ upa vasyasā hr̥dā yuvānaḥ ā vavr̥dhvam
column2: Whatever liberal givers may worship 1 the Maruts, and move about together as generous 2 benefactors, even from them turn 3 towards us with a kinder heart, you youths

column1: yūnaḥ oṁ iti su naviṣṭhayā vr̥ṣṇaḥ pāvakān abhi sobhare girā gāya gāḥ iva cakr̥rṣat
column2: O Sobhari, call loud with your newest song the young, strong, and pure Maruts, as the plougher calls the cows.

column1: sahāḥ ye santi muṣṭihāiva havyaḥ viśvāsu pr̥t su hotr̥ṣu vr̥ṣṇaḥ candrān na suśravaḥ tamān girā vandasva marutaḥ aha
column2: Worship the Maruts with a song, they who are strong like a boxer, called in to assist those who call 1 for him in all fights; (worship them) the most glorious, like bright-shining bulls.

column1: gāvaḥ cit gha sa manyavaḥ sa jātyena marutaḥ sa bandhavaḥ rihate kakubhaḥ mithaḥ
column2: Yes, O united friends, kindred, O Maruts, by a common birth, the oxen lick one another's humps 1.

column1: martaḥ cit vaḥ nr̥tavaḥ rukma vakṣasaḥ upa bhrātr̥ tvam ā ayati adhi naḥ gāta marutaḥ sadā hi vaḥ āpi tvam asti ni dhruvi
column2: O ye dancers, with golden ornaments on your chests, even a mortal comes (to ask) for your brotherhood 1; take care of us, ye Maruts, for your friendship lasts for ever.

column1: marutaḥ mārutasya naḥ ā bheṣajasya vahata su dānavaḥ yūyam sakhāyaḥ saptayaḥ
column2: O bounteous Maruts, bring us some of your Marut-medicine, you friends, and (quick, like) steeds.

column1: yābhiḥ sindhum avatha yābhiḥ tūrvatha yābhiḥ daśasyatha krivim mayaḥ naḥ bhūta ūti bhiḥ mayaḥ bhuvaḥ śivābhiḥ asaca dviṣaḥ
column2: With the favours whereby you favour the Sindhu, whereby you save, whereby you help Krivi 1, with those propitious favours be our delight, O delightful ones, ye who never hate your followers 2.

column1: yat sindhau yat asiknyām yat samudreṣu marutaḥ su barhiṣaḥ yat parvateṣu bheṣajam
column2: O Maruts, for whom we have prepared good altars, whatever medicine 1 there is on the Sindhu, on the Asiknî, in the seas, on the mountains,

column1: viśvam paśyantaḥ vibhr̥tha tanūṣu ā tena naḥ adhi vocata kṣamā rapaḥ marutaḥ āturasya naḥ iṣkarta vi hrutam punariti
column2: Seeing it, you carry it all on your bodies. Bless us with it! Down to the earth, O Maruts 1, what hurts our sick one,—straighten what is crooked!

column1: gauḥ dhayati marutām śravasyuḥ matā maghonām yuktā vahniḥ rathānām
column2: The cow, wishing for glory, the mother of the bounteous Maruts, sends forth her milk; the two horses 1 have been harnessed to the chariots,—

column1: yasyāḥ devāḥ upa sthe vratā viśve dhārayante sūryāmāsā dr̥śe kam
column2: She in whose lap 1 all gods observe their duties, sun and moon (also), that they may be seen;

column1: tat su naḥ viśve aryaḥ ā sadā gr̥ṇanti kāravaḥ marutaḥ soma pītaye
column2: Therefore all our friends 1, the singers, invite the Maruts always, to drink (our) Soma.

column1: asti somaḥ ayam sutaḥ pibanti asya marutaḥ uta sva rājaḥ aśvinā
column2: This Soma here has been prepared, the Maruts drink of it, the Asvins also drink of the lord (Soma) 1.

column1: pibanti mitraḥ aryamā tanā pūtasya varuṇaḥ tri sadhasthasya jāvataḥ
column2: Mitra, Aryaman, Varuna drink of the Soma which is continually 1 clarified, dwelling in three abodes 2, procuring offspring.

column1: uto iti nu asya joṣam ā indraḥ sutasya go mataḥ prātaḥ hotāiva matsati
column2: May Indra also rejoice to his satisfaction in this pressed juice, mixed with milk, like a Hotri 1 at the morning-sacrifice.

column1: kat atviṣanta sūrayaḥ tiraḥ āpaḥ iva sridhaḥ arṣanti pūta dakṣasaḥ
column2: Did the brilliant lords flare up? Endowed with pure strength they rush, like water, through their enemies.

column1: kat vaḥ adya mahānām devānām avaḥ vr̥ṇe tmanā ca dasma varcasām
column2: Shall I now choose the favour of you, the great gods, who by yourselves shine forth marvellously,

column1: ā ye viśvā pārthivāni paprathan rocanā divaḥ marutaḥ soma pītaye
column2: The Maruts, who, when going to drink Soma, spread out the whole earth and the lights of heaven 1.

column1: tyān nu pūta dakṣasaḥ divaḥ vaḥ marutaḥ huve asya somasya pītaye
column2: I call now them who are endowed with pure strength, you, O Maruts, from heaven, that you may drink the Soma here;

column1: tyān nu ye vi rodasī iti tastabhuḥ marutaḥ huve asya somasya pītaye
column2: I call now those Maruts who hold heaven and earth asunder, that they may drink the Soma here;

column1: tyam nu mārutam gaṇam giri sthām vr̥ṣaṇam huve asya somasya pītaye
column2: I call now that manly company of the Maruts, dwelling in the mountains, that they may drink the Soma here.

column1: abhra pruṣaḥ na vācā pruṣa vasu haviṣmantaḥ na yajñāḥ vi jānuṣaḥ su mārutam na brahmāṇam arhase gaṇam astoṣi eṣām na śobhase
column2: Let me with my voice shower 1 wealth like cloud-showers 2, like sacrifices of a sage, rich in oblations. I have praised the goodly host of the Maruts 3, so that they may be worthy of a Brahman 4 so that they may be glorious.

column1: śriye maryāsaḥ añjīn akr̥ṇvata su mārutam na pūrvīḥ ati kṣapaḥ di vaḥ putrāsaḥ etāḥ na yetire ādityāsaḥ te akrāḥ na vavr̥dhuḥ
column2: These boys have prepared their ornaments for beauty, the goodly host of the Maruts, through many nights; the sons of Dyu struggled, like harts, they, the Âdityas, grew high, like banners 1.

column1: pra ye divaḥ pr̥thivyāḥ na barhaṇā tmanā riricre abhrāt na sūryaḥ pājasvantaḥ na vīrāḥ panasyavaḥ riśādasaḥ na maryāḥ abhi dyavaḥ
column2: They who by their own might seem to have risen above heaven and earth, like the sun above the cloud, they are glorious, like brilliant heroes, they shine forth like foe-destroying youths.

column1: yuṣmākam budhne apām na yāmani vithuryati na mahī śratharyati viśva psuḥ yajñaḥ arvāk ayam su vaḥ prayasvantaḥ na satrācaḥ ā gata
column2: When you move along on the bottom of the waters, the earth seems to break and to melt 1. This perfect sacrifice is meet for you, come hither together, as if enjoying our offerings.

column1: yūyam dhūḥ su pra yujaḥ na raśmi bhiḥ jyotiṣmantaḥ na bhāsā vi uṣṭiṣu śyenāsaḥ na sva yaśasaḥ riśādasaḥ pravāsaḥ na pra sitāsaḥ pari pruṣaḥ
column2: You are as drivers 1 on the poles with their reins, and as brilliant with light at daybreak; like hawks, you are famous destroyers of foes; like wells 2 springing forth, you scatter moisture.

column1: pra yat vahadhve marutaḥ parākāt yūyam mahaḥ sam varaṇasya vasvaḥ vidānāsaḥ vasavaḥ rādhyasya ārāt cit dveṣaḥ sanutaḥ yuyota
column2: When you, O Maruts, come from afar, knowing the great treasure of the hidden place, O Vasus, the treasure which has to be gained, then keep away also from afar all who hate us.

column1: yaḥ ut r̥ci yajñe adhvare sthāḥ marut bhyaḥ na mānuṣaḥ dadāśat revat saḥ vayaḥ dadhate su vīram saḥ devānām api go pīthe astu
column2: The man who, firm in his sacrifice, offers gifts to the Maruts to the end of the ceremony 1, he gains health and wealth, blessed with offspring; he shall also be in the keeping of the gods.

column1: te hi yajñeṣu yajñiyāsaḥ ūmāḥ ādityena nāmnā śam bhaviṣṭhāḥ te naḥ avantu ratha tūḥ manīṣām mahaḥ ca yāman adhvare cakānāḥ
column2: They are indeed our guardians, to be worshipped at all sacrifices, most blissful by their name of Âdityas; may they, swiftly driving on their chariots, protect our prayer, quick even on their march, delighting in our sacrifice.

column1: viprāsaḥ na manma bhiḥ su ādhyaḥ deva avyaḥ na yajñaiḥ su apnasaḥ rājānaḥ na citrāḥ su sandr̥śaḥ kṣitīnām na maryāḥ arepasaḥ
column2: Full of devotion like priests with their prayers, wealthy like pious men, who please the gods with their offerings, beautiful to behold like brilliant kings, without a blemish like the youths of our hamlets—

column1: agniḥ na ye bhrājasā rukma vakṣasaḥ vātāsaḥ na sva yujaḥ sadyaḥ ūtayaḥ pra jñātāraḥ na jyeṣṭhāḥ su nītayaḥ su śarmāṇaḥ na somāḥ r̥tam yate
column2: They who are gold-breasted like Agni with his splendour, quick to help like self-harnessed winds, good leaders like the oldest experts, they are to the righteous man like Somas, that yield the best protection.

column1: vātāsaḥ na ye dhunayaḥ jigatnavaḥ agnīnām na jihvāḥ vi rokiṇaḥ varmaṇ vantaḥ na yodhāḥ śimī vantaḥ pitr̥r̥ṇām na śaṁsāḥ su rātayaḥ
column2: They who are roaring and hasting like winds, brilliant like the tongues of fires, powerful like mailed soldiers, full of blessings like the prayers of our fathers,

column1: rathānām na ye arāḥ sa nābhayaḥ jigīvāṁsaḥ na śūrāḥ abhi dyavaḥ vare yavaḥ na maryāḥ ghr̥ta pruṣaḥ abhi svartāraḥ arkam na su stubhaḥ
column2: Who hold together like the spokes of chariot-wheels, who glance forward like victorious heroes, who scatter ghrita 1 like wooing youths, who chant beautifully like singers, intoning a hymn of praise,

column1: aśvāsaḥ na ye jyeṣṭhāsaḥ āśavaḥ didhiṣavaḥ na rathyaḥ su dānavaḥ āpaḥ na nimnaiḥ uda bhiḥ jigatnavaḥ viśva rūpāḥ aṅgirasaḥ na sāma bhiḥ
column2: Who are swift like the best of horses, who are bounteous like lords of chariots on a suit, who are hastening on like water with downward floods, who are like the manifold 1 Aṅgiras with their (numerous) songs.

column1: grāvāṇaḥ na sūrayaḥ sindhu mātaraḥ ādardirāsaḥ adrayaḥ na viśvahā śiśūlāḥ na krīl̥ayaḥ su mātaraḥ mahāgrāmaḥ na yāman uta tv iṣā
column2: These noble sons of Sindhu 1 are like grinding-stones, they are always like Soma-stones 2, tearing everything to pieces; these sons of a good mother are like playful children, they are by their glare like a great troop on its march.

column1: uṣasām na ketavaḥ adhvara śriyaḥ śubham yavaḥ na añji bhiḥ vi aśvitan sindhavaḥ na yayiyaḥ bhrājat r̥ṣṭayaḥ parāvataḥ na yojanāni mamire
column2: Illumining the sacrifice 1 like the rays of the dawn, they shone forth in their ornaments like triumphant warriors; the Maruts with bright spears seem like running rivers, from afar they measure many miles.

column1: su bhāgān naḥ devāḥ kr̥ṇuta su ratnān asmān stotr̥r̥n marutaḥ vavr̥dhānāḥ adhi stotrasya sakhyasya gāta sanāt hi vaḥ ratna dheyāni santi
column2: O gods, make us happy and rich, prospering us, your praisers, O Maruts! Remember our praise and our friendship, for from of old there are always with you gifts of treasures.

column1: hiraṇya garbhaḥ sam avartata agre bhūtasya jātaḥ patiḥ ekaḥ āsīt saḥ dādhāra pr̥thivīm dyām uta imām kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: In the beginning there arose the Golden Child (Hiranya-garbha 1); as soon as born, he alone was the lord of all that is. He stablished the earth and this heaven:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: yaḥ ātma dāḥ bala dāḥ yasya viśve upa āsate pra śiṣam yasya devāḥ yasya chāyām r̥tam yasya mr̥tyuḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: He who gives breath, he who gives strength, whose 1 command all the bright gods revere, whose shadow 2 is immortality, whose shadow is death:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: yaḥ prāṇataḥ ni miṣataḥ mahi tvā ekaḥ it rājā jagataḥ babhūva yaḥ īśe asya dvi padaḥ catuḥ padaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: He who through his might became the sole king of the breathing and twinkling 1 world, who governs all this, man and beast:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: yasya ime hima vantaḥ mahi tvā yasya samudram rasayā saha āhuḥ yasya imāḥ pra diśaḥ yasya bāhū iti kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: He through whose might 1 these snowy mountains are, and the sea, they say, with the distant river (the Rasâ 2), he of whom these regions are indeed the two arms:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: yena dyauḥ ugrā pr̥thivī ca dr̥l̥hā yena svar iti svaḥ stabhitam yena nākaḥ yaḥ antarikṣe rajasaḥ vi mānaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: He through whom the awful heaven and the earth were made fast 1, he through whom the ether was stablished, and the firmament; he who measured the air in the sky 2:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: yam krandasī iti avasā tastabhāne iti abhi aikṣetām manasā rejamāne yatra adhi sūraḥ ut itaḥ vi bhāti kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: He to whom heaven and earth 1, standing firm by his will, look up, trembling in their mind; he over whom the risen sun shines forth:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: āpaḥ ha yat br̥hatīḥ viśvam āyan garbham dadhānāḥ janayantīḥ agn im tataḥ devānām sam avartata asuḥ ekaḥ kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: When the great waters 1 went everywhere, holding the germ (Hiranya-garbha), and generating light, then there arose from them the (sole 2) breath of the gods:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: yaḥ cit āpaḥ mahinā pari apaśyat dakṣam dadhānāḥ janayantīḥ yajñam yaḥ deveṣu adhi devaḥ ekaḥ āsīt kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: He who by his might looked even over the waters which held power (the germ) and generated the sacrifice (light 1), he who alone is God above all gods 2:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: mā naḥ hiṁsīt janitā yaḥ pr̥thivyāḥ yaḥ vā divam satya dharmā jajāna yaḥ ca apaḥ candrāḥ br̥hatīḥ jajāna kasmai devāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: May he not hurt us, he who is the begetter of the earth, or he, the righteous, who begat the heaven; he who also begat the bright and mighty waters:—Who is the God to whom we shall offer sacrifice?

column1: prajāpatena tvad etāny anyo viśvājatāniparitā babhūva yatkāmās te juhumas tan noastu vayaṁ syāmapatayo rayīṇām
column2: 1 Pragâpati, no other than thou embraces all these created things. May that be ours which we desire when sacrificing to thee: may we be lords of wealth!]

column1: vātasya nu mahimānam rathasya rujan eti stanayan asya ghoṣaḥ di vi spr̥k yāti aruṇāni kr̥ṇvan uto iti eti pr̥thivyā reṇum asyan
column2: Now for the greatness of the chariot of Vâta 1! Its roar goes crashing and thundering. It moves touching the sky, and creating red sheens 2, or it goes scattering the dust of the earth.

column1: sam pra īrate anu vātasya vi sthāḥ ā enam gacchanti samanam na yoṣāḥ tābhiḥ sa yuk sa ratham devaḥ īyate asya viśvasya bhuvanasya rājā
column2: Afterwards there rise the gusts of Vâta 1, they go towards him, like women to a feast 2. The god goes with them on the same chariot, he, the king of the whole of this world.

column1: antarikṣe pathi bhiḥ īyamānaḥ na ni viśate katamat cana ahariti apām sakhā prathama jāḥ r̥ta vā kva svit jātaḥ kutaḥ ā babhūva
column2: When he moves on his paths along the sky, he rests not even a single day 1; the friend of the waters, the first-born, the holy, where was he born, whence did he spring?

column1: ātmā devānām bhuvanasya garbhaḥ yathāvaśam carati devaḥ eṣaḥ ghoṣāḥ it asya śr̥ṇvire na rūpam tasmai vātāya haviṣā vidhema
column2: The breath of the gods, the germ 1 of the world, that god moves wherever he listeth; his roars indeed are heard, not his form—let us offer sacrifice to that Vâta!

column1: vātaḥ ā vātu bheṣajam śam bhu māyaḥ bhu naḥ hr̥de pra naḥ āyūṁṣi tāriṣat
column2: May Vâta waft medicine, healthful, delightful to our heart; may he prolong our lives!

column1: uta vāta pitā asi naḥ uta bhrātā uta naḥ sakhā saḥ naḥ jīvātave kr̥dhi
column2: Thou, O Vâta, art our father, and our brother, and our friend; do thou grant us to live!

column1: yat adaḥ vāta te gr̥he amr̥tasya nidhiḥ hitaḥ tataḥ naḥ dehi jīvase
column2: O Vâta, from that treasure of the immortal which is placed in thy house yonder, give us to live!

column1: agnim īl̥e puraḥ hitam yajñasya devam r̥tvijam hotāram ratna dhātamam
column2: 1 I magnify 2 Agni, the Purohita, the divine ministrant of the sacrifice, the Hotri priest, the greatest bestower of treasures.
